Posted: September 22, 2014
												I want to start off by saying I do not have depression and that I have heard a lot of negative things about this game and how it's not really a game etc.But.This game, is a game. It does involve choices and a story and somewhat of a level of immersion, now as a game it doesn't really deliver any sort of exposition to the player, it just sort of expects you to pick up on it, which kind of confused me near the beginning, I had questions about who my character was? if it was supposed to be me or someone I'm playing? I also was slightly confused with the cast of characters because of the gender neutral names and the lack of any true back story. So as a game this has a few flaws but the story is not one that's bad, the way its told is not bad, the difficulty is extremely easy but, I don't really see the game as something that is about winning, it seems to be more about experiencing depression through the eyes of this character. I honestly believe this game shouldn't have as much flak as it's getting, I will probably start a discussion to further my opinions on this game because its so.... currently noted.So now the standard game rating:Story: 7/10 (Its a story and its not really explained well, there are some branching sort of choices but all together its very short but well written.)Gameplay: X/10 (Text adventure things don't really count for gameplay, all of them have choices and reading, you don't add anything to that normally. Its not bad, but it cannot be rated.)Presentation: 8/10 (It wasn't just a webpage or something like that, but it wasn't fancy at all either. I like how it mixes everything together well, although that's fairly simple for a game this short.)Soundtrack: 7/10 (It fits, it ships, but it is annoying as ♥♥♥♥.)Replayability: 0/10 (Plain and simple I'm not coming back to this game, it was good for one round, maybe two and since its free the replayabilty isn't that much of a factor anyway.)As a game, it's free, it's not the game that I want to play on a saturday night, nor any other day, for that reason I'm giving it a thumbs down as a GAME. In an informational/emotional way, this game is worth playing if you're curious, or maybe if you have depression.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												This is not a game. It's hardly even a "text based adventure". It consists of reading walls of average-at-best text and choosing from a few different options. Depending on previous choices, you can get to a point where there isn't any choice at all- every option but one is crossed out. I guess the developers were trying to represent the lack of motivation that can come with depression, but when your attempt to simulate depression results in 20 minutes of clicking through boring pages of text, you've done something wrong. After playing through this "game", I just found myself angry and offended. It claims to try to help people without depression understand what people with it go through, but all it really accomplishes is making people with depression look lazy, completely unmotivated and utterly incapable of making any good decisions to improve their situation. I have depression. It does make you feel like crap, it can destroy your motivation. What it doesn't do is prevent you from trying to get help. When one of the characters gave the protagonist the phone number for a therapist and my only option was to crumple up the note and throw it away, I just sat in silence. That's the main problem with this garbage (aside from the fact that it's a boring piece of junk)- it portrays what I can only assume is one of the developers' experience with depression as what all sufferers go through. Maybe their depression makes them just sit around and watch Netflix to distract themselves from their crippling lack of motivation and sadness, but mine doesn't. Every case is different, and frankly, I find this game insulting to anyone who does suffer from depression. It's an insulting, patronizing chore with a poorly thought out choice system and subpar writing. If you want to learn about and understand depression, go look it up on Wikipedia or a mental health website. This garbage isn't worth anybody's time.

That made me sad.UPDATE: Since Steam intervened and my review is no longer falsely flagged as "abusive" by the developer, I can finally edit it and add one last thing. If any of you are interested in playing a video game that revolves around depression, try The Cat Lady or Neverending Nightmares instead. They both handle the subject in a very mature manner without sacrificing content.

The ideas that I came across in this game were ♥♥♥♥ing pathetic and the decisions you can make (if not forced) are not entirely realistic or wise when you are in that state of mind. If you want a game with a more legitimate grasp on the subject of depression play something like Neverending Nightmares or Until Dawn.If you think you are suffering with depression, I implore you to talk to your GP. If they believe you are suffering from depression you will be sent to a hospital for treatment (in my experience). If you are experiencing suicidal thoughts you will most likely stay in hospital for several weeks. Another route is by contacting Healthy Minds, and NHS-run program which has helped me get in touch with some valuable people and continue, to this day, to help me understand my own mental health.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2016
												As someone who suffers from depression for over 10 years (and counting, since at least for me, it isn’t something that can be “cured”; sometimes it “goes away”, but it always comes back. It finds its way home and crawls back, even with proper medication/therapy/love/whatever. It’s not that simple, some people might be “cured”, but it’s definitely not the same for everyone else. It’s a constant thing in a person’s life, it appears when you less expect), I felt that this game was not real. First, I felt that the MC was suffering from the effects of depression beginning to grow. But having choices literally locked because apparently “you can’t do that” made me angry. People can TRY to do those things even tho they are depressed! Locking the options was a terrible thing in my opinion, leading the MC to an endless spiral of unworthy feelings, when I actually wanted to help them. This kills the concept of the game, which was supposed to be interactive and you could attempt to make the MC get help.Character development wasn’t good either. MC was too plain, I couldn’t feel any sympathy for them, same for the other characters. This could have been a decent/good game (I honestly believe that), but it’s not.Please don’t treat this subject like a superficial aspect. I know this wasn’t meant to be a “happy game”, but it’s not that simple.

number of helpful: 59 of 82 people (72%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
												Depression Quest is an interactive narrative with a set goal: to try to help people who haven’t experienced depression understand what it’s like for the sufferer. However, throughout my time with the narrative, I couldn’t focus as much on the goal of the story because of the poor implementation of the game design itself.You play as an unnamed character who struggles with depression that progressively gets more burdensome as the game goes on. The goal of using an unnamed character was probably to put the player in the character’s shoes, but for me, it only served to give me no real connection to the character. In the first few pages of the game, when the character is introduced, there are various links to other pages that explain some of the context for future situations. One, for example, is described as “a project you’ve been working on,” but since it doesn’t go into detail, the player loses a connection with the character that could’ve been more personal. At the end of a long section of pages, when the character needs to make a decision, there are a few different options, with the first always crossed out—the next few will continually be crossed out as the depression worsens. This option is clearly supposed to show what the character could do, if not for the depression, but instead it just distracts from the actual possible choices and the player finally picks something to just get past the page.The music and overall design of each page also leaves the player feeling bored and uninterested. The supposedly “sad” piano music is distracting from the text, and the page itself, being a static, gray affair, doesn’t do much—if anything—to hold the player’s attention and keep them focused on the story. The status buttons below decision options are also static, with a poor font choice, and slightly distract the player from the options available. Another problem is that you cannot stop playing and pick back up where you left off. For a game with such a bland, boring interface, not having this option makes the player even less likely to want to work back through the game, if they have to stop playing for some reason. Overall, this game could have been much better, if it had been designed to better keep and hold the player’s attention. As it is, there are too many distracting things going on and not enough draw to the story to keep the player interested and caring about the outcome.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2016
												As someone who has struggled with depression since early adolescence, and witnessed persons with far greater afflictions than myself… this game is borderline offensive. While I applaud the attempt to address mental health, something that is arguably lacking in modern media in general, this is a momentous failure. This choose your own adventure-esque game tries to confront depression through poor storytelling, artificially constricted choice, and lack of understanding of depression. The absence of quality is unbelievable. Mental conditions cannot be simulated - any attempt to do so is totally misguided. Believing that understanding illness can be imparted through such ridiculously removed circumstances is, in layman's terms, the pinnacle of stupidity. You might as well create a Lower Respiratory Infection Quest, as it would allow the gamer to arrive at no more greater understanding of contracting a potentially lethal disease, than would Depression Quest impart knowledge of undergoing a potentially lethal mental condition. 1/10

number of helpful: 25 of 29 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 19, 2014
												As a person who suffers from depression and has to deal with the hardships on a day to day basis I can honestly say that I am offended that this title is trying to say that it recreates such difficulties in any way. The writing barely skims over daily challenges, makes it seem like therapy and medication are miracle cures, and that depression is just easily overcome. Yes, at the end of the story it says some fluff about this being a lifelong struggle, but the story never delvs into anything more than superficially. It feels as though the warnings of possible triggers were only put in place so that persons who actually suffer from this condition don't see this and point out how absolutely flawed it is.Putting the subject matter aside, I am offended that this somehow managed to get through Steam's Greenlight program when so many great games do not. This is arguably a game, and it fails on all accounts even when it comes to interactive fiction. The audio is abysmal, coming across as annoying more than saddening, what little graphics are present are blurry and come across more as product placements, and the interactivity is so minute that I felt the need to write this review to get the value from my time spent. Depression Quest should be avoided, removed from Steam, and the developers should be scolded for ever releasing it.

number of helpful: 25 of 29 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 19, 2014
												I heard about this game from all of the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that last few days revolving around its creator.  I was diagnosed with severe depression in high school and went though several anti-depressants and therapists. I'm now in my last semester of college and all is going well but High School was rough on me but mostly on my family.  So, I was thinking that I could possibly be able to relate to this game because of my past experiences.  I could not, this is not a good representation of depression and it is not a good representation of video games, hell it isn't even a game.  Ok, so what is the game?  It is a text based adventure where you are given a set of text and then have to choose a reponse based on that.  These response are in the form of hypertext and this could basically be a webpage and there would be no difference.  Whatever, the actualy gameplay is bland but it is text based, what would you expect?My core issue here lies in the representation of depression and the way the "adventure" is set up.  So it starts you as a depressed person with not much context as to how you got there.  Then, it throws you in with a cast of characters who seem  to want to help you but no matter what I did my character was constantly in a downward spiral.  It seemed like the creator was under the impression that a depressed person can only be helped by therapy and SSRI's (anti-depressants).  This game perpuates the idea (which is wrong) that all depression can be fixed with drugs and that all depression is basically the same.  This is anything but though truth, there are thousands of factors that can influence depression.  Diet, excersize, lack of vitamin D, getting a blood test to test for lack of SERT (serotonin transporters), or drug abuse.  You do not have the option to explore any of these.  No, you are on a downward spiral and you can't get help to get better.  It is a terrible representation of depression because depression is something that simply can't be represented in a video game.There are reasons that doctors spent years and years studying depression and mental illnesses because there are millions of factors and millions of solution and possiblities.  This game is not just an embarrassment to video games but to people who are unlucky enough to suffer from depression and or anxiety.  How this game got past greenlight simply blows my mind.  I can not recommend this game at all, to anyone.  If you are suffering from depression, know this, there is help and there are people out there who care about you.  I was lucky enough to have my parents and they are the the primary reason I graduated highschool and made my way into college.  Please to remember,  It gets better, I promise.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2015
												Despite the controversy surrounding this game, I was very interested in trying it out. As someone who has had (maybe even still dealing with) depression, I was excited to see its entry into the gaming world. Unfortunately, I found I was troubled by the image of depression that this game offers, and I have to wonder if this could do more harm than good. It didn't feel as if the person the player is controlling is even a person. I felt like I was wheeling a wooden plank through a series of rooms, so lacking in personality or any distinguishable features that I found myself bored, and struggling to read the text that was telling me how I was 'feeling'. It worries me that the person this game is portraying is dull, boring, robotic. While some ambiguity and vagueness is needed in order for any player to put themselves in the character's shoes, I felt like that vagueness was taken to a point where we can no longer truly care for the character. I was also troubled by the lack of options. As someone who has experienced depression, I know that there are times where it feels like options are limited. But people don't express depression in the same way. I have been the person that, despite feeling like death inside, I went out, feigned happiness. I went out and did things, even if I wasn't being honest with people, and that was part of my problem. That was something I had to deal with for years, giving the appearance I was happy and healthy, when I wasn't. I was disappointed to find that so many of the options I'd have chosen, the options that would make sense to not just me, but probably many other people just trying to survive, and maintain the life one has, were just simply crossed out, as if the mere thought of doing such a thing was preposterous. I couldn't help but feel just a bit insulted by that. That my experience was an impossibility. So no, I would not recommend this game. Not to my friends, not to people who have never experienced depression, and most definitely not to others who have gone through what this game tries desperately to depict.

content:
Posted: August 30, 2014
												I feel a bit bad for having to say this but. . .this isn't a game. It isn't even really a realistic account of someone with depression. I've grappled with it for some time and as of this review things seem to keep getting worse. I've lost practialy everything from loved ones to transportation and most recently a job. To say that I am about as low as I can get might be the biggist understatment since Lady Godiva walked into her stable and said she had absolutly nothing to ware. I tried to play this "game" out as I would in real life, I've seen profecionals and even tried medication, however in the end this "game" told me that I should be on the mend. I can attest I am not. I think it might have made me focus on my problems even more, because it's telling me things should get better. If you're going to make a text based "choose your own ending" type game you must give the player the option of choosing their own adventure. Locking off answers and simply saying "You'll never NOT be depressed" is frankly the antithisis of gaming. If the developer is baseing this senario off of a personal story then I'm happy to see that they may have a light at the end of their tunel, but in the end Depression Quest just reminded me that the light. . .is sometimes a train.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												I have read some articles with arguements and counter arguements on this game. So I decided to have a go, maybe only because the counter-arguements were developed in such a juvenile attitude. First of all, as a person who suffered depression couple of times in his life, this game fails to describe the emotions and perception of every day life of a depressed person. It repetitively tells that you are exhausted, tired, nothing to keep you going but when it comes to the actual feelings that depression creates, it is possible to say narration and description in the game is quite bland and dull. If you want to know how depression actually feels, you can always listen to People Are Strange from The Doors.Also I don't think that this game should be on Steam. As an educative tool on internet, it might help some people but here, it probably won't. If you want to tell a story about a depressed person, do it in the way Telltale Games does, if you want to explore the depths of a human mind, do it in the way Psychonauts does, do you want to express the perception of every day life in depression, get some ideas from Quantic Dreams (or even Max Payne) this is not the way how you can accomplish these with a "game" on Steam. Considering they are in the same genre, the Commodore64 game Alter-Ego is still so much better than this so called game.As I said above, be helpful to people, it's a good cause. Seriously. But please don't call this a game. The right definition you're looking for is "interactive educative tool."P.S.: Most of the people writing reviews on this game here have the intellect of a pile of manure. You cannot judge a product of a person with his or her sex and love life. You have no right to judge a person's sex and love life. Get on with your lives, because seems like you're not doing anything to contribute to the society. number of helpful: 27 of 35 people (77%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												To be completely honest, I have (knowingly) lived with depression for over 10 years. I deliberately ignored the warning to see what this "game" had to offer. Long story short, I had a really bad breakdown and then I decided to go to therapy. So there was some benefit to me playing this.If you have depression, this is nowhere near accurate because, even at my suicidal worst, I was still able to make myself do things. The best ending in the scenario presented isn't necessarily the right one in real life. Medication doesn't work for everybody, there are therapists who are motivated solely by money and, in my case, people aren't always understanding of what you're going through. However, like others have said, you're not alone in the end.If you don't have depression, the same inaccuracy applies, but I will say that it can offer some insight into what depression is. There are still a lot of people who think it's a choice/lifestyle. I think DQ busted that myth just fine, but it's not always evident when someone is depressed and there is a spectrum of kinds of depression. There isn't always consistency with depression. Believe it or not, we have good days too. In the end, Depression Quest was a bit of an eye-opener for me personally. YMMV, but don't expect all the answers to be here.

content:
Posted: August 30, 2014
												If you are depressed, do not touch this "game."If you are suicidal, do not touch this game.If you have a history of depression, do not touch this game.If you've been depressed in the past but think, "Hey, I'm doing quite well. I first checked out the website and then the game here on Steam. I spent over two hours going through different options.The writing itself is mediocre. The decisions you make from one encounter to the next have some impact on what happens next, but not a whole lot, other than determining if the protagonist gets more or less depressed. The more depressed, the less likely the character will be able to dig himself out, reach out to friends or otherwise seek help.For a resource focused primarily on text, it sure has a LOT of typos.If you are someone interested in reading the diary of a depressed person, Depression Quest may be for you. If you are having trouble communicating with a depressed loved one, perhaps this can be useful to gain some insight into your loved one's mind.However, do not bother installing this through Steam. Just look up the web site. They're EXACTLY THE SAME.

number of helpful: 21 of 25 people (84%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												I'm severely cynical of all sides in the recent social justice craze. Individuals must be objectively judged for there to be true justice, regardless of their stance on (insert prejudice or cause here), and hopping on a indignation hype train is not the way to do it.Criticism of the development staffmembers involved aside, there is some good information to be had from this project. Do I believe it belongs on Steam? No. Do I believe it could potentially assist the general public with becoming more educated about "depression" as a whole? Sure.It feels disingenuous to call this a game, when it's more like an after-school special, or a pamphlet you'd find at a clinic. Having had to live with and help many people in my life come to terms with and work through their issues, I understand exactly the message trying to be conveyed, but also fully understand that the only people who would benefit from a run or two through this "story" are practically non-existent: simultaneously open-minded and ignorant.A person with depression doesn't need this to understand depression, because they live it. A person who deals with depression in others doesn't need this to understand depression, because they live(d) with it.A person who honestly believes depression is not a real illness doesn't understand depression, and this won't convince them otherwise.This belongs on a website, which I believe was its original form. It must be easily and publicly accessible, and distributed, to be truly effective. I recommend talking about depression to raise awareness, but can't recommend this on Steam because it (and mental illness) isn't a game.

number of helpful: 22 of 27 people (81%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
												Depression Quest has stirred up quite the controversy and has already received many negative reviews as well as a lot of troll reviews that are to be honest hilarilously funny. I was really tempted to write a troll review myself but I'll try to give a honest review here. Im aware that it is highly debatable if Depression Quest qualifies as a game or not but I will at times refer to it as "the game" and to the act of using it as "playing". I don't want to scratch the topic if it's a game or not but I'll use those words for convenience.In Depression Quest you play as a person with depression trying to manage daily life. The game is fairly minimalistic and basically looks like a website with white background and some gifs. It can be controlled with the mouse or suprisingly with a gamepad. Depression Quest plays like a "choose your own adventure"-book. You basically read a short story and sometimes get to choose from a set of options to determine how the story continues. The problem is that despite the advertising there is not much to choose from here. Some people complain that many of the options are crossed out and not selectable. However, I think that is actually getting the point of knowing what the right thing to do is while being unable to do it across. Depression Quest portrays depression and it does not do a particularly bad job at it but it is all that it does. It does not offer any way out, what is depressing in itself. If that was the point of it then it works out well but I think that there should be more to it. As it stands Depression Quest does work as an art project but has severe shortcomings in the game department. The writing is not great but is does its job. It just feels too clichéd at times. During the first minute it almost put me off immediately though because it comes with a trigger warning. Also it describes the protagonist as a "human being" instead of specifying the gender or just using ''you''. The problem is that the developer apparently forgot about that part immediately. For the rest of the game it is clear that the player character is in fact male. I really wonder what the original point was then.I would not recommend Depression Quest to anybody who is actually suffering from depression or anybody not interested in the topic. If you want to get a basic understanding of the way people with depression think it's worth a look though. However, I say that only because it is free. If it would cost actual money I would advise you to stay away from it.Depression Quest is not completely horrible but below average and has next to no target audience. To a certain degree it does what it was set out to do. What it does is however not for everyone, even among the expected target audience. Some people with living depression may share similar experiences to those depicted in the game, others won't at all. If you want to play a simplistic game that explores the human condition you are better off with Papers, Please since that game does not simply describe a situation but presents you with a moral dilemma and communicates its message through actual gameplay. As for Depression Quest... it takes no advantage of the medium at all.More reviews here

number of helpful: 15 of 17 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												Before I begin, I've noticed that due to recent controversy, this game has received a large amount of backlash, all of which is either a personal attack on the people behind it or dismissing it, based on the first screen. I hope to be a little more constructive...I was quite looking forward to Depression Quest as I'm no stranger to depression, I've felt different kinds in the past and I'm currently going through a rough patch at the moment. I was also a big fan of Dear Esther, another game that centered around depression, loss and grief and I loved To the Moon for its similar themes.I was equally as disappointed as most to see that the game was about advanced as a basic website, a white background, with text and a depressing piano rift but, obviously, I tried to see past that and tried to judge the game on its story and the things that it DOES offer.What it offers is a scenario, in which it tells you, your problem and then gives you a list of options, asking you how you would proceed. I usually like this style of storytelling, like in Tell Tale's games or your average RPG and went along with it but I was a bit puzzled to see that two of the options were crossed out and one of them was the option that I would have picked. It didn't take me long to see through the message, that this game appeared to be conveying.The logical answer is always crossed off the list, meaning that people suffering from depression aren't capable of ever doing the logical thing. Though this may be true for some cases, it's not true for EVERYONE and it's certainly isn't a rock hard fact. The reason that it, especially, bothers me is the fact that the only thing you do is read a wall of text before making a decision and after a few minutes, the decision aspect is completely taken away from you, to the point that you just read a wall of text and then click the only option presented to you.I tried to make it to the end, hearing that it tries to accurately simulate depression, by taking the colour out of the world but I just couldn't get to the end of it. I was incredibly bored and I couldn't even get worked up over it anymore, the music was just depressing the hell out of me and I found myself trapped in a seemingly endless monotonous cycle, where I just read text and clicked options, that weren't mine.I've always been very liberal with my definition of what a game is, some said that Dear Esther wasn't a game and I argued against that but this? I don't know, I don't believe that it is a 'game' as you could recreate the experience by listening to a playlist of every depressing song/theme you know, whilst reading something off of fanfiction.net and occasionally slapping yourself across the face.In conclusion; I wouldn't recommend it, I don't believe that it is an accurate portrayal of depression and I struggle to see where the 'it's a game!' argument is coming from. If you want a better experience, I'd recommend Dear Esther or To the Moon over this as both are much better interractive stories.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												The War of 1812 was a military conflict, lasting for two-and-a-half years, fought by the United States of America against the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, its North American colonies, and its American Indian allies. Seen by the United States and Canada as a war in its own right, it is frequently seen in Europe as a theatre of the Napoleonic Wars, as it was caused by issues related to that war (especially the Continental System). The war resolved many issues which remained from the American Revolutionary War but involved no boundary changes. The United States declared war on June 18, 1812 for several reasons, including trade restrictions brought about by the British war with France, the impressment of American merchant sailors into the Royal Navy, British support of Indian tribes against American expansion, outrage over insults to national honor after humiliations on the high seas, and possible American interest in annexing British territory in modern-day Canada.[3]The war was fought in three principal theatres. Firstly, at sea, warships and privateers of each side attacked the other's merchant ships, while the British blockaded the Atlantic coast of the United States and mounted large raids in the later stages of the war. Secondly, land and naval battles were fought on the American–Canadian frontier, which ran along the Great Lakes, the Saint Lawrence River and the northern end of Lake Champlain. Thirdly, the American South and Gulf Coast also saw big land battles, in which the American forces defeated Britain's Indian allies and a British invasion force at New Orleans. At the end of the war both sides signed the Treaty of Ghent and both parties returned occupied land to its pre-war owner and resumed friendly trade relations.With the majority of its land and naval forces tied down in Europe fighting the Napoleonic Wars, the British used a defensive strategy in the Provinces of Upper and Lower Canada, repelling initial American invasions. Early victories over poorly led American armies such as the Battle of Queenston Heights, demonstrated that the conquest of the Canadas would prove more difficult than anticipated. Despite this, the Americans were able to inflict serious defeats on Britain's native American allies, ending the prospect of an Indian confederacy and an independent Indian state in the Midwest under British sponsorship. US forces were also able to make several gains on the Canadian frontier; taking control of Lake Erie in 1813 and seizing western parts of Upper Canada. However a large-scale American attempt to capture Montreal was repulsed in November 1813, and serious American attempts to conquer Upper Canada were ultimately abandoned following the bloody Battle of Lundy's Lane in July 1814.In April 1814, with the defeat of Napoleon, the British adopted a more aggressive strategy, sending larger invasion armies and tightening their naval blockade. However, with the end of the Napoleonic Wars in Europe, both governments were eager for a return to normality and peace negotiations began in Ghent in August 1814. In September 1814, the British invaded and occupied eastern Maine. In the south-west, General Andrew Jackson destroyed the military strength of the Creek nation at the Battle of Horseshoe Bend. The British victory at the Battle of Bladensburg in August 1814 allowed them to capture and burn Washington, D.C, but they were repulsed in an attempt to take Baltimore. American victories in September 1814 at the Battle of Plattsburgh repulsed the British invasions of New York, which along with pressure from merchants on the British government prompted British diplomats to drop their demands at Ghent for an independent native buffer state and territorial claims that London previously sought. Both sides agreed to a peace that restored the situation before the war began. However, it took six weeks for ships to cross the Atlantic so news of the peace treaty did not arrive before the British suffered a major defeat at New Orleans in January 1815.[4]In the United States, late victories over invading British armies at the battles of Plattsburg, Baltimore (inspiring their national anthem, "The Star-Spangled Banner") and New Orleans produced a sense of euphoria over a "second war of independence" against Britain.[5][6] The Federalist Party had strongly opposed the war effort and prevented New England from providing much in the way of soldiers and troops; it now virtually collapsed. The war ended on a high note for Americans, bringing an "Era of Good Feelings" in which partisan animosity nearly vanished in the face of strengthened U.S. nationalism. Spain played a small role, but was not an official belligerent; some Spanish forces fought alongside the British during the Occupation of Pensacola. The U.S. took permanent ownership of Spain's Mobile District.In Upper and Lower Canada, British and Provincial militia victories over invading American armies became iconic and promoted the development of a distinct Canadian identity, which included strong loyalty to Britain. Today, particularly in Ontario, memory of the war retains its significance, because the defeat of the invasions ensured that the Canadas would remain part of the British Empire, rather than be annexed by the United States. In Canada, numerous ceremonies took place in 2012 to commemorate the war, offer historical lessons and celebrate 200 years of peace across the border.[7] The war is scarcely remembered in Britain, being heavily overshadowed by the much larger Napoleonic Wars occurring in Europe.It was ok.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												Depression Quest is about a chap who can get a kitten...His psychological problems seem to mostly stem from both, a lack of sleep, and feeling everything is too easy; and attempts to deal with it via a misguided imposter syndrome. (freudian slip of the developers, perhaps?)Anyways, in the story you can get a pet kitten. Highlight of the game.On that note, it is not really much a "game" as much as a "take some mostly irrelevent choices that we think reflect depressed people's thoughts" sort of thing. The design is mostly text and images with links. This is closer to a choose your own adventure book, a shallow one at that.The imagination here is very paint by numbers and does not portray depression as anything other than a woe is me dithering, to the point where it's downright insulting to the science behind depression as well as misrepresentative of depression in sufferers as a whole. But umm... kitty... going in between people's legs... (The writers are oh so cleverly subtle)I, by no means like freudian phychology, but this game's writing makes a very compelling argument for it.Conclusivly, this choose your own adventure book (because calling it a game is highly demeaning to the gaming industry, forsooth, it is insulting to adventure books akin) comes off as an abusive exploitation of the depressed, and is downright offensive to the reader's (player would suggest gameplay) intelligence, shows and pervades a contempt for humanity, and portrays the depressed as unlikeable slobs who are to blame for their own issues.Cons-Choose your own adventure book pampered up as a "game".-Insults your intelligence.-Demeaning to men and women alike.-Comes off as abusive.-Taunts with choices you cannot choose.Pro-Kitten.-Wonderous example of irony.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2016
												Terrible. Just a terrible mess of a game. Where do I even begin? From a gameplay standpoint, it's boring. There's nothing visually stimulating (and while I realize that's not the point with choose your own adventure games-but something semi-decent would have been nice, a background to simulate scene changes), and it's all too easy to get the good ending if you have even a sliver of an idea how choose your own adventure games work. The story is bland at best and does nothing to suck the player in and make them care about the character their playing as. Honestly, 3/4 of the way through and I found myself skimming the mammoth-sized paragraphs of crap just to get to my options. Speaking of options, why cross out the ones that would actually help you? I'm speaking from an odd position here, as I have never been diagnosed with depression, but it feels strange that, in an attemtpt to simulate someone being depressed you wouldn't present the helpful option as an option. To the people who played this game who actually have depression, did that feel condescending at all? Plus, the character is completely self-absorbed. There's a point in the game where one of your friends is having some nasty issues in their life and instead of consoling them, you can choose to just ignore him because you feel that you have it worse. Even though this person is a life-long friend you can still opt to turn your back on them. And a trigger warning? Really?Would not recommend this game if you're looking for something good to play. Would recommend this game if you want to have another reason to dislike Zoe Quinn.

												Didn't like it. I may be being a little harsh as I know this is a hard topic, and I know it's trying to portray depression which can be a very individual thing, but disliked the way there were right and wrong choices. Don't want to go talk to a doctor?...well that means you can't go talk to your friends or family instead 'cos we're going to grey it out. I mean there's no way you could help yourself....you need MEDICATION! (Or that's the impression I got from this game anyway.) Yeah I get it, it's meant to be a spiral, but I don't think it's the greatest representation even from an individual standpoint. It's more like someone's idea of what they think depression should be like, but comes off more like someone who's just whiny and can't help themselves without managing to incite any understanding or compassion at all. Can think of many better resources for people wanting to read up more on what depression is. It's also concerning the play though I did at least, makes out like there is no end to it and you'll be miserable your entire life which I think is very misrepresented and a dangerous message, especially for those with current clinical depression. My opinion- skip it.

number of helpful: 16 of 21 people (76%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												I'll preface this review by saying that it's highly unlikely that anybody is checking out Depression Quest in total ignorance of the massive storm of internet drama surrounding it, and I'm no exception. Thus, my view of this piece of "interactive (non)fiction" isn't the product of going in completely blind.I don't have any problems with visual novels, "story games," and "walking simulators" on principle, since they can be great experiences if executed well (insert plug for The Stanley Parable here). However, Depression Quest has some major issues that ultimately cause it to fall flat. The writing is poor on a technical level: it's difficult to get immersed in a text-heavy experience when you have to wrestle with typos, ambiguous pronoun references, and unnecessary alliteration. In addition, instead of being written in a way that evokes certain emotions in the reader, Depression Quest explicitly tells you how you feel every step of the way. This caused me to approach the experience in a disconnected, analytical manner. Finally, perhaps due to my disconnect with the "player character," it was far too simple to determine the proper series of choices to guide the character toward a solution to their depression (protip: don't lay in bed all week).In conclusion, although I personally can't speak to whether or not Depression Quest is an accurate representation of chronic depression, I couldn't force myself to care about the events in the story due to awkward, weak execution. But hey, if you don't believe me, it's free and only takes about half an hour to go through once, so it's not too hard to form your own opinion.

number of helpful: 16 of 21 people (76%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 21, 2016
												Just finished the game. Despite the short amount of time it took to complete, it felt like an eternity.I wanted to give it a fair chance, but there was no game here. The design of the game is just lazy. It's so bland and uninteresting to look at that I really couldn't focus on the story. It's white background, with black text, and a picture on top that pertains to the story.Whenever I could actually look at what was going on, I was extremely disappointed in the lack of originality of the situation I was in. The story is that I have a girlfriend and family who all love me and are concerned about my depression. WHOOP-DEE-DOO!!! I got excited when someone gave me a kitten. I thought that would make it a good game, but the cat POSSIBLY only shows up one other time. There was no connection with any of the characters really since they're all nothing more than cliches.The game has a total of ONE TRACK of a short piano piece on a loop. There will be background noises sometimes depending on the area which can make this short track even more annoying than it actually is. I would go insane listening to it as I merely got the gist of what was going on. I can't imagine what would happen if I took the time to go over all the details.The whole thing about this game is making choices. It doesn't matter how many choices the GAME says there are because in reality there are only two every time. There can be 6 choices the GAME gives you, but there are really only two. It lists some options only to cross them out because you're "TOO DEPRESSED" which is just the most infuriating thing a game about choices can do. I understand my character is depressed, but don't tell me you're restricting my options because of this. Depression doesn't mean incapable of choosing to do enjoyable things. Depression doesn't make some options impossible, but it does make some options more difficult to make because of the emotional weight that just doesn't seem like something to bring around other people. The choices that were presented in this game seemed like they were made to guide the player towards one over the others. I can't choose the crossed out option, but I can choose the option that's the crossed out option with different words. The obvious right option sometimes is actually not always the obvious right option for someone who isn't depressed. The writers basically assume that this is how a normal life should be and anyone who isn't living like this is depressed. I don't have time for parties, internet interaction, and Netflix with a girlfriend when MY JOB is on the line. Depression should have nothing to do with that. Do my choices really matter? Only when it comes down to choosing to see a therapist and taking medicine is when it truly matters. The game is always telling you that you're not doing those things, so obviously the player can deduce that those are the things that must be done in order to win the game. In the real world a therapist and medication does NOT fix all cases of depression. Sometimes these things cause people to become more lost and more depressed.I do not believe that this game depicts depression exactly. There are many ways people can struggle with depression and I've only seen one very generic and uneducated depiction in Depression Quest. The writing is made to make your character obviously sad when sometimes it's not always so obvious even to those affected by this terrible state of mind. I, along with some of the other reviewers here, have struggled with depression and know how it feels. The game gives a trigger warning to anyone who has been depressed that this game might be too real and may emulate our own lives too well. IT DOES NOT!!! If anything it offends and belittles anyone in this very serious condition. I know it wasn't their intention to do so, but that's how I feel about it.Depression Quest is a pretentious way of bring attention to this issue. I'm not even happy that some of the money they receive to support this game goes to the Suicide Hotline. It should ALL go to the Suicide Hotline. It's insulting to think how these people have made money off of this. At the very least, it is at the least totally free if we choose it to be that way.1/10 since it was free. Play it if you want, but your time is better spent elsewhere.

Overall, this game was a disappointment and could possibly be one of the worst games I've played in my entire 18 years.

content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
												The game tries to deliver an okayish story with much pathos, but it really just doesn't accurately portray a clinical depression. The description of the issues the main character is having are as vague as it gets. The game simply boils it down to 3 symptoms. Being anxious, antisocial and having a bad mood. This sadly doesn't do much justice to the complexity of the illness at all. It also doesn't count in any of the problems that come with it, like forgetfulness, irrational input evaluation and the side effects of medication.It seems like the game is about someone who is having a hard time being depressed, rather than suffering from a major depressive disorder.tldr; Not in-depth, but okay story. Still would not recommend to anyone interested in this particular topic. Go, read a book about it. Much more worth your time.

number of helpful: 12 of 14 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												Criteria - Score out of 5Controls - 1Design - 1Playability/Gameplay	 - 1Entertainment level (How quickly did you lose interest?) - 1Technical flaws (bugs, glitches, etc.) - 2Cost - 5Identity - (Idea behind game, Is it unique?) - 5Graphics - 1Artifical Intelligence Competency - 1Storyline - 2Writing Technicalities - 1Voice Acting - 1Music (Does it have soundtracks? Is it enticing to the mood?) - 1Genre Structure - 1Return Factor - 1Average Score - 2As everyone knows, a game is entitled a fair chance. 'Depression Quest' is unique in its development as it brings forward the viewpoints and emotional curtains that define depression. However, it is only applicable to one scenario. It in fact plays through the possible actions of a single person in a very specific environment. The limited actions allow for smooth transitioning, but are generally lacking for what gamers consider to be a developing title.With all else said and done, the game was fairly straight-forward in its guided direction. Did you fight through the depression, or did you succumb to what would be a vision-altering take on an individuals inner turmoil. With multiple paths to choose from which gradually became more and more limited as time progressed, one could feel restricted to their options, an argument which invalidates the free-thought that many gamers wish to experience. With no real graphical rendering save for a very contrasting back-drop to the text, I found my eyes hurting and straining, consistently reminding myself that this game looked more like a website than an actual game. There wasn't any Artificial Intelligence to interact with so the choices seemed rather stale in comparison to other titles. As for the images that did perceive themselves, the images were repetative and didn't give an ebb or flow to the text, so when it came up with changes in time, it felt much like a car slamming into a concrete baricade, and other times it felt like time was at a stand-still.The music was a single repetitive track that played itself over and over again and was almost maddening in and of itself, so the feel was genuinely successful, but the music felt out of place at many points in the story line. As a fast reader, I was able to play through this game in roughly twenty minutes with all possible endings. On that note, the gameplay was very short, and the replay factor was damaged by my own personal abilities. That being said, it felt short and fairly lacking in immersive content. Credit shall be given, however, into the emotions that the game drew out. Having suffered from depression myself, a majority of the situations actually forced myself to review my own experiences in some self-reflection and as I am writing this, I can't help but feel emotionally connected to the game. However, I must remain clinical and give an honest review, and so my personal feelings will be directed in a more professional manner.The last questions that come to mind are fairly straight-forward. Is this a game, and does it befit the genre advertised? The answer to these questions is an undeniable, "No." Depression Quest feels more like a book that you would select your choice, and then turn the page to reveal your decision's consequence, whether it be positive, negative, or neutral. As well, with Depression Quest having the graphical interface of a web-page or flash-based game, it did not feel like it belonged on Steam as a Green-Light. With all this said, it also cannot be considered a Role-Playing Game as it doesn't fit the criteria to be considered a game.On a personal note, I feel that Depression Quest was fairly enlightening and would definately help others feel what depression is. As much as I can relate to it, I feel this would be better as a graphic novel or a short-story rather than a video-game. As a video-game, I stick by my rating of '2 out of 5" and would not recommend this game over-all, but on a personal scale, I feel that this could become something better if it were applied in a different application.If you like this review, please be sure to head over to my Twitter or my Facebook (both will be linked below) and leave a follow/like. If you would like to see more of these reviews, please be sure to send me a private message or leave a mention on the page. If you would like to see a video-style review, please be sure to let us know in the same manner!https://twitter.com/Xerixima "@Xerixima"https://www.facebook.com/Xerixima

number of helpful: 12 of 15 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
												To get it out of the way immediately, I have Bi-polar depression. This 'game' is not an accurate depiction of depression in the least. It is a depiction of someone who is depressed. There is in fact a difference here. Much of the text trivializes the long term issues and makes it appear as if this is something the character is just now dealing with, as in it suddenly appeared. While it is possible for someone with untreated clinical depression to have a girlfriend, a job, a (apparent) group of friends, and overall live a normal life, that is near miraculous as depicted in this game. I attempted to self-manage my depression for years without help, and can tell you that social withdrawal and self-esteem issues are pretty much a given in this kind of situation. I truly think this 'game' utterly fails to depict the mental state of someone with clinical depression. There are a number of issues with the presentation, even aside from the inexplicably understanding people surrounding the character, such as the portrayal of anti-social behavior as a direct result of depression. Some people genuinely don't like other people, and have issues connecting with them, thus seeing avoidance as a way to not have to deal with the added stress trying to deal with that you don't understand creates. I know I'm anti-social. I also know that my being anti-social has nothing to do with my depression, but more to do with just not having the desire for social interaction. That is the root cause of anti-social behavior in most people. Social withdrawal is getting so anti-social that it begins to affect your life negatively. Moving on from that, I cannot call this an accurate portrayal of even caricaturized depression. It portrays someone who is depressed, and fails to do that very well, due to a number of misconceptions on the creator's part on what depression is, and on what the effects are.

number of helpful: 13 of 17 people (76%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 9, 2015
												I downloaded this game to see if it would live up to the hype (for better or worse), and I decided to take an objective look. What I noticed first were some typographical errors, which would be negligible if not for this game being almost exclusively text-oriented. Also, since I find it difficult to concentrate on large areas of text for long periods of time, I think having a save state of some sort would have been a nice addition to the game, especially since the developer was generous enough to include a graphic showing how to "play" this game with a controller.As far as content goes, I think that since the protagonist is supposed to be you (the player), I think that “Alex” (your girlfriend in the game) should have been a neuter character so people of all sexual orientations (not just lesbians) could better relate – there was a huge opportunity to do so, what with “Alex” being a unisex nickname, and since this game is meant to simulate what it feels like to be clinically depressed, I think it would have better immersed the player in that world.Other than these few minor nitpicks, it does have a semi-interesting story, and as someone who has suffered from clinical depression myself, it does have relatable elements. I didn't finish because it was too long for me to complete in one sitting and I couldn't find a way to bookmark my place to pick it up later (as I stated before, save states would have been useful). I think this game could use more development, but it does have potential, and I can honestly say I got what I paid for from Depression Quest.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												Don't play this "game", nor should you view it as an accurate depiction of depression. You don't make the choices in the game, instead, the developer has already crossed off certain options in order to force you down the same bad ending. Depression Quest only tries to show the worst case scenario for depression, not at all acknowledging that it is treatable by the choices you make, instead, it portrays the only way to treat depression is with pills and a therapist. Notice how I said "tries", because even then everyone in the "game" acts like a complete idiot around the player.Accuracy aside, this is just a poor excuse for a "game". From the static overlay constantly on the screen in a pathetic attempt to make the mediocre story seem "deep" to the lack of multiple endings with your choices basically doing nothing, there's a reason this game's top reviews are mostly negative.

Perhpas another medium other than point and click might have worked. Random events, for example. A different format or engine. As it is, I found this game lacking in every way. I found no emotional connection to a game that wants me to feel connected to it. To relate to it. I find it does a horrid job even depicting depression itself. It's simply a series of cliking on choice, and get better or worse. That's not even one tenth accurate. It's not showing the troubles one faces in feeling down, then depressed, then the utter despair. I tried going into this with an open mind, and realized this game was simply awful.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
												I think the game does what it set out to do by helping people understand depression more. These symptoms are relateable by almost everyone with the fog or time moving slow at work but I think the game expresses well that depression isn't just these feelings coming and going at work, these feelings last for months and months. It's the consistancy that is emphasized. The narration is a bit hard to read because it is written as a 20 year old girl and these situations are a bit over exaggerated in my opinion. The anxiety of parties and such are very real but the reasons we create this anxiety are not valid most of the time. Example, being in a crowded party by yourself, you feel as if every person is staring at you and judging but in reality most people don't even care what you're doing. The exaggeration is useful to help people with no base for depression to relate but it might give the wrong impression. I get that the writers used a 20 year old character to help relate to the people who probably need something like this most and that is young adults dealing with these issues so I think the format works but I personally just don't like reading about a 20 year old girls problems. I think this game really shows depression well but also shows the glaring problem of peer pressure and social "norms" that people experience. Why is it so crazy to just hangout at a party by yourself and not really talk  much? there should be nothing wrong with that and yet people always ask "whats wrong with you?" "are you okay?" I lost count of how many times in the story "are you okay" or "whats wrong" came up and I think that is the worst part of depression usually. No one understands and no one knows how to approach it and so they affectively make it worse. Thats what I took from this game. I wouldn't recommend it as a game but I would recommend it as a tool to help understand depression a little better.

												As a person who has suffered with depression for the majority of his life, and a person who loves visual novels like Ace Attorney and Professor Layton. I can't bring it to myself to give this game a good review. I tried to give this game at least one full playthrough but after about 10 minutes I really couldn't do it. I understand what this game is trying to do but honestly its execution is downright♥♥♥♥♥♥poor. I know everyones battle with depression is different and many people deal with it in different ways but this game only gives, in my opinion, a sterotypical depression outlook. Some of the good options to pick through to advance in the story are crossed off. As it seems like a person battling with depression is unable to do those things. It would have done the game more justice to let the player pick some of the more social and common things to see how a person with depression would react to them! I know when I was battling with depression I still tried my hardest to do what was right and I went after help to get things under control. So overall do yourself a favor and don't play this game. The game isn't even worth it to be free. Go download the demo for Five Night's at Freddys or something. Or if you want a good visual novel expierence go pick up Professor Layton vs. Phoenix Wright:Ace Attorney next week.I'll probably sit down and play the game from start to finish and give my full thoughts on this, however the game just isn't worth your time.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2014
												I don't know who's going to actually take the time to read this but I need to get this out. Jesus, does this whole drama situation make me angry. Angry that I can't do anything about it. I'll start off by saying something that might seem irrelevant. I consider my political stance quite conservative. But you see one thing that I see often labeled as "the liberal idea" is that the government has total control over you, and you are simply puppets. Now to a certain extent I see this fit, because after all I'd like to have some control and not erupt into anarchy. But that doesn't mean I'm willing to live in an orwellian society where citizens have no voice. Why am I talking about this? Well see, what sparked my interest in this game was the actions of the Reddit r/gaming subreddit. Comments being deleted. Now that isn't maintaining order. That is flat out repressing our voice. How can you even call it a public forum anymore? It's not like those comments were yelling obsecnities, posting links to viruses, or bullying each other. They were talking about the situation, maybe asking question about the situation, and simply getting deleted. Now I like going to the gaming reddit sometimes to read up on news and stuff. Gaming is something I consider a big part of my life. When I saw something like that happening, it was kind of an eye-opener. A feeling of, wow this is right at my doorstep, kind of feeling. Suddenly, my closeted political activist side of me thought, alright that's it. So many things in this world that I am upset with. Israel and Hammas, ISIS, The looting in Ferguson. And then there's this. Yes, compared to what I talked about this whole ordeal is of lesser importance, yet I think I'm going to voice my opinion about it. This kind of thing probably happens everyday in our government. Corruption. Manipulation of press. Don't tell me that someone sleeping with someone else in exchange for priority over others is not corruption. If it isn't then why aren't we allowed to discuss it? Why do I go through those threads and see *deleted* *deleted* *deleted* everywhere? One more thing. Another reason this game doesn't recieve my support is because of the way this creator has acted publicly on twitter. Alogn with others. I'm not part of this wizchan forum, but jesus, the things peopele were saying about them. THAT is the real abuse. THAT is the bullying. Many feminists are headstrong about the use of sensitive terms and advocate the consideration of other peoples thoughts and feeligns. I respect and admire that. But what I saw was the term 'virgin' being thrown around with a incredibly huge negative connotation. Where's the respect for people following religions that advocate abstinence till marriage? So no, I can't have respect for someone making a game, who is immature, insensitive, could possibly be lying!?!?! (ever thought of that? who really did call her?), and just flat out immoral. I cant support conspiracy and manipulation. But for those of you who want an actual game review. Well I watched a playthrough. Despite others, I thought the idea of the game was amazing. Truly needed in our society right now. But the playthrough that I watched. My god this game misses the mark completely. Just really shoddy work all around. Makes this important topic look very dissmissive. A careless approach to what I thought was a good idea. Surely there wasn't enough work done on this game. I guess it makes sense it was free. But unless this developer puts out anoher free game that truly reflects impressive, hardworked, artistic work. Then sure, I'll give a thumbs up for that one. But for this one, well sorry but it really isn't good. As I said, I'm just here to rant, and provide my opinion on the game. If you want to reply, you wont get a reply from me. Dont think of that as "Oh man, I really got hime! He's at a loss for words and cant provide a rebuttal!" No. I'm not going to spend my time arguing about this. Just here to do my job downvoting what I think is a disgrace to the gaming comunity and harfmul   to the industry.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2014
												The idea behind Depression Quest is something I have no problems with and is fairly solid. Making people aware of how difficult living with depression can be is really important and more people should be aware of it. However it's also important to take this 'game' at face value. It's at the most a choose your own adventure story with minimal end results. The creator made the right choice in releasing it for free, as it has nowhere near enough content to justify a price tag.Would I recommend people play this game, possibly yes, however for the sakes of the steam review system no. As good as it is,  it's very minimalistic and lacks decent content, it's very linear and when playing it makes you feel like actually the choices you make have little effect on the games outcome. It's also really only good for a single playthrough as results become predictable. Im sure eventually there will be a more fleshed out itteration of this game. However now isn't that time.

The story takes place over months but the writing makes it feel like it took place over a week. That is what overall made the game feel fake to me I didn’t feel like the protagonist I felt like a person clicking buttons and making choices that didn’t really affect me. I wouldn’t recommend this game to anyone and I wouldn’t play it again maybe if the devs did a major rework on it like change the writing and made it seem real but that’s a soft maybe.

number of helpful: 13 of 18 people (72%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 31, 2014
												There are two things I want to discuss here.  The game itself, and the controversy.  The Game:  This is not a traditional game, rather a kind of interactive novel.  It is more along the lines of a choose-your-own-adventure type game.  It follows the life of someone struggling with depression, in the second person, in an attempt to illustrate the experience.  While it's a noble goal, the game itself tries to beat the atmosphere and helplessness into you in such an awkward way that playing this is unpleasant.  Not in an "uncomfortable because it's thought-provoking" way, but an "I can't do anything" way.  Were it not for the disclaimer page before the game starts, I would be concerned about it trivializing the condition by stereotyping it.  I have not put much time into this game, and I don't think I will.  It's just too uncomfortable.  Fortunately if you do try it, it is not very long and can be finished in a matter of minutes.The Controversy:Face it.  The negative reviews and forum posts on this game are not because of the game itself, but are about the creator, Zoe Quinn.  Quinn's ex-boyfriend made a number of allegations about her, and her personal life basically went viral.  It's become a sport in the last few weeks to attack Quinn directly and indirectly for the unforgiveable sin of "doing it".  It's like the Internet is made of middle school kids giggling while getting their shamesticks out.  Look.  We get it.  She isn't a nun, nor did she claim to be.  That has nothing to do with the game.  Even when you try to disguise misogyny as being about journalistic integrity, or honesty, or whatever excuse gets used.  When the method is calling someone a "hooker" or making "5 guys" jokes, that's not about journalism.  That's about her private life.  Conclusion:This game is not fun or enjoyable.  It's kind of an interesting experiment, but most people will probably want to avoid it.  Unfortunately a straight review is hard to find in the nest of cruel and inappropriate snark.  This game is marred by the public reaction to it.

Posted: August 26, 2014
												If this define the future of gaming then I will be depressed... not only depressed... SUICIDAL! Don't get me wrong, I like reading! I've been playing the latest interactive novel released on Android such as House of Hell, Blood of the Living Dead and Lone Wolf. And I've been collecting Fighting Fantasy gamebooks for age!But this...This...Has nothing to do with what I grew up with.The title "Depression Quest" is very misleading. I thought the game would be about reaching the deepest level of depression. What a fool I was!So basically, you play some boy who as a hard time being positive and living an enjoyable day. The story is set in a very generic context: you live with your mother, you have an old brother and a girlfriend, you have a job and everything seems to fall apart. The writing style doesn't manage to deliver the complexities of depression. It is like listening to a casual conversation so there is nothing creative about the writing. The writer has absolutely no imagination.The music is alright but it is the same throughout the whole playthrough.The game uses some images to help the "reader" to get an idea of what is going on but there are too few of them.The mission goal is to meet a therapist and take medication so you can feel better. What kind of institutional propaganda is that?!Even if the game is free, it's still a ripoff. The game doesn't deserve that much attention.♥♥♥♥ing a video game journalist will not save the game from bad reviews.A bad game is a bad game.I hate to say it but...I can list a number of bad games that are better than Depression Quest: The Graveyard (dare I say it!), Dementium 2 HD, Robocop (Xbox, 2003), Judge Dredd Dredd vs Death, Daikatana (thumb up John Romero!), Country Justice Revenge of the Redneck, Land of the Dead Road to Fiddler Green, Big Rigs.Reading my review will spare you from the depression that awaits you in Depression Quest.Rating:1.0

content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												If you’re looking for nice graphics, great sound, challenging gameplay or fascinating story, Depression Quest fails on all of these.  It’s pretty debatable as to whether Depression Quest is even qualified as a game. You click on some hyperlinks that take you to another text-card against a grey background and… that’s it. And by no means should this game be viewed as an accurate depiction of depression. It’s utterly disrespectful to those clinically depressed, portraying them as lazy, hopeless people with no desire to change their lives. If you want to understand depression, ask people with depression or do scholarly research, and don’t play this game. It was pretty hard to play this, but I had to try it out because it was free and I wanted to find out what the controversy was about.+It’s free+Lightweight on your HD space+/- Music was okay, but repetitive-Low entertainment value -A bad way to spread awareness about depression -It will probably make you feel worse if you are seeking comfort.

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 16, 2016
												Okay so real talk from someone who has had clinical Depression since they were 9.Depression sucks. Big time. A lot of the thought processes, situations, and dialogue that are used in this 'game' are somewhat relatable to some of my own experiences. The not feeling good enough for your partner, being emotionally exhausted, having to pep yourself up for menial activities...It's a lot more difficult than people realize, and I will give some credit to Depression Quest for trying to shed some light on that, for the small hints of it that are there. However, while I understand what this was trying to accomplish, there are better ways of doing so. This is not a game. It is an interactive journal essentially. It is trying to be a new-age look into a 'deep' soul that ends up sounding very pretentious. I just know most people do not want to sit and read walls of text(s) of sad things, which is probably one of the major reasons Depression Quest has been so negatively received. There's also the fact that the story overall really isn't even that engaging. I started skipping over entries after the seventh one and just clicked the most positive options to get to the end. I also can't stand the title. As another reviewer stated, Depression is not a 'quest' where you get a nice little reward for making it to the end. It's draining and exhausting. It's learning how to cope and when you think everything is fine and figured out, the rules change again for no reason. Basically, it's not nearly as straight-forward as this 'groundbreaking game' claims to be.I read a bit on Zoe Quinn and her desire to create a more straight-forward game because all the ones dealing with Depression are more metaphorical and about symbolism (which I prefer personally). Well, congratulations Zoe. You created your snorefe-masterpiece!

number of helpful: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 6, 2014
												When I finished Depression Quest, I was taken on a journey of discovery as I tailed the story of a man who has suffered Depression. It's a wonderful game with lots of potential and is crisply written and nocely noted.Now what I say beyond this point is basically a spoiler and if you intend on playing the game, I don't recommend reading. But if your interested on why I don't recommend it, keep reading.As a man who's had major depression, and has been diagnosed with Schizoaffective Disorder (A disease that makes it harder to comprehend reality and gives you immense mood swings.), I have to say that the justification given in the ending I GOT, is NOT the way to approach depression. It doesn't matter if the story has multiple branches and has various amounts of endings, it should all end in the RIGHT way to treat depression and not with the going excuse of just saying "deal with it". For one thing, depression is not something you can just accept and just let it pass. Like any form of mental disorder, it can be treated with the right amount of medicine and seeing a therapist. It makes me angry seeing how a game about something as serious as depression can just say "you have to live with it". Depression is something YOU CANNOT just say go away to.Now I know the game is probably vouching for many playthroughs, and it wants you to find the "optimal path" to fighting depression, but the problem is that there IS NO SPECIFIC PATH to fighting depression. And giving the answer to people who may have depressio to just deal with it is the WRONG APPROACH. With Depression, you have to be more careful in what you tell the public due to the numerous misconceptions about the disease. Depression is CURABLE, it's something that could be fought with help. Giving an ending that says deal with it is not only infuriating to me as someone who has known and has had depression himself, but also infuriating because it sending the wrong message to people.Now what can I recommend to make the game more exact in how to treat depression and how to articulate depression better? I would make the story have branching paths, but have it only have one ending which is getting yourself cured. Giving the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that you just deal with it is NOT the way to do it. With a premise as important as this, you have to tell the right message and not muddle the message by adding mechanics that hinder it.So that's what I think. Depression Quest is not something I would recommend listening to but would recommend actually playing to see what experiance you might actually get. From the looks of it, there's a way to get to the right ending, but giving an endng that just says to deal with it is not the way to go.To all of those who have depression, please seek help immideately. Dont be afraid to go to a psychiatrist and talking about it. The psychiatrist is payed to listen to you. Don't be afraid if he will started judging you or something, because he wont. He will help you, and will get you better.Spread the word that Depression is something you can FIGHT, not just AVOID.

												I won't lie. I am a casual gamer. I have a small collection of games that I very much enjoy. I'm not competitive. I like story. And I like unique aesthetic. After all the hubbub that I probably don't need to mention, I decided to give this a shot. It couldn't be nearly as bad as everyone said, right? Well... Depression Quest has a unique aesthetic in that it doesn't have one at all. It is text. I can't even call this a Visual Novel since there are NO VISUALS. I have depression, yes. It's nice to see my illness exposed, but this is inappropriate. THIS IS NOT SUITABLE FOR STEAM. This is not a game. THIS IS NOT A GAME. Even though this is free, get a different game with mental illness as a theme, read a book, or perhaps talk to someone who actually has depression. This garbage makes Gone Home look like Demon's Souls.
