content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
												Okay, let me get this off my chest. This is not a game, this is an interactive Short Story.. My rationale for it being a non-game is that it has no gameplay just hyperlinks that can be done in so many different ways including powerpoint. I can't see how this got through greenlight or how it won awards especially over Papers Please.. Personally, I come from a family that does have Depression problems in it and this game while it gets some things right most other problems it doesn't. So don't buy the hype you see from these "professional" reviewers.. It is just insane how they think this is a perfect way to understand depression. Its not. I still have my Psychology text books and those are more clearly defined and from personal experience as well. My next problem is on the writing level.. there is no characterization, not even a very good idea of the feelings one experiences when being depressed. But it does get some right. It is very hard to even care about the protagonist or even the choices you make since the weight to them is painfully clear. Some more emotional weight and more atmosphere would have been better suited for the emotional impact. Heck it doesn't even have anything in the way of a hero's journey or even much depth of character. Overall, even though this is a free game its best to avoid this story and actually read up on depression and actually support those suffering from it. Encourage them to get the help they need even if they are afraid. Pro tip for the creator, more depth, more emotion, more characterization, and more atmosphere. Plus researching and interviewing would help too.. That is my friendly advice from me to you writer to writer.

number of helpful: 12 of 17 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												Grade Scale Notes: This review operates on a One-to-Ten rating scale for various segments.1/10: Horrible. 3/10: Nothing interesting. Might have potential, but is weighed down (By glitches, poor/uninteresting design and controls, ETC)5/10: Average7/10: Well made9/10: StellarI do not give 10/10's, as there is no such thing as perfection. I do not give 0/10's, unless the game truly lacks something. And I always round down.Review Intro:When I was in elementary school, I would read a few choose-your-own adventure books in the library. For vague reasons, a friend told me to try this game out and see what I thought of it.Gameplay: 2.5/10Depression Quest is not a game, it is instead a virtual Choose-your-own-adventure story that does not let you choose your adventure, as it will frequently provide you with many options that cannot actually be selected. This single fact made me lose interest rapidly. If the game had allowed you to select those options, but the results would vary based on the three stats displayed at the bottom of every page (Depression level, therapist level, and medication level), the game might take a turn for the better. The three options do change based on some available actions, but the fact that it means nothing is disappointing. The option for plugging a controller in is strange and entirely unneeded.Gameplay Suggestions: Allow the ability to select options who's results vary based on the stats located at the bottom of the page: Depression Level, Therapist Level ( Which would include seeing a therapist, and one's relation with said therapist) and Medication level (level of medication in one's system at that time.). Do not deprive the player of their aility to choose: There is always a choice.Graphics (For the sake of this particular review, this will include music): 1/10I've never been a fan of grayscaled images. That comment aside, this program features limited visuals that are meant to go alongside the story text, but due to the nature of the layout these pictures fall to the wayside on longer text instances. The music is meant to set a sad mood, and ignoring the fact that slow piano music has become a staple for sad game moments, the lack of variety in music made things feel monotonous...The piano number is also boring, to be blunt.Graphics Suggestions: Different music numbers to coincide with different events, that, like the singular piano number, are meant to envoke feelings. There are many kinds of sadness, there should be just as many sad music numbers. If the game is changed to feature more scenes and instances, have music that accompanies it: Music that shows joy, anger, defeat.Story/Writing: I divide the Story/Writing into three categories. Theme, Characters, and Quality. The total score for writing is 5/30, or 1.6/10, rounded down.Theme: 1/10Depression is a serious topic. However, depression on it's own is not enough, thematically, for a game. We need to better see a gradual decent into the depths of sorrow, but being able to rise above and triumph over depression is just as satisfying as defeating the final boss in any other game. This game lacks any of those feelings, and in turn I felt nothing from the game.Theme Suggestions: Make me feel something.Characters: 3/10The protagonist is unnamed, and meant to be an avatar for the player to see the world with. I did not once feel connected to the world or the plights of the protagonist. The reason for this is tied heavily to my comments in regards to 'gameplay'. We have Alex, your 'significant other', but we know very little about them, and less of the other minor characters such as Attic. Alongside the lack of noteworthy characters, the story does not make you feel for the characters already present.Character Suggestions: Add additional characters. Usually an iffy topic for any story, but when your story lacks characters, you need a few more to bring life to the world. Provide us with more details of these characters; make us feel for these characters. Yes the story is about the protagonist, but those characters are a part of the protagonist's world. At present, they exist moreso to advance the story.Writing Quality: 1/10Depression Quest lacks it's quest.I found the writing to be similar to a High Schooler's Biology essay: It might look proper, but there's no soul to it. It's also short.On the first playthrough the protagonist broke up with Alex, and then a few turns later the story ended. On the second playthrough the protagonist went to a therapist and got some medications, and actually seemed to start to get better (which almost made me become interested in the story) and then a few turns later the story ended. If I decided to suffer a third time through, it would go on for a bit, and then the story would end.THE STORY WOULD END. Yes, all stories have to end, but when the ending is "Thank you for playing, we know this might not be the easiest game...". First off, game is the wrong word (see Gameplay review), secondly you do not deprive the reader of the story's end unless you've crafted the story in such a way that it can be interpreted freely by the reader...which is not how a 'Choose-Your-Own-Adventure' works. You do not interprete the end because you found the end, and the end is not a message from the author, it is THE END of the story.Story Suggestions: Start over. That's all I can say.Overal Game Score: By math, the score is 5.1/30, or 1.7/10. But my soul believes the score to be 1/10, at the most generous.Depression Quest attempts to show us the world of someone who is depressed, but it's limited gameplay and poor story are the only depressing things to be found. I would suggest that Depression Quest either evolve into an actual, fully fleshed out Text-Based Adventure game that challenges the player to free the protagonist from the bonds of depression, or be transformed into a Short Story piece. It cannot operate as both.Also, and this question is solely to my fellow reviewers: What in blazes does Five Guys have to do with any of this?

We've evolved far enough as a species to begin to question basic things that we have taken for granted, but we've done so in completely the wrong ways.A: "What is talent?" B: "A BARRIER THAT STOPS THE UNTALENTED FROM PARTAKING IN THE ARTS."A: "What is merit?" B: "A RACIST, SEXIST, HOMOPHOBIC CONCEPT THAT BARS SPECIAL PEOPLE FROM ENTERING SKILLFUL DISCIPLINES."A: "Why was Zoe Quinn allowed to publish this steaming turd?" B: "Even as the loud, obnoxious SJW example in this made-up conversation, I can't answer that. This game's free and I still feel ripped off."This "game" (and I'm being generous by calling it such, even with the utmost sarcasm) is emblematic of pure, distilled half-assery. Badly written, horrifically narrow in scope, poorly scored (bland piano, noice), and reeking of a fedora-clad Starbucks customer. A review on Steam of a game with a two-year-old controversy seems like a waste of time, but after wasting ten precious minutes I'll never get back, I felt obligated to post. Have a nice day, unless you're Zoe.

												This game was extremely simple. About an hour into the game, I figured out that the choices presented all had a very easy to predict path. I could be a loner at the party, or I could be cheery. Guess what made me sink deeper into a depression? That's right. The game is too easy to predict, so I didn't really enjoy, especially since I do have these thoughts. It tells me that I only have one way to go if I choose the choices I would, because it would be hopeless. I can respect what the creator was trying to do, but this is something extremely tricky to create a game out.I'm even directing a play about depression and suicide, and it has been difficult. She goes with the stereotypes and connotations associated with depression, when there is a lot more that goes into it other than feeling hopeless. I would recommend that next time anyone makes a game that deals with that topic, they research the hell out of everything,Overall:4/10It's a fun-ish game to see what your playthrough will result in, but it isn't something to take seriously.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												I've decieded to give this a bash because I saw Isaac Schankler was involved with the project and I really liked his work with Analogue and Hate Plus. People have been bringing up the controversy with Quinn, but here's the thing: it has nothing to do with Depression Quest so I could care less about someone's personal life simply because it was never my business to begin with so lets move away from that and actually talk about the "game". Depression Quest is simply a choose you own adventure kind of ordeal touching upon the subject of depression and I have mixed feelings on how the subject matter was handled. I do like on how it simulated the feeling of depression since there is a sense of hopelessness in the world, but what also irritates me is that they crossed out choices that makes a real positive impact in your life and forces you to remain in a state of depression for the entire run, which for those people who are currently or formerly depressed might not find this helpful in any shape or form (at least they gave us a warning about suicidal thoughts). You are basically just some guy in his twenties who currently is in a state of depression possibly because of an inferiority complex constantly comparing himself with his friends and family including his significant other.Unfortunately the soundtrack basically consists of one track on a loop the entire time and for me, it did not deliver much of an impact so that was pretty disapointing because if Depression Quest wasn't good, (which it wasn't) I was hoping the music would at least make up for it.Despite having multiple "endings", I had no desire to go back and find out what they are because I feel it would be similar to one another, which is falling into despair with no chance of self redemption with the best "ending" is continuing to assess your condition which in no way it feels reassuring which is the purpose of this "game" and it acheives it.I do not know much about depression other than it negatively affects the relationships of those around the victim, so to end this, I can only say to those who is or knows someone that is depressed, try to be patient and get assistance as soon as possible.

The food was outstanding: the juicy patties, crispy bacon, melted cheese, and toppings blended so perfectly together that after eating I felt satisfied; in fact, I was in such a good mood after that meal that if you'd asked me to help out in some way, for example like praising your game, giving it a positive review, or bashing others that disagree, I'd gladly do so.HOWEVER, this "game" brought that mood down after 5 minutes. If you're the sadistic type, then this might be for you; for the vast majority of people out there, this "game" is terrible. While the disclaimer at the beginning warns that this is not meant to be fun, it undermines everything a game should be: FUN. I play games for entertainment and immersion into different worlds, not to read endlessly about depression. If you actually do want to learn about depression, talk to your doctor, psychologist, self-help book, etc., anything but this game. Also, the graphics sucked.But hey, it did get at least 60 FPS and it has controller support.

number of helpful: 10 of 14 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
												While playing this game, I found my mind constantly wandering. That's not good.To put this in perspective, a few weeks ago, I had to play a few text based adventures made by my classmates. The developers were (are) not yet professionals, and some of their games were better than others. However, they were all written in a very similar format to Depression Quest. Very rarely did I slip into a daydream, or wish I was doing something else, when playing my peers' games, something I cannot say for Depression Quest.Self insertion characters, as well as depressed characters, are very hard to write. I should know. I have written characters who have mental illnesses, or have just been down on their luck. I had to rewrite them all several times to keep them likable, realistic, and sympathetic. But the narrative keeps beating me over the head with how depressed the protagonist is. It's pretty much their only character trait. The secret to writing self instertion characters is to give them a backstory and personality of their own. I'm pretty sure Depression Quest Protagonist has a backstory, but a very shallow personality.I'm not overly fond of the piano either. I don't claim to know much about proper music, so to get an idea of how to compose a better piano score, just play Long Live the Queen. It manages to express a wide range of emotions with just the one instrument. (And that game was also developed by a predominantly female crew. :) )However, I'm going to give credit where it's due. Even though I'm not diagnosed with depression, I could feel the weight of needing to protect people close to me, including my own mother, even though Depression Quest Protagonist was the one who needed help.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2014
												This game is absolutely terrible. I hated playing this, but I played all the way through. First off: Title is completely misleading, I was completely expecting to be playing an RPG but it turned out this wasnt an RPG... The entire game I thought was like a cinematic where you create the storyline for your character before you start the game. Extremely misleading...Second off: There were a lot of parts where I just wanted to smash my girlfriend, but the game DID NOT ALLOW THIS, EXTREMELY UNREALISTIC. If I was super depressed or anything, I would just smash my girl and be done with my issues.Third off: I dont understand quite why some of the options were completely unavailable to choose from: perhaps I was playing the game wrong? Missed the pre-requisites? Maybe I wasn't a high enough level and after the long cinematic I would be able to choose a class and go back to have those options available? No, not in this game, this game was not a game where you could do whatever you want..My suggestion to the developer : Change the name of your game, I was not on a quest, I did not save the princess, I did not get any poonanny, I didn't make it to the highest level, and I didnt slay the ♥♥♥♥ing dragon - this is not a quest!!!!!!!If you dont wanna change the name of the game, you might wanna make it so that after the whole depression storyline, you can actually move on to the quest and choose a class and♥♥♥♥♥♥ but dont do like Rogue Warrior and Sorcerer either, that's too cliche, you should make it so you dont really have a class, but you choose what skills you wanna be good at, know what I mean?Pros: awesome soundtrack - I personally downloaded the soundtrack and use it when I workoutbeautiful quality images - I felt like I was actually watching netflix at one point when the netflix screen popped upCons: no real questsno classesno boss fightsno xp systema lot of options unavailablecould not smash girlcould not get into hard drugsI would NOT recommend this game to a friend. I would recommend it to someone who I really dislike though.2/10

number of helpful: 12 of 18 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2015
												I've never really written a review so please bear with me.Honestly without even considering gamer-gate I'd give this game alone a 4/10The whole story lacked any sort of real emotional words (whether that's intentional or not) and never really "drew" me into the experience. On top of that for the first half of the game what seemed like wrong choices (since they were doing nothing) turned out to be right choices closer to the end of the game. The fact that seeing what I thought would be common sense and the right answer rejected and then picked up later sort of brought the feeling like I could have done better in the game even though, in all likelyhood, I had a near perfect game. I also had an issue with the music. I get that it was supposed to help greaten the story, or maybe even cover over it, but  it wound up distracting me from the story. I of course didn't turn the music off out of fear that the generally labeled "sound" would somehow be important later in game (it wasn't). By the end of the game I was not only not affected by the music but I was out right sick of it.Another issue is that some of the points are automatically crossed off. This lead to a more straight-forward feel to the game instead of the (hopefully) intended mood of it being a choose your own adventure. By the end of it I felt like there could have been a completely better and different game if you didn't focus on keeping the character so depressed for half the game. So in summary I feel as though Depression Quest has a lacking storyline, monotone music that will bore you to tears, a confusing choice of story options, and a lack of creative writing that will never really help draw in the player. I rated it a 4/10 because it was honestly not a bad game considering it was free, just medicore at best.  If it was paid I probably would have never bought it because even the cover art draws me off from this title.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
												It's not a game, it's a book. And a bad one at that. The dialogue is rubbish. The choices are very limited and unrealistic, basically boiling down to "sink into depression because the game says so". Music is a bad looped piano. This "game" doesn't give you any background information or characters' backstories. There's no way you can feel for the characters. Failing at it's main reason for existance, it doesn't even capture depression realistically nor does it get the point out there. The main character laments over his pointless life while having friends, a decent job, family and their loved one, making them sound like a jaded emo kid from a rich family. Why are they not at a therapy? Why do they start at despair?The idea of Depression Quest isn't half bad, but the execution is just painful. Does it work good as a book? No, not at all. 95% of the contenent on fanfiction.net marked as "angst" shows depression better than this.  Does it work well as a interactive story? Yeah no. Any choose your own adventure or even visual novel (if you're into them) does its job better than this. As a simulation? Oh please. Read any book on the subject, even if it's under average for better experience than this. It has nothing going for it. Rubbish about an important issue is still rubbish. As a person that experienced depression, I'll tell you this: It's rubbish. Don't waste your time. It's junk like this that drives others to despair thanks to depression being displayed so shallowly in media, with others claiming to suffer from it because it's "cool, since my favourite video character suffers from it!". I wonder if Steam realizes that most of the recommendations for crap like this go among the line of "10/10 cured my cancer".

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												I literally have no interest in the controversy surrounding this game and I'm no professional, and I can say that this was an interesting experience. Not good, not bad, interesting. Objectively, it should not be a game. It's a work of (non)fiction that has the sole gameplay mechanic of clicking on stuff. It was mildly interesting to see that the logical things for people with depression to do in order to break out of it were unable to be chosen, but other than that I really don't feel that this was, in any way, shape or form a game. The music was a tad repetitive, but it suited the tone of the game. Actually, its dull, repetitive grind might actually be symbolic, or it could just be lazy design, or an unwillingness/inability to find better music. From the title of (non)fiction, I do believe that it's not unlikely that Zoe Quinn based the nameless character on herself. I ignore the developer and focus on the game, and the problem is that this is not a game. I refuse to make fun of the risk of depression, so I'll just say that this is an interesting view on depression and leave it at that.This is a piece of mildly interactive writing disguised as a game. Only one thing in there actually piqued my interest, and that was the red text that was slashed through. Other than that, I recommend it only for you to play it once and then subsequently ignore. I have no interest in replaying what is, to all intents and purposes a website. Overall, the game itself is, ironically, depressing to play. The dull grey background and the repetitive music give the player a feeling of intense ennui. It's dull and feels like it goes on forever, and thus you should get children to play it before bedtime, as they'll fall right asleep after five minutes.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
												This is a badly written game, with a message that you get from just reading the title. It seems like the people behind it follows the "tublr-definition" of depression, and not the real definition of depression. Every "choice" you make is not really a choice, and leads to the same ends (at least as far as I can see), which is probably to strenghten the message that depression is a vicious circle. But this game is just throwing the message down your throat, like if you didn't already know it. On top of that you have a boring, and not even that depressing piano-piece playing in the background all the time, where it would just have been easier to put "mad world" on the soundtrack and be done with it, and even come out with a more effective result, if only slightly.And while I am totally for artsy games, and are myself an avid fan of companies like Tale of Tales and the Fullbright Company, this game just doesn't hold any merit, even as being an "art-game".Plus, the amount of spelling mistakes in this game is unbearable, and I began skipping a lot of text after a few screens, because of the major unimportance it had, and on top of that the horrible writing and lack of proof-reading. I'm surprised that a game with this great a following could not even get some volunteer fans to proof-read and "play-test".Do NOT waste your time on this mess. Go read a book instead, it's a way more fulfilling experience. And if you want something containing a lot of depression or depressing subjects, then let me suggest Edgar Allan Poe's "The Raven" or anything by Victor Hugo.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												Well...It's not exactly easy to give this game a cheerful thumbs up amidst a sea of negative feedback from others, but this is what I believe and this is what I have to say.Depression Quest is misunderstood. I know that sounds like an excuse, but believe me. I've clocked in one playthrough of it and in that one playthrough, more thoughts crossed my mind than any 12 hours spent on a typical shooter of your choice. In fact, I think it's wrong for me to even bring up the term 'shooter' as though in comparison because shooters are games. That's something many people who criticise this tend to complain most about. That this is a poor excuse for a game. In doing so they miss the biggest and most powerful message that this game does it's ultimate best to send.Depression is not a game.I've read plenty of complaints about this game from people who do have depression that found this game insulting or offensive. The last thing I, or Depression Quest, want to do is devalue those people and their experiences. But I can assure you that the opening message of the game openly admits that it's only trying to give a semblance of depression and what it's like, though they can not, in fact they can never, fully encapsulate everything about it. No two experiences of depression are the same, something the multiple choice nature of this story can only reach for. The game is honest about itself, which I think everyone at least can appreciate. It's not the be-all, end-all definition of depression. It's a taste, based on a limited experience set to try and share the pain that is experienced in the real world.If you have depression, the game warns you beforehand what you're getting into. You may not get along with this game, which is completely okay.As for me? I do not have depression. Nor do I understand depression. But Depression Quest did for me what it set out to do. It showed me - if only just a little - a little of what it's like. In an ironic use of the word, it's through 'play' that I'm given a bit on insight into how hopeless life can be. This is a game that teaches and shares. It might not be music that resonates with you, but the important thing is that it's heard. And I heard it.Another complaint I've read is that your 'character' has no personality and is an empty protagonist. Again, something has been missed. This is a game told through written 2nd-person narrative. You are the main character. This is your life that you're playing through and these are your decisions. How restricted you are is how restricted you could be if you had depression. How you're told that you're feeling is how you could be feeling if you had depression. The game is saying through it's presentation of the story and 'main character' that this could be you. This could be your life. And for some people, this is their life.You're given choices on how to make decisions on what to do, some of which are completely inaccessable. Even though you know that it's there, you can't do it. You're told often how you feel and what your mental state is, so sometimes you'll try to do what seems like the right thing only to realise that your character is only feeling worse. You'll wonder what the right choice was, or even if there ever was a right choice to begin with. Again, not everyone faces the same kind of depression, but to see into the eyes of even one kind is... eye-opening. And regardless of how it ends, you can't simply resolve everything because, once again, this isn't a game. This is life. This is depression. This is no idealised, escapist happy ending for feeling better. This is depression awareness.In summation, no. This game is not fun. You are not meant to have fun playing it. You are meant to think, to consider, to choose and possibly to feel. If that's not what you want, if this isn't what you're looking for, walk away. But if you're up for it, dive. Dive right in. This is less of a game and more of an experience. An experience with depression for those unenlightened to it. Even if you disagree with it and it's portrayal, that's all the more reason to try it.I promise. Devote yourself to one playthrough and you'll come away with something meaningful. Positive or negative, this is a game that redefines what games can be and what they can live up to. This is something more games should aspire to try and perfect.So yes. I recommend it. It's thoughtful, well-written, intricate and with the best of intentions. Above all, it's different. Even if you hate it, you should try it.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												First time I played Depression Quest (about a year ago now), I wasn't doing too well mentally. I didn't want to admit anything was wrong to the people around me and felt shameful about many parts of myself. At some point, I came across the game, made by a few indie developers I hadn't heard of before, and decided to give it a shot.Of all of the games I've played, this one has had the biggest impact on my life. It managed to show me that, just maybe, what I was experiencing in my head wasn't "normal", but neither did I need to feel ashamed about it. I've since sought out professional help and I'm dealing with my mental issues much better.This game may or may not be for you. It is not a fun game - don't expect to come out all smiles. Some even say it's not a game (not me, although I can understand their point based on their definition of the word). If you're easily triggered by stories or discussions about depression, I recommend avoiding playing it if you're trying to stay in a positive mood.However, if you're looking for an understanding of what depression is like, to help you understand what someone else might be going through... or even yourself, this game offers a perspective. It is not the be all or end all of descriptions of what it is like - for sure, some parts of the game's perspective differ from my own experiences with depression - but if you're looking for a starting place to help you develop that understanding, this game is worth a try.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
												Gameplay: 1/10There... isn't any gameplay, really. It doesn't seem like any of your choices really do much of anything, and since there's also no ending, there's no point/motivation anyway. It's essentially just randomly clicking links until you get bored. It's extremely short too; when it finished, I hadn't even reached an hour of play time.Audio: 1/10The audio was just annoying. It's described as being an important part of the experience, but all it is is really plain and awkwardly slow piano music that tries way too hard to sound sad. There was also audio of people talking, which was... okay, I guess. The sound all sounded a little off but I assume that was on purpose.Graphics: 0/10The only graphics were small grainy photographs that appeared over each wall of text. Even without the filters, they look like bad amateur "photography" taken with an old webcam. This contributed to the unprofessional feel of the game.Story: 0/10It's aimless. There's no plot. The pacing is really quick, and you find your character suddenly go from miserably depressed to "barely depressed" in a span of five minutes. A lot of your choices have no real bearing on what will happen anyway. We aren't at any point made to care about this character, so we're stuck lugging through as a guy we don't care about moans about how miserable his life is. I don't know what emotions we were supposed to be feeling throughout the course of this game, but I assume "annoyance" and "boredom" are not on the list.It's also not an accurate portrayal of depression. It's so much more multifaceted than it's portrayed here, and it's obvious that the developer has either never experienced depression or was trying to portray a blatantly fake, one-dimensional depression stereotype.Writing: 0/10Since this is a choose your own adventure book rather than a game, I feel the need to comment on the writing. It's nothing short of awful. To visualize, imagine everything that good writers do; then, imagine that the writer aimed to do exactly the opposite. The Choose Your Own Adventure books in the kids section at the library are more thought-provoking and engaging.Overall: -10/10Yes, that's a negative ten. It's a book, not a game, and it's a bad book at that. Why was this greenlit...?

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
												So, I only played this to see what that whole scandal (and the surrounding mess) on the Internet was about. If it hadn't been for all that, I would not be here writing this.Is depression a real problem for many? Yes.Can it be useful to discuss in a public setting? Sure.Is this the way to do it? Not really.This is like one of those "Choose You Own Adventure" kind of little stories, except it's about depression instead of adventure. There's no actual gameplay, just pages of text and a list of choices that branch the narrative out in different ways. The happy choices are crossed out, so you can only pick less happy ones. Depending on your choices, you get different ending text, but considering that the ending was not even particularly interesting, I see no reason to replay it.The continuity in the narrative is so-so. Even after I kept picking "positive" choices and having my avatar be open about how things were, and so on, for quite some time, the text would occasionally revert to my avatar being back to the bottom without recognizing the previous progress "upwards" in the text, except for the three status phrases always shown near the bottom. It felt rather forced, I must say.Also, regarding the way this whole narrative is presented, I don't get why they would choose to make the reader's perspective one where the narrative keeps pushing "you feel this", "you feel that", "you think this", when clearly that is not going to be the case. It just pushed me, as a reader, away. Combined with the heavy handed narrative that gives the impression that your choices don't necessarily matter all that much, it comes close to breaking even this basic "Choose Your Own Adventure" structure. What were they thinking?They ask you to play with sound on, as it's supposed to be part of the experience, but it's really just annoying. Poor piano music and the occasional annoying sound effect just bugged me. Visually, the presentation looks like a bunch of white web pages with black text, a picture here and there and some links, which I suppose might be pretty close to the truth. The whole thing feels as though it had little to no effort put into anything outside the text itself, which perhaps had some effort put into it but seemingly suffers from a lack of storytelling skill.To summarize, this product of just barely interactive fiction did not tell me anything new about depression, nor did it make me more aware of it than I was previously. If someone claims it's educational, don't believe them. It really isn't.It also has no real entertainment value, so no points there. Those "professional" reviews shown on the store page are just a bunch of non-sense, which is admittedly not all that surprising.Decent products typically exist to do a job for a consumer, be it to educate, to still hunger, to save time or money, or whatever. I can't think of any job that this thing does for a gamer or reader. Perhaps it serves as a vent of sorts for its creators, I don't know. What I do know is that I cannot think of any good reason for this to be on Steam.I wasted a little over half an hour on this, but you don't have to. If it wasn't for the publicity this got from that big mess on the Internet, this little story piece would have been largely ignored and quickly forgotten, and for good reason. It's just not worth your time, so go spend that time on something worthwhile, like doing something fun and/or hanging out with someone who needs you.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												I will be honest, I only heard of this game because of the contreversy surrounding the creater. But amid the turmoil, I found myself somewhere I didn't want to be -a particularly hateful state of mind. I've said things I am not proud of and decided to cool off and approach the axis of this whole ordeal with the presence of mind to be as objective and purely observant as possible, and leaving behind any intial personal feelings and bias so that I may gain a perspective. I am not a professional video game critic in the least bit, but I do write and edit people's stories as a hobby, so I like to think that I have a credible right to review this.With all that said, and after playing through, I do no recommend this game. Foremostly -and this critical point has been brought up before- can this really be considered a game? It is a digital choose-your-own-adventure novel that feels like it belongs to a site dedicated to ametuer fiction or to an art blog like Deviantart -not a video game distributer. I feel Depression Quest would of been more appropriate and more well received if it were distributed on an art site where skill progression and opinionated pieces are welcome. But Steam brings with it a great expectation, and you can be hard hit by the community if you fall short of it with even the greatest intentions. There just isn't a place for a glorified book in steam, and I feel that alone warrants my negative recommendation.But beyond where and how the developers chose to distribute Depression Quest, the game falls flat in a number of ways. Despite a fairly strong start, the protagonist becomes insufferable and I find it impossible to sympathize half the time, and this is due to, for the most part, the constant repitition of the same theme of "I'm sad". The chapters blend together as a blur of melancholy and it becomes increasingly difficult for me to go on as it progresses to the point that it is so dull it becomes a chore to keep on reading. Each page felt like a rehash of the previous with a different background and theme like a depression Madlib. My determination to see it through to the end to gain perspective on the situation was the only thing that kept me going, and I otherwise would of just stopped half way through if this wasn't the case.Then there is the sporadic grammar mistakes, colorless style, lackluster attempt at scenery and visuals, bluntness in the expression of emotions and feelings where I'm just told how he feels and am expected to just accept it -not a sight of subtley to be seen. And there's just a general lack of direction, with what would seem obvious to be the main goal of being 'not depressed' always being touched upon but never probed. Without the going into detail of the process of recovering and coping with depression, all this is is page after page of complaining and whining, with brief breaks to choose between an obviously good choice and the obviously bad one -which brings me to my last point.Literally the only gameplay mechanic the game provides is terrible. There is no critical decisions to be made. One is always the best choice with the rest at varying degerees of bad, making the story linear and defeating the purpose of a choice system, and therefore effectively turning this into a book entirely. The only reason to choose the bad decisions is just to speed through it again to see how it ends differently -and spoiler: it isn't suicide. Yes, what you would expect be the greatest and most terrible end the character could possibly find in game about depression is not that. Not to say that I was hoping to see someone, even fictional, lose themselves to the struggle with depression, but it would add such a greater depth when the reppercussions of not being able to solve your issues with depression is ultimately depth at your own hands. If this game achieved anything, it definitely looks like a depressed person designed it, but it needs a writer that can bring across the feeling of depression and have it seep into the reader with the protagonist's actions and thoughts without the writer themselves getting absorbed in self-pity. If this was a story I received from a upstart writer, I would praise him/her/whoever for what they accomplished, but would stress that they put asside a few more months to work on it and make it everything it could be. However; this is a professional, million dollar site that I and everyone else expects a higher standard from, and this game is below that standard. Its only saving grace is that it's free.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												Okay this isn't going to be a negative review for it being "Not a game" as that's just a pretty ridiculous thing to complain about. Depression Quest, as a product, simply can't exist as anything else other than an interactive experience which at least today, we call a game. It can't be a movie because of the multiple choices, but it also can't be a "Choose your own adventure" book because of the fact that not all choices are available, so it has every reason to be a game. Sorry guys but not all games have to be about winning or losing anymore; whether you like that or not.Anyway yeah Depression Quest, I'm giving this a Negative review not because of what it is, but how it does what it wants to do badly. There are good aspects to the game, I personally like how the more depressed you are the less options you're available to choose, you know it's a nice blend of storytelling and gameplay. Also I dig the grain filter on the images, it's pretty fitting as depression's about exhaustion and the grain makes things seem well... exhausted.But that's about it for what I like about Depression Quest. Depression Quest simply doesn't do its task well. For starters the choices you have to solve the depression are PAINFULLY obvious. If someone was to tell someone with depression how to solve it, they'd say "Take Medication, see a therapist and talk with people about your feelings", things which are much easier to say than do, and while could help depression, it's not necessarily all there is to helping it. Well that's all you need to do to solve it according to the game. A small child could solve the character's depression in this as you simply just do the things that seem helpful. The game could have presented player with harder to understand options, have the more positive options not always be the highest available one, anything. But it doesn't so solving depression is just easy according to the game.And I know you're supposed to put yourself in the character's shoes but you can't really. You're basically told how to feel about situations and characters around you. The game could have very much benefitted from things such as interacting with the co-workers you don't get along with to see why we don't relate to them, but basically the game just tells us we don't which makes it harder for me to be in the character's shoes. Now I'm not depressed. I enjoy my life quite a bit. However even if I was depressed, I'd still be hesitant to relate with this character. I won't know the people in this game, I won't experience the job I hate, I won't feel the lack of motivation from this character when it comes to choosing Depression Quest's choices as I'm never going to face consequences of actions because of my lack in place of this story.  All depression quest boils down to is obvious advice on how to treat depression which COULD help but I can see it not working for a lot of people... however I still don't think it shouldn't exist.  This is a game which is incredibly hard to make. You need to write a LOT to convey this character's life, you need to make the player think a lot with some very complex choices, among other things. Hell, as weird as this sounds, maybe give the player really tedious and unskippable things to read or do that will help make the player feel more exhausted. I don't know. Point is, depression quest could be an alright tool, but as it stands it's just not good enough for somebody with depression to have as a help. I'm sorry.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												This game isn't a game at all. It lacks content, the subject around the plot is incredibly mundane and not enjoyable. Finally, this looks like a game fabricated in the 80's. Text based adventure games haven't aged well, but this game wouldn't pass the bar back in the 80's. Video games are supposed to be an escape from reality, not a center focus around some of the worst parts of it. The reason why this game doesn't fit the bill is simply because of that. Depression is not a good plot for a video game. Maybe a subplot for a specific character, but this doesn't sell. If you're going to make a game based around a mental illness, then I first suggest that you don't do that and instead make a game that is actually enjoyable no matter who's playing it.. I've never suffered from depression, so this game is foreign to me and I cannot connect with the main character(s) at all. That is another point where this game falls so incredibly short. Maybe this would've been alright to donate to a hospital that deals with mental illness, but even at that this "game" would need a massive graphical (sorry, text based adventures dont cut it) and content overhaul. 0/10

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
												I wanted to check out this game and see if it stood up on its own merit, barring all the controversy around its developer. It doesn't. I've played some games similar to this style, such as the infinitely better Digital: A love story, and this one is kind of♥♥♥♥♥♥ Overall, the visual style is pretty plain. Each screen is essentially block text of black font on white backgrounds with 3 polaroids at the top showing some pictures that look like something jacked from shutterstock. The game introduces you to the depressive protagonist, a shut-in with a deadend day job and a sympathetic girlfriend, and presents you with choices on how to deal with different problems in their daily life. This could be anything from fights with said girlfriend to adopting pets. While this could potentially be interesting, the writing is pedantic and completely artless. Normally, prose is probably the last thing you would give a♥♥♥♥♥♥about in a game, or you would at least be willing to look past it. Unfortunately, this is what boils down to an interactive adventure novel, meaning looking past the garbage writing would require you to find meaning or at least enjoyment in the menu layouts. The message is delivered in a very heavy handed and completely unengaging way. Each choice event is usually 3-5 options. Of those, 1 or 2 are red and crossed out options that those of a more balanced brain chemistry would most likely choose. Obviously, the player is supposed to see these options and feel frustrated, much like how a person with depression would feel, given their inability to help themselves or make the "right" choice. Where a more talented developer would have used visual cues/environment/well-written script to make the player feel depressed, they instead decided to use a very simplisitic crutch. The truth is, I really do like these kinds of games. D:LS, Slouching Towards Bedlam, Cypher, etc. Unfortunately, this game is just really not good. To be honest, its pretty boring and nothing deserving of a download. I normally wouldn't even bother to write a review, but I felt that it was good to have some posts from people who are relatively impartial. I could care less about the politics of the developer and all the other controversy surrounding this game. I just wanted to say that Depression Quest, when judged solely on its own merit, is not worth your time.

Posted: August 20, 2014
												To call this game a game would be a misnomer, its essentially a tumblr blog with hyperlinks in which you are given a couple of different option all ending at the same points. However more insultingly then calling this a game is calling this depression quest: The person depicted in this game isn't depressed they are an emo kid who derives enjoyment out of pretending to be depressed so they have something to cry about on their tumblr page to the people they are pretending to be "deep" with.Let me make this clear, depression doesn't make you stupid, which this character clearly is. From my point of view this game was clearly made by someone TRYING to be insightful, but who had a less then terrible grasp on the source material. This project is to accurate portrayal of mental health issues what Victorian era wandering womb & hysteria diagnosis’s are to modern medicine: In no way related.Whatever this project is, one thing is for certain, it needs to not be on steam: Steam is a place for games, not emo masturbation fantasies conveyed in tumblr blogspot style wall of text, with annoying eye straining animation, repetitive image use & white noise static for music.Watching this game scramble for mediocrity and failing is just painful to watch: I'm not depressed, but i'm pretty sure i would be if this was the best thing i could create given how much support the author was given to succeed.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2014
												Depression Quest, is not a game. It is an experience. Unfortunately, the experience is more akin to sitting in a DMV waiting line and reading the dictionary at the same time, only even more tedious. First and foremost, the main portion (and by this I mean all of it) is reading and choosing some "action" that leads to... more reading! . Yes! I totally want to read some lame story to pass the time instead of, you know, PLAYING something. This could be forgivable if not for the fact that the story isn't even that good to begin with. And by that, I mean that I enjoyed reading Wuthering Heights more than this story. Wuthering ♥♥♥♥ing Heights was more interesting than this. What really bothered me the most about this was that the choices you were given almost never go through because your "character" is just too full of self-pity to do anything you say. Way to make me feel like I have ANY control whatsoever over a gaming experience.Imagine if an actual game did this. Suppose you're playing some Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time, and you come across a Blue Tektite. You have some choices here.1. Swing your sword2. Shoot it with an arrow3. Bomb it4. Megaton Hammer it into the groundSo then you choose the best (or most fun) option, but then a text box appears "Link tries to lift the Megaton Hammer to hit the Tektite, but feels his scaly arm skin scratch on the inside of his tunic and is reminded of his moderate to severe plaque psoriasis.* And then Link drops the hammer and leaves without bothering with the Tektite to wallow in self-pity.That's not FUN. That isn't satisfying whatsoever. That's just annoying.Now, I know that there are some "games" where you choose the best options and if you choose a wrong option, bad things happen... but this is EVERY SINGLE TIME YOU CHOOSE SOMETHING. After about halfway through the game I had a sort of epiphany. The goal of the game isn't to understand how it feels to be depressed... Well.. wait yes it is.But by making you depressed.Depression has a few key symptoms that include: -Difficulty concentrating, remembering details, and making decisions.Difficulty concentrating: I'm so bored that I can barely finish a paragraph at a time.-Fatigue and decreased energy.Even scrolling down feels like an effort to me.-Feelings of guilt, worthlessness, and/or helplessness."I can't do anything worthwhile in this game so why bother?"-Feelings of hopelessness, regret and/or pessimism"This game is hopeless and it's so boring. I really regret downloading it, even though it was free."Only see, in this case it doesn't get better. Sure, there's an ending that is "happy", I guess? Honestly I stopped caring long before I got to the ending so I can't really be invested enough to care about the ending. The point is, the game never gets better. So if you're the protagonist. you never get to enjoy life (the game). The only way to get out is to play through and feel like♥♥♥♥♥♥..Or turn the game off (suicide)I'd tell the creators of this game to try harder next time, but that would require them trying at all in the first place.Depression is a serious mental problem. Depression is not a good premise for a game, because depression is not a game. By that token, Depression Quest is not a game. If I wanted to learn about depression, I'd look it up on Wikipedia, not play a "game" about it. Now if you'll excuse me, I'm going to "commit suicide" and go play an actual game.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2014
												first of all, THANK THE GODS that you can turn the sound off... if the developer was actually trying to make people upset, the same boring cycle of slow piano chords ceaselessly droning in the background definitely was a good start. for a game that is mostly comprised with text and story driven, it's not going to win any writing awards, and has some major grammatical issues. It also literally defeats the purpose of gaming for most people (escapism, fun, excitement, etc.), and thrusts you into an extremely boring story filled with a 2-dimensional protagonist (you) and 1-dimensional supporting characters. It was utterly annoying that any and all "good" choices in this choose your own adventure story were crossed out, and the only choices you were allowed to make were either self destructive or passive aggressive.plus, it was a little weird that the main character is actually doing pretty well overall. has a decent job, has a great girlfriend that's super understanding and supportive, family that also are nice and helpful. purposely choosing self destructive behavior to drive people away just resulted in the glaringly obvious to happen (treat gf really terrible and she leaves), and removes the more passive aggressive choices to only leave the more self destructive ones (except adopting a cat adds one or two new options to play with the cat randomly instead of watching Netflix) but the ending is still pretty much the same boring ending as when you choose all the good things.overall impression: somewhere between 'meh' and 'why would anyone play this?'

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
												Interactive Fiction was one of the first genres of videogames that I ever got seriously into. The reasons why are mainly by accident: I was a pre-teen looking for fun things play online that had a little more depth than crappy flash games. A google search landed me on an Infocom database site, and learning how to use WinFrotz, I entered the magical world of text based, parser command games. Zork, Andrew Plotkin, Emily Short, Chickzilla, Slouching Towards Bedlam, Aaron A. Reed (Blue Lacuna), Taco Fiction. These games and authors of games shaped what I know, love, and enjoy from the genre.Playing Depression Quest was difficult for me. The reason being because it does so many things that turn Interactive Fiction players like me off. One of the biggest mistakes was doing the age old WOT, or Wall of Text mistake. The game likes to open, and continue, to barrage you with walls of text, and this makes for terrible flow in IF games. No one wants to sit and read a wall of text every time they make a decision. It's a typical amateur IF game mistake that I'm surprised has been allowed in a game published on Steam. The second biggest issue with this game is the lack of choice. I get that part of the reason that half of the choices are crossed out and unusuable are because they are the "rational" or "good" choices that a person who does not suffer depression would typically choose. But that's not a good excuse for crappy design, because I am no longer playing the game: the game is instead playing itself. The only feeling of "helplessness" that Depression Quest seems to evoke is that of surrendering all choice to the game. Which is another amateur IF mistake.And yes, I get it, that is the point of Depression Quest. To take away your choice because when you suffer from depression you don't have one. But that's where the word "game" comes into question here: is Depression Quest a game? The reason I know it is not, is simple.It says so right in the WoT introduction: "This game is not meant to be a fun or lighthearted experience." It's not meant to be fun. So of course how can it be a game? Nor is it a CYOA (choose your own adventure), because despite the feature of choice, the choices ultimately effect literally nothing, and are always extremely similar to one another.So why is it on Steam? Well I guess it's in an effort to raise awareness that Depression is a real problem. So is it a good education tool? I don't really think so; it doesn't do it's job as well as it should. There were games that made me feel like the person I was playing easily, not from experience, but from sheer authorship alone, and the way it was designed. That was Blue Lacuna, and when I look at this game, Blue Lacuna, in terms of trying to get the player to understand how something feels, makes Depression Quest look kind of...lazy...in terms of what it tried to do in order to simulate an experience. Blue Lacuna, unlike Depression Quest, didn't "tell me how I felt" constantly, it evoked that feeling by building the feeling around me. I felt it. And like Depression Quest, it had the same outcome: an insurmountable dread that you cannot escape, no matter how much I clung to the time, place, and people I was living with. It came and it took me regardless, no matter what I felt, or what I did.tl;dr:While Depression Quest may bring depression awareness to Steam, that's about as far as it goes. Honeslty I don't think this should have been made a game. Using words is a very hard way to convey a feeling. And other than that, there's a difference between making a game with an agenda, and making a game with an agenda done well.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												This 'game' is not a game.It's text-based and basically you read long paragraphs about the character, who you are supposed to reflect yourself in to, and then click various hyperlinks to see where the story goes from there. In the beginning there are a few hyperlinks within the post that tell you a little about your relationships with your parents, brother, and your girlfriend, as well as your job. After this, it talks about the following days with hyperlinks on what to do next at the bottom. This is where I have my problem.I have depression. Out of all of these 'choices', normally one or two of them are in red and have a strike through them meaning that these are options that you cannot do because your character is simply incapable of doing because of their depression. The other choices? One is the 'right choice' of doing something that brings them out with their friends or to work on their side project, and the other two are normally 'withdraw from social interaction', 'nothing, I don't want to talk about my problems,' or, 'I'm going to go back to sleep.' Most of the 'bad options' made the person with depression seem lazy and that people with depression just don't want to deal with what's bothering them. Are you ♥♥♥♥ing kidding me?Depression is different for everyone and what this game seems to recommend is to get out and do things. Sure, that helps a little, but it never gets to its core. Not everyone is going to get help from that, and not everyone gets better by taking anti-depressants or medication.I'm offended by this game. After playing it I felt angry. Clearly, they have no idea what depression really is.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												Where to start. This game looks like it was written in Flash by someone unfamiliar with how to create a project in Flash. Seriously, I've seen students who - in their first few weeks of learning how to create Flash projects - had created something far, far better than this.The writing and design of this title is simply poor. Choices, when prompted, often don't make any sense, even in the context of psychology (not to mention game design). e.g. if someone doesn't like cats it doesn't mean they're going to get depressed - dog people exist too. This game does nothing for the great cat people/dog people divide in our society - instead of taking the opportunity to mend fences, the author insists that people who don't like cats are depressed loners, longing to slit their wrists.As someone who has suffered on and off again with depression my entire life, along with extensive counseling and even some psychology coursework, I went into this game expecting to understand the subject matter better than most. Instead I'm given a series of overly simplified, trite choices created by a team who didn't understand the first step in game design: understand your subject matter. If you're going to make a first person shooter, you need to spend your time looking at other first person shooters, learning what makes them good and bad, then try to create a game that's compromised of more good elements than bad. When you're going to make a game dealing with psychology,.. you damn well better have a firm grasp of psychology. Anyone who was actually depressed would likely end up getting more depressed by "playing" this, thanks to the boorish way the authors deal with their subject.I recommend in the strongest possible terms that everyone simply avoid this title at all costs, it has no redeeming value whatsoever.

number of helpful: 19 of 33 people (58%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
												Thought I would review this game to get an alternate opinion of it.Depression Quest is an interactive fiction game and not a modern one. It is in the vein of early computer games that were entirely text-based and derived from narratives. I think that is one of the reasons reviews are mixed on it. It doesn't fit the mold of what a "modern" computer game is. Us old fart garmers will remember this type of gaming experience with fondness.That being said, I can really only reccommend  the game for people who want to experience or learn about clinical depression or people who want to deal with their clinical depression in a positive way.It is ingenious in its audacity and for tackling an often overlooked mental disease. It is innovative for its attempt to recreate the experience of a disease at a very realistic level. All the little things are there, such as the thought among many depressives that they don't actually have a disease when they are able to deal with it effectively (yes, that is a real thing) or excusing your tiredness for simply being tired, instead of the effects of a disease. Effects on concentration, focus, seeking diversion (as a result of the disease, not as a way to find enjoyment as it is with many people), social anxiety, interpersonal relationships, and others are all modeled. It takes the form of a choose-your-own-adventure (as interactive fiction generally is) and so there is some replay value to it. I personally played it several times and, since I don't know how the different paths of the game are determined, it's actually kind of fun (yes, in that ruminating depressive sort of way!) to tease out how the choices are rendered.This is a game that does not have a wide appeal and is a very niche product. It is a game that has a therapeutic effect for suffers and/or is a way for the curious to "play" with the disease and challenge some preconceptions of yours or your preconceptions of those who suffer from the disease. If you are even remotely interested or intrigued, I'd suggest it because it is free. Just realize that the "fun" of the game is derived from  learning about something, not derived from entertainment.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2014
												This "text based depression simulator" is pretty on point with how depression presents itself upon a persons actions and thoughts, however the simulator tells you again and again how much you care about your loved ones, but never lets you act on these variables as they are presented to you. It seems the simulator just really wants to drive the point home that depressed people are sad all of the time. Feeling sad isn't called "depression", feeling sad is called "feeling sad" If I didn't have depression, and was told to play this game to learn more about what depressed people deal with day-to-day, I'd spend more time making the depressed person feel worse by asking them if they were "okay" all of the time. What depressed people want are people that understand that a depressed person is depressed, rather than trying to sit them down and lecture them or...try to tell them how they can help. Depressed people are healed by being in an environment where they can forget about their self-loathing for a little while, or by doing something that takes their mind off of it. It doesn't help when someone is at your back asking you how they can help when you show any signs of coming down. The ending to this needs to have an addendum to letting people know that getting someone who is depressed to forget about it for a while is all the help they need to do. Anything else is just pity or unrealistic.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
Not A Good Game.Depression Quest = Depression - QuestOkay, sooo...  I'll preface this by saying that there has been a lot of "controversy" about DQ in gaming spheres.  Most of us that are clued in to the gaming subculture know all about it and I'll only bring it up just this once during the review.  The only thing I will say about it is that this review is utterly detached from the poopstorm.  I'm here to tell you what I think of DQ as a game in it's own right.ProTip: If that already sounds too "SJW" for you, this game is definitely NOT for you.  Don't download it, don't install it, don't worry about it.  Everyone else, read on.Download this FREE game if you: Are interested in learning a bit more about depression. Are looking for a very casual narrative experience. Are interested in what all the "hullabaloo" is about. Aren't a Burgers & Fries poopstain.Decline this quest if you: Want interesting gameplay, such as puzzles, shootmans, or jumping.  This is not for you. Do not have an open mind about clinical depression. Are looking for something that is "fun".  This is a game about DEPRESSION. Are scurred of scurry SJW skeltins hurtin' your fee fees!The Bottom LineAs the title suggests, this really isn't a "good" game, or even much of a game at all.  It's a short story exploration and there is no real "win" condition exactly, no highscores, no frag count, and no real "questing" despite the title.In short, it kinda really sucks as purely a game.That isn't why you should play DQ though.  You should play DQ if you think you may suffer from depression and don't know what to do.  You should play DQ if you have "that friend" who seems nice but is always a "loner" and you don't know why.  You should play DQ to learn more about a prevalent mental health issue that suffers from intense stigma.Is Depression Quest the "answer" to depression?  Hell no.  It is only one facet of the story.  Depression is something that plays out differently for everyone that experiences it, and no one experience is the end-all definition of the condition.  That all said, however, there were a few situations in DQ that hit close to home for me, despite other scenarios not being necessarily so.The take-away here is that you should absolutely not feel alone and that you should seek SOME sort of help.  From family, from friends, and your other loved ones.  Depression's best ally is isolation.Don't expect a lot from this game.  It's not a revolution.  It doesn't even say anything new.  It is just another helpful point of view in the overall discussion and nothing more.  Really.  That is it.It's also free, but you can donate if you wish.  That's really all there is to it.  After all the hyperbole I fully expected to be forcefully neutered by a crack team of dye-color haired SJW cuck-warlords just for playing it.  Nope.  Just a regular♥♥♥♥♥little text adventure about a condition that affects many people in our societies, regardless of politics.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2014
												I've played this game for a bit on the Depression Quest site. And I thought the title was strange. Am I on a quest to being depressed?There is absolutely no gameplay whatsoever. You just click hyperlinks and just keep reading. Think Homestuck, but no interesting visuals, no engaging dialogues/text to read. You can't really seem to 'connect' with the main character (depressed you).I like visual novels. And I've played quite a bit of date-simulation games mainly for the pretty visuals.But 'Depression Quest' isn't a visual novel; it's literally a novel digitized with some somber music playing on a loop. It's so full of text I doubt anyone who's looking to play an actual game would want to spend a quarter of an hour on this. You'll prefer reading all the books in Skyrim.You get options:> Continue with 'game'> Quit and play something more worthwhileSome options being crossed-out so I see no point in even listing them as a choice.I'm much in support of helping people rid of depression but this isn't helping me or anybody i know who has depression. I'd very much prefer not to waste my time playing this 'game' and actually talk to my depressed friend.Depression Quest lives up to its name in getting you Depressed. For real.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												I'm not a fan of Zoe Quinn.Is it weird that the story describes me so well, yet has so many flaws to it that I don't understand? It's like as if they have picked at my brain and took my life apart but added extra things to it to spice it up a bit, like parents that care or a job that I can sustain but I hate?I've only been through a bit of the game and it has turned out okay. To be honest, even though it's a text based adventure, it feels like there is just TOO much text. It branches off important subjects that you don't know properly, like your relationship with your girlfriend Alex, your parents, your job, your brother that you're jealous of, etc. when it feels like it shouldn't really be describing each important subject with such detail. They should have just added minor explanations of certain things to help you become acquainted with the character that you are portraying, rather than create entirely new stories out of them that make it hard to catch up with and remember.The idea of depression being different for everyone is both true and false, and they do have that kinda knotted down properly in the beginning of the game with an explanation, but I don't think they should say to stop playing it immediately if you are suicidal or anything close simply because it's a falsity of something relevant to you.I like the idea of the game to help explain to people not suffering from depression what it's like, but it just doesn't fit well. It says that it's not an explanation or detail of depression because it varies between people, but it nails it down to just one type of depression, contradicting itself in the process of the entire game.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												This is utter tripe. Not even as an avid adventure gamer could I find enjoyment out of this. I suffer from depression and almost a year ago I ended up in the hospital due to it, but this experience, and i use that term lightly, was not something I could relate to.The thing about depression, and it's associated pain is that it's individualized, no one will know what it is like to be in your shoes, and a video game about your experience won't help anyone come to any realizations.This doesn't show what depression is like, nothing can and since everyone experiences it differently, I suggest you pick up a psychology book if you really want to understand depression.There isn't much here of substance, it's all very arbitrary and lacking. It looks like a 5 year old designed it and athestically it looks like it was made with windows 95 in mind.Ironically, the game made me more depressed than I already was, but depressed in a different way... depressed that this made it through greenlight. This doesn't belong here. It's not a game.The entire time I was playing it, I was pigeon holed into making choices I didn't want to make, and as a person with depression many of the choices that were blocked for me were choices that I would make. I felt a strong sense of a victim mentality from the "author".Just like anyone with depression - We are but a victim of our own minds. She is a victim, but her own victim, and it doesn't sound like she has enough of a grasp on depression to be trying to educate others on it. Having depression doesn't make you a good teacher on the subject.There isn't much to be had here, it's basically a choose your own adventure book, except you can't really make your own choices. Only the choices of the author. Which is the point, I get it - but it is poorly done.Thumbs down.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												This game is the video game equivalent of valium, and is extremely offensive to someone like me.As a sufferer of deep depression, the creator of this game is so far off base. Depression is not you feeling sad or upset that you're behind on that big project, or worried that your girlfriend might not be completely happy with your relationship. Depression is a numbness. There are days when leaving the house feels like the biggest accomplishment on the planet. There are no distractions from depression. You can't just get on Twitter or your email in hopes to forget about it. There is no blocking it out. And no matter what, you put on the bravest of faces, and you hide your condition.Zoe Quinn, you did a horrible disservice to the gaming community and sufferers of depression.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
												Not only is this "not a video game," in the sense that there is no video and nothing to play or have fun with, but an oddly formatted choose your own adventure novel, it's also a poorly written choose your own adventure novel; it breaks the classic rules of "show, don't tell," the writing is awkward and clumsy, and little of it is actually grammatically correct. "Depression Quest" is not only boring and poorly written, it's portrayal of depression is off-base in a number of ways. If you choose the "right" option early on (like the third page or so), everything goes swimmingly for "you," and you suffer basically no symptoms of depression. You have a loving and wonderful support system of family, friends, and even a girlfriend. Everyone in the story's universe seems to understand depression (aside from your kind of ♥♥♥♥♥y mom), and you face no obsticles in your pursuit for therapy and drugs beyond yourself. The main character is an overprivelaged ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ who does the bare minimum to cope with his depression, and feels, at worst, "a bit worn out" by his attempts to carry on a somewhat normal existance. In reality, depression ravages you, and it changes it types of decisions you would make. It does not instantly turn you into a whiny litle ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Depression ignites a myriad of different reactions, but the character in this story lays down and waits to die. When I myself went through depression, I was♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥that I had to bury my feelings and keep trudging onwards. For the most part, extreme apathy seems to be consistent, but never really arises in this game. If anything, "you" care TOO much: Depression Quest's character is "worried his girlfriend doesn't really like him that much," even though she is entirely supportive (unless you agressively whine at her and accuse her of not caring) and doesn't even get frustrated with you when you wake her up. Depression Quest treats depression as something easy to get out of if you get your thumb out of your bum for just long enough to get into therapy. It also treats drugs as a cure-all with little to no side-effects and an impossibility of increasing your overall distress. How accurate. This game sucks.

In its current shape, Deprssion Quest would've been better off being launched as a website, or a web/browserbased game, rather than a full scale game suitable to be played through platforms like Steam.All in all, the game could really need some more improving. And if you ask me, no price is the best price for this game.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												It's hard to review this for 2 reasons. 1 is obviously all the controversy surrounding it makes it hard for anyone to take any review seriously, and 2 because it's not even really a game. I don't mean because there's no graphics, swordplay, puzzles, platforming, etc, etc, I still play zork on dosbox. I say that because it's more of a story of someone ELSE'S battle with depression, which is a serious problem I won't make fun of. You aren't given options that you'd take, you're forced into the same pattern of spiraling depression everytime which kind of gives the impression that it's hopeless, as if it didn't already feel like that. I've battled depression since my father died when I was 11, dealt with it still when I was 15 and my grandfather passed away from cancer, then at 19 when I was diagnosed with cancer, then for the next 14 months as I watched two close friends lose their fight with cancer. I know depression, my depression, but that doesn't mean I can tell anyone else what it's like or how to deal with it. My way was to open up to my friends and family (Drake, Mar, Crim, if you guys read this know you've probably saved me a couple of times when I was in a down mood just by bringing in some normalcy and letting me know there are people that care) but I know that's not an option for a lot of people. It was actually impossible for me to come out and talk to my mom about it, I had to write a note on the computer and leave it there for her to find. If you suffer depression, this game won't help you. If you know someone that's depressed or that you THINK might be depressed, this game won't help you.
