number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 31, 2014
												Is there any better way for a game to start than by disclaimer it is not for the faint of heart, yet it fails to depict meaningful drama or genuine negative consequences of depression? Besides occasional lines of dialog how I am horrible because depression and someone cannot take it any more and suddenly we're up to something else? What borderlines irony is the foreword of the game is perhaps the most enjoyable part of the game, since it feels like the developers knew their onions; they laud and dazzle how it focuses on depression... by simply telling what it is. You have depression. Everything is great but you just have depression and then things falls apart and end of story - or not quite but more like sort of but not kind of. Boo said the ghost of hung criminal at the gallows.Unless there is some new, booming market for choose-your-own-depression books, since choose-your-own adventure books usually operate on different matters at hand.If the game simply gave basic framework for interactivity to properly explore, shallowly telling what is going on with no further investment is not bad idea. That is assuming there is more interactivity besides click for another skip of text that makes me want to read an actual book. I do not shun the idea of interactive media branching beyond common "ideas" for video games, but I hesitate to call Depression Quest even an unfinished novella, or early prototype for a visual novel. It is a game which throws plenty of text with less substance than Harlequin novels, offending ambiguity not to offend anyone with anything vaguely related to English gender pronouns, and no personal viewport to depression... which the foreword already said is very subjective. I am here to read a story for the novelty of reading a story about depression that pretends to be a video game: People are referred as human beings as ambugiuosly as possible all the bleeping time with less character than mouldy piece of paper, and once again, I am supposed to be looking through viewport to one manifestation of depression. Yay. (If semantics are that important, can we please have it written in language with no gender-specific pronouns - aside from inconvenience of less potential readers? Too hardcore? Why not ask the reader's gender? Still too specific or offending? Why not just offer option to type it down then and have pronouns adjusted accordingly for pity's sake?)Rhetorically, it is the only part where the game feels like there was actual effort to convey idea of depression with extremely nonexistent and empty presentation of everything. Unfortunately that still leaves me, as a reader, unconvinced as lame horse merchant given the pronounced lack of subjectivity in something which is supposed to be pretty subjective experience. Warsaw in Poland, cows moo, dogs bark, depression is unfortunate experience etc etc. Such lovely and profound words of wisdom and insight! Truly we are dealing here with a masterpiece! Broken record! Round two! Fight!Oh, and the absolute best\worst part of is lack of even hinting at suicide or you know, actual drama between people besides few lines of dialog. My depression nearly culminated to eaten shotgun and several burned bridges; some which remain burned to this day. What does the game tell you to offer anything remote to this kind of drama? Few lines of dialog and leave imagination do the rest, which could be fair with deeper substance. Once again, the game outright assumes player has absolutely no idea what depression is about, which is subjective but the narrative is less compelling than reading kindergarteners' stories. Where is subjectivity? Has the writer(s) ever heard of show, don't tell? Here it's tell, also choose your own silly options which leads to even more telling what depression is about in daily life.Depression Quest could be passable, even perhaps curious and interesting piece of work if it did not too hard to be an "art" game. Art game with novelty of being about depression to educate the foolish, ignorant savages how depression may manifest by presenting ideal scenario torn down by boringly dramatic events presented as grippingly as reading the latest football or hockey match results from news, only exception being at least the match scoreboard can offer me useful insight to what happened. Same cannot be said of Depression Quest, no matter how noble or unfortunate its beginning may have been.(Edit as of September 2nd: fixed some Engrish.)

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 21, 2014
												The best way to do this game justice is to look at a pile of♥♥♥♥♥♥with a few roses hidden inside it. A lot of the story seems like projection of the author and a misunderstanding of how deppression works on the brain and through processes. There are, however, a few very good points that perfectly outline what and how deppression is, but only if you are able to analyze the game without your own bias. The author tried to use situations and telling (instead of showing) how the character feels to try and manipulate the player into understanding deppression, yet she *completely* missed the point. If she truly wanted to make people understand deppression she would've used the mentioning and not mentioning of in game concepts to manipulate the player into looking at a 90/10 world of happiness/sadness and making the player only look at the sad. That would be a true work of art, unfortunately this is just angsty-projection with big words thrown in to sound smart and tell instead of show. 2/10 Is harmful to the understanding of how deppressed people's mindset and feelings. Is also terribly written at times and has typos.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 16, 2014
												I'll admit, when I first downloaded this game, I thought it was going to be much worse than it actually was.As far as games go, you could definitely do worse, especially since some of those worse games would actually cost you money. However, the writing style feels a bit sloppy. The main character is described as sparingly as possible early on, to make him/her a blank slate for the player to put themselves in his/her shoes. And then the writers screwed that up by giving the main character a family and girlfriend, which requires him/her to be a definite person seperate from player. You can't have a character that you make your own and have the same character be defined by the writer, because odds are, the two ideas of what the character should be won't mesh.I'll be generous and give it a 7/10.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												I was (And still am) diagnosed with moderate-to-severe depression. While it has been getting better, I can entirely say this experience was complete and utter garbage.How it handles something as permeating as depression is shameful at best and downright ham-handed at worst, shoehorning in options some people take, but then crossing them out in what I can only assume is their way of saying people who are really depressed don't make them. Some victims don't just shut themselves in, and this story seems to be saying that all of them do. In addition, depression is usually a slow fadeout. It doesn't just ♥♥♥♥ing appear in less than a day, and getting rid of it can take months at best, years at worst. Then, the ending which claims it is a constant battle is an absolute slap in the face. We've been so hilariously unrealistic so far, why didn't you go that final ♥♥♥♥ing mile and make our protagonist suddenly all better, ready to face the world with his arsenal of rainicorns and unibows? Did you waste it on your "Watch Netflix and cry" scenes?I could say so much about this game, about how badly it does what it set out to do, how I completely loathe the developer and the scandal parade behind her, but I'll just stop at this:This is not depression. This is a Social Justice Warrior's depression fantasy. And that's dangerous.

												This isn't really a game, it's more of a short story, a poorly written short story at that.  I don't really care about the controversy, I will admit that is what brought me here, but I wanted to see if this person had created something that could elevate public awareness of what depression really is.  Unfortunately the answer is no, the "game" looks lazily put together with little to no effort whatsoever, the narrative is a stretch at best and does very little to illustrate what living with depression is like.  To be frank, calling whatever this is a game is a travesty.I understand that Zoe wants to see women in the gaming industry and I fully support this notion.  Women have a lot to offer the gaming community as a whole and the gaming community can only benefit from the inclusion of female voices in the industry.  However the controversy that bore this "game" is not the way to make that happen.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												Played it for a little to see what's up thinking, hey at least it brings attention to depression, but I think it does a poor job of showing what depression is like, from my experience with it, and it would be difficult for a game like this to show the thought process of someone who is depressed when the final options are already laid out in front of you. The writing was also kind of meh, just seemed very stale and boring, lost interest around the third page. I also could not become immersed or interested in the story at all, I was not able to put myself in the shoes of the character basically because the whole gender neutral tone gave me no information about the character, and what information I did get felt like it was being shoved down my throat from the beginning and I was not left to discover the information throughout the story, it made it seem like the character was more of a robot than a person the fact that I have to describe the character as him/her or "the character" illustrates this point. Something’s that could be done to improve the game:1) Try to make it easier for the play to become immersed, a short questionnaire that would ask the age, gender, and sexual orientation of the player that would change the story slightly to fit this information and help the reader step into the shoes of the character. I was basically taken out of the story from the very beginning by how hard the game tried to be gender neutral with the whole "you are a human being, you have a significant other" thing. Also no one describes them self as a "mid-twenties human being and this information is irreverent anyways, we know the character is a human being and there would be better ways to find out the age of the character than this. 2) You need better writing period, this game is heavily dependent on reading and yet the story is poorly written and robotic. Instead of telling us who the character is right off the bat, let us discover the character, develop him/her over time instead of having him/her fully formed straight from the beginning. Show us his/her experiences instead of telling us "you lack motivation, you lose sleep over this" show us how the character has lost his/her motivation, show us how him/her is up all night wondering why he/she can't seem to get his/her life on track. TD;DR:Get better writers who can write a decent story, get rid of gender neutrality, and make the game more interactive.

												This game is so bad written that you actually don need tho read the whole text to know what is happening.Besides the fact that your decitions through the game doesn't make any actual differences on the story, the gameplay is just clicking over hyperlinks to read the rest of your "story".The story is about some person (you; and the genre isn't specified, wich makes everything a lot confusing) that is wondering what to do about it's life.l The character is around 22 years old, and it's a complete moron; the "game" is supossed to make the player actually "feel" what is it about having "depression", when the character is just being a complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥ about everything and playing the "victim" role.Actually, the thing that most bothered (sadly not the only one) me is that the only character that's actually well personified is the main one, the rest of the characters of the story were just a cliché of what the "main" character thinks about people, getting you away from what's really happening, and confusing your gameplay.You can make decitions, but only the ones that the game lets you make, the others are actually ridiculous and are marked in red (ovbius sign that is just more text to read) this gimmick of the game makes you feel that all the decitions you make are all the same. number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
												As much as I would love for people to understand what it's like to live with depression and go through every day with such helplessness and a game is understandably a very promising way to go about for giving others that insight, I don't believe there was much fleshing out at ALL for this so-called "game." This is not a game. It's a choose-your-own-adventure story that would do better if there was some kind of visual, less scrolling paragraphs and pages to read through before a choice, and somewhat better options. The thing with it is that it's understandable that it's not going to be any fun - I mean it's called Depression Quest and the whole point is to show what it's like but at the same time, so much work to go through means nobody is really going to read everything. People are just going to exit out. Some of the responses don't seem very realistic either. But then we all have different experiences with depression and some have none. It wasn't very good, the story was mind-numbing as were the supposed characters, responses and timeframes could be better, it was long and arduous and usually I just skimmed to make my choice, and the "game" was so quick that it was just blah. If I want I could just tell people everything I'm experiencing or feeling instead. It'd be a little more fun that's for sure!

content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
												It's utter♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ It does not even help in the slightest in learning about depression (Let alone the MULTIPLE FORMS OF IT), and instead uses it to motivate a floppy 2 dimensional story. That's right. It uses depression as the driving force of a story. Not that it can't be done, but this game delivers it in the most awful way possible. The game gives no insight on how the psyche of a depressed person truly works, and utterly shames the issue completely. Developers, you should feel ashamed for this. I feel ashamed for this game, as a player, and as someone who deals with others with depression daily. A simple google search could have given you plenty of insight, but instead you choose the most bland, stereotypical version of depression, and followed that through. Why on Earth would you all think your base knowledge was good enough for such a complex issue?!?! If this game was truly for insight on depression, you all should have spent more time adding in various stories that at least include each form of depression (Chronic, Persistent, Major, Bipolar(Manic), Seasonal Affective Disorder, Psychotic, Postpartum, Premenstrual, Situational, and Atypical. There you go, listed all known forms of depression, go research them and deliver the players a PROPER informational Story on each form of depression with actions backed by research from professionals proven to help against depression. Not just "Take the meds, get motivated" bull♥♥♥♥♥♥) As a person who deals with this, depressed people can lie to others, can manipulate cunningly well to hide a more sinister side to their depression, which can ultimately cause themselves Fatal injuries. Some depressed individuals, if not all, plan out their deaths to prevent any intervention. This game shames all of those people. This game shames the issue. This game is shameful, and any news site or what have you that tells you that it is accurate to the psyche of a depressed individual clearly need to research their♥♥♥♥♥♥Alright, now the game is nothing special. It's a shoddily, quickly done Visual Story (If that can even be justified), with a looping audio of a "Piano playing a minor key for emphasis on the mood which makes the game cheesy and irritating to listen to". Not to say the piece is bad, but when it loops it becomes grating on the ears quickly. Devs, add in different audio tracks, options for said audio, and the like to suit the mood of the story. When things go well, make the melancholy music fade somewhat or become slightly more cheerful. When there are dips in the story, make the audio change accordingly. The audio, as it is, is half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥and lazy. I can play any D-minor improv and get the same effect as this audio. Improve the game's audio, and story, those are it's fronts and they are both LACKING. Obviously the game was designed to play on people's heart-strings and suck out as much cash as possible. So make it do that, because right now, you all are FAILING MISERABLY AT DOING THAT. You are failing as a team to deliver a sensational, informational, honest story that could be BEAUTIFUL. It has the premise of a good Story, so make it good. If you need help with that, read EDGAR ALLEN POE a few times, Read notes from depressed individuals, spend TIME with depressed individuals. Learn about the people, then their psyche, and then deliver the steam player base a sensational story.Fix it, or rebuild the game completely, but don't leave it as a decaying piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥it is now. If you all fix it, I garauntee a lot of negative reviews that are relevant will turn positive, and you all might not have such a bad track record later on.If you, the individual thinking about this game, truly want to learn about depression, don't waste your time on this piece of garbage, and instead look it up online and learn from professionals who deal with it daily. This Free game isn't even a game, nor is it even informational on the situation it tries to convey and talk about. You could spend your time better by having a burger and fries at Five Guys.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
												Impossible to relate to. This guy is not depressed, he's just unhappy. In reality you don't make one simple mistake and it drives you into spiraling depression leaving you unable to interact with people, have fun or function in daily life. That's what happens in this game: he makes one simple mistake that anyone can make and goes from being moderately depressed to deeply depressed (there is an ingame tracker). Real depression is NOTHING like that! It takes a lot more than that to actually make depression worse keeping in mind that depression numbs your emotions so you don't care about stuff as much. You can actually make him reach the highest level of depression in 3 steps making the same mistakes any person could do in one day and brush it off and walk away. Whoever made this game has never had depression, doesn't understand it and is not in any position to be educating anyone on it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
												The game has an understanding of how a person with depression can react to things but doesn't take some things into consideration. I feel it can be a hard read mostly due to the length. I don't think a lot of people can really relate with it since they will be in varying situations. I would have prefered if the game featured more than one music track since looping one can get kind of irratating. As a tool to teach others about depression I don't know how effective it would be and it feels more like a depression questionnaire that you would take on a site then a game. As someone who was diagnosed with depression I could relate to parts but I feel a few things should be mentioned. Antidepressants are not always the best solution, in my experience I kept having to switch between meds to find which worked best since some cause really bad nausea, insomnia, and mood swings. I can't speak much on therapy since I only went in for a few sessions and would constantly put off or forget my sessions. And for those that don't have people in their lives to talk to it is worth noting that you can find support groups that you can talk to. I always found it easier to talk to people I didn't know about my issues since I felt less worried about being judged. Overall I think if you have depression you would understand some of the choices you are presented with but if you are trying to understand someone else's depression it might be a bit harder. I liked that some options were crossed out but I feel an explaination on why you aren't up to that choice would be better suited. The game was kind of long winded and I feel that it could have been said with fewer words and would still have surmised the point it was aiming at.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2016
												This "game' is nothing more than a story made by a team of people who seemed to only read articles about depression, never experiencing it first hand. Depression is not feeling good enough and knowing it 100% of the time. Depression is distancing yourself from everyone, including your family because you feel like you'll drag them down. Depression is choking yourself until you see nothing but black and fall to the ground only regretting that you didn't tie it tight enough. Depression is hoping something terrible happens to you, like being run over. Depression isn't this game. This game is a sorry excuse for a depression simulator. I have been sexually assaulted, and not in the "he only touched me" way. The person in the story has no motive really, besides work and we don't even know the job all that well. This game did only one thing for me and that was relive my past. The only depressing thing about this game was that. But if the game's job was to make me depressed today, then mission ♥♥♥♥ing accomplished. ♥♥♥♥ you developers.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												An incredibly offensive game implying that people suffering from depression are absolutely helpless; the removal of so many options and restricting the character to a meagre amount of actions, some that many depressed people would take if in that position, shows how little the writers understand about depression. The obvious ignorance about the disorder combined with the gall of the writers to pigeonhole an entire group of people and the absolute abhorrent use of the death of such a beloved public figure (Robin Williams) to plug their game is, frankly, disgusting. I would not recommend this game to anyone as it perpetuates societies ignorance and apathy towards mental illness whilst simultaneously offending and marginalising the victims of this cruel disorder. The only positive I can say is at least this filth has not been monetised and hopefully the proportion of negative reviews dissuades any one to play this game. I sincerely hope the creators regret publishing Depression Quest and in future refrain from hurting people. For individuals very enmeshed, get up yourselves.

It's the most lacking game I can think of as being on steam. It consists of clicking on hyperlinks to continue the plot, which is told through text. Not really very gripping material.At the very least, it's somewhat informative about what people with depression go through, but it's a really awful "game". I was bored with it when it was a browser game I clicked through once, and I'm still immensely bored with it, and surprised it got onto steam greenlight with how little of a game it was. I'm willing to bet people only threw in their vote because they felt they had to because of the creator's supposed "attacks because female" and will forget about it just as soon as I did.Save yourself the download and play it in a browser.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 21, 2014
												This work of interactive fiction (this is not a game on the basis that a choose-your-own adventure book is not a video game because you read it online) fails on both of its objectives, that is a, to "show other sufferers that they are not alone in their feelings", and b. to "illustrate to people who may not understand the illness the depths of what it can do to people". Firstly, the concept of "Depression Quest" seems to be something of a text-based roleplay, but the protagonist has no definite identity other than a "twenty-something human being", presumably in an attempt to be politically correct for correctness's sake, which instead comes of as dismissive to "other sufferers" as the only thing i could tell you about the protagonist is that he/she/it has depression, the effects of which seem to be feeling sad sometimes and losing motivation after every few paragraphs based on my playthrough, which in no way illustrates to people the effects of the illness since it does little to differentiate depression from "being sad sometimes". Furthermore, the "professional" reviews above seem to praise the game for being "innovative" and "artsy" however nothing In the game open to interpretation in the way a proper art piece should be, and it is impossible for this game to be Voyeuristic if the character himself has no identity, there is no intimacy between the reader and the character;the reviewers Effectively use the game to deliver the illusion of artistic critique.Going past the recent social media uproar surrounding the personal lives of the developers, Depression Quest is still Ultimately a falied experiment at best and a dismissive publicity stunt at worst, delivering nothing that any site on depression You could find wouldn't give you. It is ultimately a cautionary tale about indie games that try to push the limits and be "edgy" Somehow becoming less artistic than games created solely for gameplay.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												*This is a review based off the game alone. No contoversy, no rant about being text only, just a review"Bottom line, Depression Quest is a game about immersing you, the player, into the protagonist's shoes, trying to fight depression with little hope.It starts off telling you that this isn't ment to be played as a game, but as an actual way to help you sink into someones life that is suffering from depression. It does a good job of doing that. The game's strong point is being text based. This may sound weird, but when the games says you are feeling hopeless or sad, I remembered when was the last time I felt hopeless or sad, and then I reflected what I tend to do feeling these emotions. Instead of showing what happened to you (with an animation, or a cutscene) the game lets you use your imagination! (To an extent.) This is how gaming was some time ago, in "the dark ages", like Zork!The characters are good as well. Ranging from your family, your loved one, and even a freind online. This game covers most friends that we have! The dialogue is good (at times), and it shows different personalities to each character, not some copy and paste/repeat characters.Another strong point is the sound, it's a repeating piano melody. However, sometimes you can hear some other noices reflecting to what the character your controlling is hearing, like noices from a party, or mellow talking when the character is in a therapy session. It's a small touch, but cool.Now some problems with the game:-No save feature. Like come on, I had to do something between a play session, and all my progress was lost! What a bummer!-The "Mood Meters". These meters found in the bottom of the screen tells you how depressed you are, how you feel on regards to therapy, and how you feel in regards to taking medication. This is okay, but it gave me dead giveaways to how the character felt. It would have been better if these wern't there so I needed to debunk on how the character is feeling. The main purpose that I got this game is was to find out what is wrong with the character, that's not the case in this game.-Ending. Now the ending, at first enraged me. However, when I read the epelogue, it made sense to me. However, I sort of wanted it to wrap up better than how it did.-Length. The game is shoooort. Even if you read every backstory in the beginning and you read eveything, you will see the ending in 30 minutes flat. Same with the ending. I wanted the story to go further, and to see the character change as time goes on. The game sort of stopped dead in it's tracks and says "The character is feeling better now". It kinda ruined the experince for me there.Overall, this game isn't ment to be played as a game, it's rather a simulation.I cannot recommend this game to everyone, becasue again it isn't a game, but I will say it's worth checking out. Hell, it's free to play. The only thing your spending is 30 minutes of your time.5/10

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												Frankly, I like the subject - I've had depression, and to keep it blunt, it sucks major♥♥♥♥♥♥ I found it interesting to read a story I could in some senses see comparisons to my own experience - which is no suprise considering that it's a medical condition attributable to a deficiency in dopamine and serotonin. Being neurotransmitters that regulate regions of your brain responsible for emotions, it's a simple step to say that across individuals a deficiency in these chemicals will cause a similar response. Considering that, I think at best I was able to get an 'I know that feel' and perhaps gave me an opportunity to look back on this experience, but these two things are aspects 'I' brought to the table. So what did Depression Quest bring to the table as a game?Well, for one it forgot to bring the game. I could go on a long tirade about what can and can't be considered a game, and honestly that area is muddy as all hell, subjective medium and all that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. However, what this is is an interative novel, and when I attempt to draw comparisons to other similar experiences I have had (something I just like to do when experiencing games) - I find myself looking at things like Goosebumps choose your own adventures stories - a book. There are plenty of places for interactive stories to be, and now that this is here on steam, knowing steam, it won't go now, but I just can't call this a game, and so on that level alone, I'm not recommending it - and opening myself to being called a huge hypocrite because I like Proteus, which is also ostensibly a game.The difference for me however remains on the subjective - I found Proteus interesting - this was not - it was just another story, and one which made me think more than anything else.Goosebumps was the♥♥♥♥♥♥

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												An incredibly offensive game implying that people suffering from depression are absolutely helpless; the removal of so many options and restricting the character to a meagre amount of actions, some that many depressed people would take if in that position, shows how little the writers understand about depression. The obvious ignorance about the disorder combined with the gall of the writers to pigeonhole an entire group of people and the absolute abhorrent use of the death of such a beloved public figure (Robin Williams) to plug their game is, frankly, disgusting. I would not recommend this game to anyone as it perpetuates societies ignorance and apathy towards mental illness whilst simultaneously offending and marginalising the victims of this cruel disorder. The only positive I can say is at least this filth has not been monetised and hopefully the proportion of negative reviews dissuades any one to play this game. I sincerely hope the creators regret publishing Depression Quest and in future refrain from hurting people. For individuals very enmeshed, get up yourselves.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												*WARNING, WARNING. WALL OF TEXT INBOUND. GAIN +5 DEPRESSION POINTS*Where to begin this review? My first impressions of Depression Quest were on its official site with a myrid of glitches in the hyperlinks. Thoughts "Oh, well it was an indie project trying to raise awareness for depression and taking donations to give to iFred and the Suicide Prevention Hotline." This soon faded from memory as a lackluster indie game with a good cause. Now recently seeing this game released on the free to play raised a little curiosity. Did they expand on the story of the game? Have those glitches in the website version been fixed? Disregarding reviews I downloaded the game today and played through ten to 15 minutes. First thought is that this all seems familiar. Same red lines blocking choices, same exact description, same hyperlinks, same everything. But wait, there is artsy piano music now to make it sad as you read. "Ok, so they haven't expanded the story or improved the look of the game". Next are the glitches encountered, for example crashing the application twice in a single playthrough. Finally getting through to an epilogue another realization kicks in that this is the exact same version of the game I played before it was released on steam. Nothing changed, nothing fixed, nothing brushed up. I'll rate here to avoid having people read a wall of text. 3/10. Onward to elaborationPlot: You play as 20 year old Michael McNoCharacterization. You have a decent job, loving family, loving girlfriend, good little social circle but you also have depression. A lack of motivation, disillusionment, and general angst ensue. The plot will railroad you, and railroad you hard, further into depression, more actions will be cut off from selection to simulate depression getting worse. The plot falls flat due to this in my honest opinion. Instead of giving us a reason to sympathise it gives us invisible -5s to happiness time an option is chosen.Mechanics: Simple pick option A get outcome A, pick option B get outcome B, with the occasional Pick Option A crash game.Soundtrack: Royalty free piano music to make things sad. Emotional manipulation at its finest.Fourth ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t listing: I hate ending on threes so here is a fourth detail, cannot pick this option. Raise depression points.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												After I played this game, I asked myself one question. "How did this get on steam?" I mean sure, visual novels are on steam as well, but at least those have art and actual soundtracks. Sure, they aren't free, but they're far more extensive and faaaaar less pretentious. I'm sorry, but this hardly deserves any of the publicity, interest, or credit it has recieved. If you had told me that this was a browser game, I wouldn't doubt you for a second. I've seen browser games that put more effort in. Bare graphics, some piano music, and overall poor and unrealistic writing.I can't say much on the game's subject. People I know with depression don't normally act in the way the character in this game supposedly acts, but that can be written off as coincidence. The word pretentious comes back because it simply feels like it's trying to be more than it actually is. These websites that reviewed it made it seem like something that would stun me and blow my mind with how thought-provoking it is. It wasn't. At all.Not to mention the recent controversy surrounding this game. I have some not so positive words surrounding the developer and her boy toy- er, friends (HINT: Pretentious is one of them).  Quite frankly, I don't want to say them because I'm horredously afraid of Phil Fish and his threating twitter tweets.  Needless to say, this isn't about her as much as the game. And the game sucks. It may be free, but it's a free waste of time you could be dedicating to contributing to society. Or playing actual video games. Both are more satisfying and significant.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 21, 2014
												Depression Quest is essentially a Choose Your Own Adventure book put into an electronic format. I wouldn't even go so far as to call it a visual novel, much less a game, because the pictures placed above the text don't add anything to the story. Basically, you play as "you", and you start out depressed. You have a bunch of first world problems going against you, and you have to manage all of these issues in order to get to the point where you're still depressed, but coping with it by the end of the story. I believe that the producer of this "game's" goal was to raise awareness for depression, but I don't think she really was able to do so. She made it seem much like the misconceptions that overpriviledged people who self-diagnose themselves were what depression really is, and it made the whole storyline seem a bit pretentious. I don't think it's really possible for anyone to get anything from this experience, because quite honestly, it didn't explain depression at all to those who don't have it, and only maybe convinced those with depression that it does help to get seek guidance and comfort from those who are close to you. And with all of this going against it, the producer couldn't even go through all the text walls to make sure there weren't any spelling or grammatical errors!Overall:Pros:-Shows those with depression that they aren't suffering aloneCons:-No gameplay-No visual aids-Not a correct depiction of depression-Grammatical/spelling errors all over the placeScores:Gameplay: 0/10Soundtrack: 1/10 (There was pretty much only one instrumental throughout the whole game)Style: 0/10Graphics: 0/10 Addictiveness: 0/10 Overall: 0/10

Posted: August 21, 2014

content:
Posted: September 4, 2014
												As someone who suffers from depression myself brought on by Bipolar, I played this game with an inside knowledge of what depression is legitimately like. Not only is this game NOT a game, but it's a TERRIBLE representation of what Depression is actually like. This game reinforces terrible stereotypes about people legitimately suffering from the disease, such as that we're never happy and all we do is wallow in our own misery 24/7 with no interest in getting better, seeking treatment or taking care of ourselves. It tells people that nothing ever makes us happy ever, not even temporarily, and that all we do is lie around unable to do anything.Sure, depression is brutal. Believe me I know. But this? This game is ridiculous. The only time I've ever been NEARLY as sick as the protagonist of this "story" was in my extreme lows where I was borderline suicidal. But it's harmful to people who ACTUALLY suffer from depression to reinforce these horrible stereotypes. Zoe claims she wants to help fight against the stigma but all she's done was add to it. This game is further proof to me that Zoe Quinn not only doesn't care about ANYTHING she claims she does (Women's rights, mental health, ect ect) but that she has no problems milking these things for all the money she can get. Sure the game is free but look at all the press she's gotten from other people who think this is a GREAT thing, people who (spoiler alert) more than likely don't have mental illnesses themselves and just think the sentiment is nice.Do not support this game. It's not even a game and were it not for Zoe's constant lying and harmful use of legitimate causes to gain for herself this game would NOT have made it onto steam, period. Steam sells games. This is not a game. And it CERTAINLY isn't an acurate depiction of what living with depression is like, nor is it sending out a positive message in any way, shape or form.

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												   This game gives a wrong idea of how depression truly is. It only talk about social anxiety and how difficult it is to accept yourself in a group, wich is sincerely, something really common these days.   The creator makes sure to make the game even more "depressing", removing the "healthy" option and making the other options completely unnecessary. All the options leaves you more depressed, and the game keep telling you this, even if you made the "right" decisions.    Plus, the long texts makes the game monotonus, also because the story doesn't lead you anywhere. The character gets more depressed and rejects any kind of help, doesn't matter if you choose it or not, and there's absolutely nothing you can do about it.

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
												As a 22 year old who has suffered depression as long as he can remember (as far back as age 5) I can attest to the accuracy of the main character's emotions in this story. The way the main character overthinks things, beats himself up over large and small mistakes alike, runs through possible scenarios in his head, only causing himself to worry more - I have experienced all of this. Also, too many times do I hear people telling me to "cheer up" or "get over it," but they just don't understand... it's not that easy - I don't want to be depressed, if it were just a mindset, I would have stopped being depressed long ago. Although many situations in this story I have not experienced (I've never had a girlfriend, or seen a therapist) I can still relate to how the main character feels throughout - the narrative is very thorough, and thus is very effective at portraying the situation, making it easy for me to put myself in his shoes. The choices are well varied, and I always found at least one option that I would do in that situation. After completing the game, I came to what seemed to me to be the best ending. Too bad it's just a game.By the way, it's funny how many bad reviews this game got by people who aren't depressed, saying, "it's not realistic" when they are the target audience, and yet, a depressed person writing a review gave a positive one saying that it is realistic.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												I don't really know what to say, it's a basic choose your own ending story. I've had depression problems since I was in high school and the narrative was always always skewed negatively. I do realize this is intentional to make you feel more hopeless, but not necessary in my opinion. The story was a simple short story, not bad, not astounding but you get the idea. I came here to check out this game because all of the journalism craze going on and its not as good as the critics were saying more like a student project in college for a game design class. I don't expect triple A results or anything from this but it's not a professional game. If journalists were really skewed over this game screw that. I mean its a good student project but it is by no means a masterpiece. So play it yourself if you like story based games. not bad for a student game but not fantastic for a student game either. like 3/10 4/10

number of helpful: 9 of 16 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
												As an actual depression sufferer, I felt a morbid curiosity to see for myself what the deal is with this. I am going to set aside the controversy surrounding the game and focus on the game itself.I am not sure exactly what Zoe Quinn thinks depression entails, but it is not simply a series of "I don't feel like it" moments. What is portrayed in this game, if you can really call it that, seems like an eight-minute commercial for Prozac that pushes the "Hollywood Angle" on the subject. Depicting anyone who is withdrawn and unhappy with their life as automatically depressed and stating they must be rushed to therapy and put on meds. The mood is punctuated by a rote series of piano codas designed to make the viewer sad and sympathetic, but quickly become annoying. If anything this is almost feels like a poorly-written tearjerker script for a Lifetime movie than any accurate depiction of how depression affects a person and those around them.I almost feel like the game isn't about depression in general. Instead I'm left with the impression that Zoe Quinn created this visual novel, again if you can really call it that, to engender sympathy because she went through a rough patch for several months. I suppose that in and of itself is not a problem, but if it's all about you then just say it's about you. Don't try to speak for all depression suffers, because depression is not one-size fits all.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
												This is a game? Hahaha, oh wow In all seriousness it's a interactive story about some random guy and his depression and you have to direct his actions via multiple choice outcomes. You could probably speed play through it in 1 minute; there's not that much of a story to it. It's not really that much of a game. Maybe it could've been considered one back in the 80s or 90s when they had those interactive text based ones, but even those usually were a lot longer than this and more interesting as well.Now I don't like to use Ad hominems but the broad who made this, Zoe Qunin, didn't even make it directly. She got help from some game makers who were doing a project where they'd help inexperienced women make games. After they helped her make this, she attacked them! Also, after Robin Williams took his life (rest in piece, you were one of the few celebrities I actually felt horrible from after they died) she tried to cash in on that to promote her game more. So she also has no respect for victims of suicide. There's been a massive storm of controversy over her actions, and a lot of censoring of facts and freedom of speech. So I encourage you, the audience, not to support her. Depression is a hellish sickness of the mind that nobody should experience. I can appreciate trying to find ways to make people understand it much better, but this 'game' is an inefficient way off doing so, and it's creator is shrouded in controversy. I cannot recommend this game. Thankfully, it is free, so I didn't waste a dime.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												I usually play FPS games, so this was a bit of a departure for me. This game is text based and doesn't take long to 'complete', but what it is lacking in graphical sophistication and hours of gameplay it makes up for in emotional depth. I played it through many times in a row because I cared about getting the best outcome for the protagonist. Great value for money considering it didn't cost me anything! If you want to learn a bit more about yourself, about the impact that depression has on a person and how to combat it, then give this game half an hour of your time. I have spent plenty of hours grinding on MMPORGs or clearing screens of coloured blobs on my mobile device, but I got more out of ten minutes of this than I though was possible for a game. Recommended!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 19, 2014
												Boring, uninspired, and a bit condescending. Depression Quest isn't a game so much as a 'choose your own adventure' book in a digital format. Unfortunately, it doesn't even do that well. The story is plagued by long, boring, and bland writing. That's unfortunate because the writing is really all you see. There aren't much in the way of visuals, and navigation feels more like navigating an awkward web page than moving through a story. It tries to ram into your head that your 'character' is depressed, but it doesn't personalize the character enough to make you feel sorry for them, nor does the awkward writing make it easy to sit through all of the story. Most of the actions you choose also tend to railroad you in one single direction. It gives the illusion of variation where the reality is that it is severely lacking in that department.Overall, I do not recommend this game. I can't even begin to give this a score because it's not really a game, and even the experience it means to give you fails so horribly that trying to give it a */10 score is like trying to score a trainwreck.

												Out of curiosity, I decided to give this game a try. I now wish I hadn't.This game is hard for me to review because there's so little to review. This "game" can barely be called a game. This game doesn't even have that.Generic piano music plays throughout. I'm guessing this is supposed to make the game feel more sad, but it just sounds annoying to me.The story itself is dull and boring. It's impossible for me to relate to the main character. None of your decisions feel like they have any major impact. Nothing truly bad happens to the main character that makes me want to sympathize with him. It just slogs on and on before reaching one of many anticlimactic, unsatisfying conclusions.Depression Quest is the laziest excuse for a game I have ever played. Anyone can make a text-based adventure game. Anyone. You could program a game just like this in flash in ten minutes. This isn't even Newgrounds quality. The only reason this got put on Steam is because the author has a ♥♥♥♥♥♥. That's it. I bet you that if this game were called Ice Cream Quest, it would have never been put on Steam.This "game" is a waste of time. You're better off just reading a book.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 3, 2014
												This is, hands down, the worst "gaming" experience of my life. If you can call this a game. It is basically a “chose your own adventure” novel that people read when they were kids. Some parts are well written in terms of style, but not content. It’s not fun, it’s not informative. It’s a complete waste of time and I highly suggest that you not waste your time on it like I, unfortunately, did.As someone who suffers from serious depression, and other depression-related disorders (e.g. anxiety), I found this game to be massively offensive and miss the mark by far. This game will not raise awareness or increase understanding. All it does is reinforce depression stereotypes. Whoever made this game has no idea what it means to be clinically depressed and have a $#!tty lot in life. The creators have reduced the deep and personal struggle I face every day of my life to a few clicks of a button, in a highly unrealistic scenario, and somehow this is supposed to be helping people? You’re only lying to yourself if you think anyone is being helped by this “game.”tl;dr: This –thing- is a complete waste of time and needs to be taken off steam.

content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
												Note: Before anyone goes and starts a flame, keep in mind this is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ review, and I feel like I need to get the point across that this game does NOTHING to address actual depression.Long story short, I don't recommend. Not because it isn't actually a game, but for the tremendously unrealistic portrait of a depressed person. To put it bluntly, this does not seem like a depressed individual who you control in the story, but a socially awkward, self-loathing, well, ♥♥♥♥♥. I don't mean to say people with depression are♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥because they aren't, don't put those words in my mouth. I'm saying that this guy, who has a girlfriend who loves him; a job that, in spite of his hatred of it, pays well enough for him to be comfortable; a family that loves and cares about him, and who constantly are trying to help and support him through it; and a ♥♥♥♥ING KITTEN (No, I'm not kidding) manages to still just be a mope about everything. Thats not depression my friend, thats called a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ attitude. Which is ok, I have a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ attitude towards most things. But the point is, the main character is a tremendous ♥♥♥♥♥. And the people who suffer from depression related to a.)substance abuse b.)abuse in general or c.)real, actual problems in their lives that create stress are amazing people for sticking it out and I suggest they seek help etc. But if you have a girlfriend, loving family, a supporting job that gets you by, and a KITTEN, thats a ♥♥♥♥♥♥, rotten attitude you got there friend. Should be called "♥♥♥♥♥♥ Attitude Quest"0.5/10(I gave it .5 points because I have a soft spot for kittens.)

content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												The question you propably have if you haven't played this propably is: ''is this game good?''. Here is a better one: ''is this a game?'' The answer to both questions is no IMO. Why? Cause it is just a mediocre book. There is no gameplay and no graphics. There is no reason to play it over so many wonderful free games on steam. Let me cut this game apart in steps.1: No gameplay: Gameplay makes a game, and this one does not even have incomplete controls. It is just a book with some options, there is no gameplay that keeps you excited. It is just not there.2: The story is stupid: Who makes a game about a girl who is despressed and you need to help her get rid of that depression. To me, that is not a good idea for a game (but this is not a game anyway). For a game that tries to sell itself as immersive, the poor writing and the long walls of uninteresting text just make me want to skip it all. 3: It is not fun: I know that at the beginning it says that ''it is not meant to be fun'', but fun is the thing that makes a game good for me. Even technically bad games will be liked by me if they have a good fun factor. But this one does not even try, and it is not hard to see. It is so boring, its only use would be as a tool to help you sleep. If you want to read a book, THEN READ A F*CKING BOOK. 4: The developer: This is a thing that keeps coming to my mind when i think about this 'game'. You see all of those reviews saying it is a great game? Well the 'game' itself did not do anything to create these positive reviews. Rather the developer had sex with the reviewers and they had to pay her in a good review for her game, i am not kidding.... look here:  


YouTube™ Video:  

			Views: 0		



 all credit to InternetAristocrat for making it. It is just stupid, and also why the reviews are lies. Developer Zoe Quinn....... you should be ashamed of yourself. Those are mayor reasons why this is not a good game, or a game for that matter. There are many good and free games, please do not waste time on this one. And you may call me a hypocrite for wasting 7 minutes on it (it felt much longer), but now i experienced it and i want no more..... ever. The End.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
												I'm sad that Five Guys Burgers and Fries was tied to this. They didn't ask for this.Though on the game here's what I think:I won't go on about how the text is uninteresting, etc. or that your  options are always left and right,  even though the door on the left is a hallway to the right.The game was so unengaging, that you don't have to worry about being called a sociopath if you didn't care about what happened to the character. A man in the prime of his life, with a girlfriend, friends, a job, and his own place. That's a lot more than I have, and I'm not complaining with what I do, So why's this guy upset? I guess what I'm trying to say is: This guy has no reason to complain, he's got a mate and lads to hang out with, a job, etc. so what's his deal? The thing with depression is: There's always some sort of underlying cause, and one is never given in the game. How do I sympathize with someone who hasn't a tale to his struggle? There's no sign of social distress, or infidelity (Which would be ironic in a Zoey Quinn game) no past history to go off of to see that the character has a reason to be depressed. And that's the thing: He doesn't. You quickly realize that the character is unsuitable to represent depression, or at least a common form. The Developer's chosen the MOST UNLIKELY SCENARIO to give someone depression, and that's why I can't feel a connection.There's more I'd say, but I've decided to refrain.TL;DR? Succinctly: It's kind of like a mid-life crisis ten+ years too early.

content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
												Its a fast food joint that serves up burgers-- so don't expect a "5-star" restaurant, just expect a damn good burger served up the way it should be done. Also, if you've been to a 5 Guys, you know what you're getting here, this is pretty run of the mill. All that said, I love this place probably more than I should. And there's a couple reasons for that....Its fast food, but its cooked to order. This isn't like those other fast food places where you place your order and its ready in 60 seconds. Place your order and grab some free peanuts while you wait for everything to be prepared fresh and to-order. Free peanuts! Don't want to spring for fries? Fill up on these little guys instead.The burger itself. I know its not very good for me, but I love these patties, covered in gooey cheese and crispy bacon, topped with whatever I ask for. And the fries. Sometimes over salted, they're cooked nice and crispy and delicious. And they're tossed into the bag, overflowing from their container. If you're not stuffed after a burger and an order of these guys, you're inhuman. All in all, if you set your expectations right and are looking for a good but not so good-for-you fast food meal, you'll have a hard time finding something better than this 5 Guys.

content:
Posted: April 17
												Firstly, if you are having mental health issues similar to the ones depicted in this game, please seek help. Even if it seems like you're being dramatic or making a big deal of a situation, talk to someone at the very least. Many of the negatice reviews are simply from other steam users who wantes to enjoy a free to play text based game. However this doesn't necessarily belong on the same page as team fortress 2 as it's not a game. It's more of a short story providing the 'player' with simplistic choices to conquer a situation where that situation has no satisfying conclusion. It's not an enjoyable 'game' by any means, it's sole purpose is to educate people about mental illness.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2014
												It had hyperlinks. It had too much reading. And I didn't understand the concept of this "game" at all. I don't think this is even called a game because it was done terrifying. I thought you had to get out the the depression, but instead it twists around, and makes you even more so depressed. This was also the shortest hyperlink clicking object thing ever. 25 mins I think. Yes I am a girl so I am not trying to be sexist. Being bullied online you just have to block and report them. I couldn't tell if I were a guy or a girl at all as my character. Then again I got bored of reading millions of paragraphs per page. If you wanna read about depression make a book instead of a game. For some weird reason this game made me play webkinz again... There is something mentally and physically wrong with the publisher of the game. Zoe Quin wasn't it?        This quote: “Depression Quest hinges on its deeply personal writing style. It feels as though you’re reading someone’s unfiltered mental diary. Depression Quest is uncomfortable in that it feels voyeuristic, but the cramped proximity is how you develop a relationship with the character. It’s why, by the end, I was able to say I understood depression a bit better. It's a window.” By-Giant Bomb Was not a smart quote I would say. By the end of the game to me I didn't understand depression at all. It wasn't in first person at all it was in second or third person view. Reading a diary? I just said it was in second or third person view. I didn't develop a relationship with the character at all.    This quote also: “Besides the blues-ridden story, it's just a well-made game overall. It's excellently written, well-paced, and so engaging that you might just find yourself playing again to find out what might happen” By-GameSpy Well, let me just say this, it's too slow. Yea I played it kinda fast cuz I got bored or reading the paragraphs, but how the story builded up was too slow. It didn't have a climax, lowering action, and cliffhangers. It was just one straight line. Yea when it comes to games I don't reccomend I have like a really long paragraph.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												Just a day off of school and I scroll through this, and pick it up because I have nothing better to do.I played through it, answering honest and what is best, and I got a generally good ending.The game is just a story, nothing mechanical other than clicking and making games. Even though it might not be considered a game we all know and love, it is more of a novel or a little story, like a webpage comic or something. So if you were expecting a game, this might disappoint you. Steer away from this if you just want gameplay.A person like me loves a story, and this game did well to portrait realism and a guy genuinely going through life choices that we are all destined towards to, experiencing depression and emotionall/physical exhaustion. The choices in this game chilled my spine just thinking what would happen if I clicked it. Also, there is a nice feature, which if you are depressed in a level, it won't let you make the choice, further adding realism. You can't expect a morbidly depressed guy to suddenly go up to people and say "Hey guys, hows the weather".The "characters" did well in their role, adding a sense to the story, etheir adding emotional support if you choose the accept it. "The music adds to the surreal atmosphere, although I put off my headphones because I don't want to feel chillsOverall, if you like stories, go with this. If you like choice-making, go with this. Otherwise, I would steer away from it because it's not an actual game.( I do like the awareness spread with this.)

												Before I start this review, I just want to ask one thing: Me and the bae want to guy out to eat tonight, does anyone suggest anything? I've heard Five Guys is pretty good.Now that we've got that out of the way, let's talk about the actual "game" itself. It isn't one. It's a "visual novel" and I use that word as loose as Zoe Quinn apparently is.This game has Tumblr written all over it; it's almost funny to me. It's pretty much the equivalent of some SJW trying to be deep and poetic, trying to make something that's "groundbreaking" or some stupid♥♥♥♥♥♥like that. It's essentially about a guy who didn't get an extra hour in the ball-pit at Dashcon, and now he's an over-emotional crybaby who can't get out of his own ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.One thing that actually made me laugh: the music. It's some somber piano track that trys to force the "sad" feeling of the game, but is about as emotional as Yung Lean. This "game" is so pretentious that it's not even funny.My final conclusion: The one thing I don't understand is: Why would you cheat on your boyfriend with "le five guys xd" to get such a stupid game greenlighted? If you're gonna sleep your way to the top, at least make a game that shows for your work; not some tl;dr HTML crap.5 McLovin's out of 5. One for the burger, two for the fries (because Five Guys give you a lot of fries), one for the drink, and one for the overall atmosphere of the restauraunt.0 privilege-checking McLovin's for "Pretentious Quest".

Posted: January 4, 2016
												This game is remarkably accurate. I suffer from a small bit of depression, and have felt many of these things. Thankfully it has not gotten to the point where I couldn't get out of bed. However, "games" like these help; let's me know that there are people who understand enough to try to enlighten others on the struggle. I'll be honest, while there weren't triggers for me, I did tear up a couple of times.So, to end, the "game" is worth a look see. It's not just a comfort to those of us with depression, but a learning experience for those without who think that people can "just cheer up". Thank you, kudos, and keep up the good work.

content:
Posted: August 30, 2014
												If you are unfamiliar with depression, or know someone suffering with depression, play this to get an idea of how they may feel and how hard it is for them to do certain kinds of things. I love seeing unique experiences on Steam. My hat goes off to the developer for releasing the game free to reach as many as possible. Depression Quest is an interactive text novel  where you read real-life examples of how someone with depression feels and then try to select the best answer for him. Depending on how depressed your character currently is some answers are crossed out/unavailable such as "Hunker down and get to work". This helps those unfamiliar with depression to get an idea of how debilitating depression is.You can tell a lot of time and attention to detail has been put into this game. The music changes to match how your choices are affecting the characters depression and the graphics on each story page also change.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2014
												From a person with clinical depression i found myself able to relate with how the main character was feeling, like waking up some days and just not wanting to get up because you feel so bad or telling people everything is okay when really you are falling apart. I had read some reviews prior to playing and i realized once again how immature and stupid people can be and those of you who posted those stupid comments i hope yall grow up one day. To the developers, i actually enjoyed the game and its mechanics, how ever i didnt understand why i couldnt choose some of the choices and at first had no idea what was going on, as i progressed i learned i was playing a 20 something year old and was male but i would have been nice to know those details alittle sooner. I enjoyed the happy ending as well, how he ended up saying that for once he was good. like i mentioned before i suffered with clinical depression since i was 11 years old and even now into my 20s but as life has gone on it has only gotten better but its still hard some days and i think the developers hit the nail on the head with the way some people with depression feel, it wasnt perfect but i feel they accomplished what they said the object of the game was and i really enjoyed seeing the main character end up happy. I hope yall continue to make more games i would like to see them. Goodluck:)

number of helpful: 7 of 13 people (54%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
												I like the set up of this game and its very cool you have several possible responses to choose from in each event of this person's life your in charge of living. Of course every decision later affects future decisions.The more positive the decision, the more positive the responses usually be. Likewise the opposite can happen as well, when your character becomes more depressed. The one ordeal I'm trying to figure out, if its even possible is being able to almost choose the top positive expression. I do feel though that's just there to show what he'd choose if he was mentally capable to at the current moment(most of the time if chosen right it might become available) and not so deeply affected by his depression.Regardless though playing this game helped me realize(or rememebr more clearly/understand) quite a bit about myself since I used to feel some aspects of depression after some events in my life occurred and I thought I couldn't be happy after them. I did figure out a way to get past them and got rid of habits, some mentioned here such as going to bed at a healthy time and helping others. A lot of this is real life and can happen to any of us. Depression hits you randomly but you gotta be strong enough to break from it. Granted its hard but encouraging yourself and others can do a lot of good to help those feelings melt away.I would recommend a friend to play this at least a few times if you enjoy real life themed games cause this one is written pretty well for how generic it might seem to be layed out. I like the visual/in game sounds that add to the emotion your reading about. Your mind surely does draw a lot of metal pictures to all you end up reading, maybe even envisioning yourself in the situations/or recurring similar ones.

number of helpful: 7 of 13 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2015
												I cannot in good conscious recommend this game for any reason, and I took notes as to why, huzzah! This review will be slightly nit-picky and slightly spoiler-ridden, but no one who reads this is really going to care about that.Starting off with the very first line of this story we have this: "You are a 20-something human being". Okay, cool. But yet it reads that your significant other is named "Alex", again, not a huge deal until you realize that Alex is a female, meaning the only two demographics of "human being" that the author recognizes are heterosexual men and homosexual women. If you are a heterosexual female or a homosexual man, tough cookies hombre! I mean, why even include this if it's so obvious that this story is about a female and her experience with "depression"? to make people feel included? great job there! you couldn't even include a sexuality slider somewhere? And let's talk about the protagonist here: over the course of the story she is clearly socially awkward with what seems to me to be a rather average case of ADD.Throughout the pages of the story you will see notifications about her depression level, and the lowest I could get it to was "mildly depressed" However, knowing what clinically describes depression and how depression actually feels like are two wholly different beasts entirely. Honestly in my opinion this person was just fed up with their awful job at kinkos or fedex, or where-ever and simply wasn't cut out for customer service. Hey, I get that some people aren't meant for that sort of job! But I don't care HOW depressed you are, you are NEVER too depressed to order a pizza over the phone, or most likely over the internet. Heck, I'm almost willing to bet that because of a bad mood you might get extra toppings on it, maybe get some sort of dessert, too!Returning to your depression however, lets take a closer look at what you claimed to have done in order to calm your mind, shall well? Netflix. video games. playing with your cat with a laser pointer, browsing social media.. never at any point while reading through this whatever-it-is did you once make a reference to, or make any attempt to do some sort of physical activity for the purpose of stress-relief. A sedentary lifestyle, which the protagonist seems to have displayed throughout this story leads me to believe that they were not in fact depressed, but simply bored. This lack of physical activity in the protagonist's de-stressing routine may have led to additional stresses, such as an inability to deal with others and making one become quick to anger. (Which really isn't helped by the cliche nosy mother character you seem to have.) It could also explain the complete lack of progress on this "secret project" they keep whispering about. Though maybe this motherly issue is somehow related to the fact that the protagonist very well may have lead a rather sheltered life up until leaving the nest and the mother is simply putting on a harsher front to help toughen her up. In either case the protagonist is overly sensitive to perceived threats and probably needs trigger warnings when watching the news.If all of this wasn't enough the protagonist is also quite paranoid, not to the point of delusion really, but every single thing is like "oh geez, oh man! what if! aaaarg!"  And ya know what? this protagonist needs a good slap in the back of the head, NCIS style. Not everything is a personal attack, not everything is a slight against you, In fact most people on earth have some of these effects simply due to aging. Yes, even an inability to sleep.So, is the protagonist in this story depressed at any point? I believe the other reviews will answer that question nicely. See what I did there? you and your awful ending.. feh! this whole thing was just absolutely infuriating.

												It's a game. Thats the only real positive thing I can say about it. As far as a simulator goes it is very poorly designed and written out. The right and wrong choices are painfully obvious so theres no real trial and error to play. Besides that the choices that would actually help you get out of depression are all blocked, as if everyone with depression has zero mental willpower to try and help themselves. Overall my experience with this game has been very depressing indeed, the biggest letdown was the fact there was no suicidal option on the panels, as well as the fact the piano music was driving me insane to the point I had to turn off my speakers and risk not hearing the inevitable gunshot. I would not recommend this game as one to play seriously, but more as to show friends how bad it is.

number of helpful: 7 of 13 people (54%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 9, 2015
												I see a lot of reviews talking about how Depression Quest isn't a fun game, and at least one review saying that the game reduces the serious subject of clinical depression to being a whiny ♥♥♥♥♥.To be honest, you should play the game. I finished it in 55 minutes, and I see a lot of the reviews played for a lot less time than that - to beat the game that much faster, you'd have to avoid reading which eliminates the point of playing a text-based game or you'd have to flake out part of the way through and write a review without fully understanding the subject of your own review, IE talking out of your♥♥♥♥♥This is not a fun game. If you've ever played Spec Ops: The Line or This War Of Mine, its one of those. This is a game expressly created to address the issue of depression in an interactive format. I'll get the gaming stuff out of the way first.Fun: 0/10Reactivity: 10/10Effort: 1010Graphics: 1/10Gameplay: 1/10Story: 7/10This is not a fun game. It was never meant to be fun, or feel like a heroic journey against impossible odds. This is a game designed to take the experience of being depressed, of feeling like you're a worthless piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥and nothing you do matters, and present that in a format where people who aren't depressed might understand. Since we've established that Depression Quest has little to no value purely as a video game, how does it meet that design goal?Based on my personal experience with the game, I'd say it does. It presents the feeling of being depressed in the long post-process paragraphs after you make decisions which your character reflects on. I'm not gonna lie - you're going to need to have a basic understanding of human empathy and need to be paying attention to read through the lines and see the emotions rolling around in the character. That said, that'd also be true if you were speaking with a person who is depressed and trying to open up to you.I can't believe I'm saying this, but somehow a free game about the experience of depression is controversial, as established by this game's history as kicking off the GamerGate lunacy. But as a simple unbiased player, I find this game unfun and a step to the side compared to what I normally go to video games for. However, that's the exact design goal of this game, and I feel it succeeds in what it was trying to do. Even the controversy can be interpreted as success, since more often than not depression in my society (USA) is interpreted as being a whiny ♥♥♥♥♥ who won't take responsibility for themself.As an experience, I give this game an 8/10, and I would recommend every gamer play this at least once.

He's got more than many people who don't mope and ♥♥♥♥♥ about their life. Then, when he gets to doing something about his problem, it takes half a year to get it under control; Damn that's fast!      Looking at the posted official reviews on their Steam page, I see three gaming sites whose word I will never trust. Not just the game is unpleasant though, the developers are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. I dared to make a snarky discussion post and it took about an hour for them to ban my discussion. They are actively censoring criticism where they can, and I'll probably be accused of being a mysoginist for saying this game sucks.      Also, a lot of the other reviews are making me hungry, I'm going to Five Guys.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												This "game" felt real to me. Depression Quest is very upfront about its intentions and what it is. This collection of choose your own story narratives is the result of a few people and their friends/family who experienced depression using their collective experience to tell a story. It isn't the story of every depressed person at all, no matter how many variations you try to go through, but from what is there, you can get an idea of what it is like for some people.They clearly say this and I'll repeat it. This is not meant to be fun. This isn't an enjoyable game. If you yourself are or have been depressed then you may not want to play this. It gives you a vague idea of how someone suffering might not be able to act in certain ways, and the resulting feelings they are experiencing when they make a choice.Going through this, making choices that I would see myself making years ago, I could relate to the narrative that was told as a result. For this reason I think this is an alright way to try to vaguely understand how someone with depression might be feeling.This is just my advice. I do not recommend choosing the "right" responses based on what you know to be the best course of action. Try choosing options that are maybe a little isolated from people. Avoid what might be considered uncomfortable for an introverted person. Don't try to act like a healthy person if you're playing it to try to understand someone who isn't.And don't play this for fun. It's hardly a "game". It's an interactive story.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
												Due to a medical problem, I've been for some years in a perpetual dark place before it got treated: guess what? That problem, messing around with hormones, can make you slip in a depression.What Depression Quest was describing was what I've lived. So, yeah, it struck a cord.While I don't think it will cure you or help to put the disease behind, I do think that the game can open eyes for some people (depressed or not).You're in the shoes of a man, getting depressed each day a little more. As it's a choose-your-own-story type of game, you choose the option that will suit you better. Sometimes, the results are not what you expected. These choices will have an impact on your job, on your relationship and on your family. In the end, or you fight the disease or you let yourself getting into a darker pit.As I've said, it struck a cord in myself.
