content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
												This is definitely not a happy game, but for those who have depression, it really hits home. Several times I couldn't help but see the parallels between the narrator's thoughts and mine. Just like the game does, I'll have to warn those with severe depression that some moments could possibly be triggering. Just like real life, Depression Quest doesn't really have an ending, more of a reflection of the choices you made and the people you reached out to. Yes, some endings are more hopeful than others, but overall, I think Depression Quest did a great job of getting inside the head of someone who is stuck in an endless cycle, not sure how to get out. However, it also teaches you that while you may not make a lot of money or save the world, sometimes it's the little things that make life worthwhile.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 1, 2016
												I saw the many negative reviews, read some of them, and knew what was going on.The fact that there are so many negative reviews is indicative of the very thing that is one major cause of depression. Things like complaining that not all reaction options are available or criticizing an allegedly clichée or cheesy or pretentious writing or how the music is dull and repetitive shows a horrifying lack of empathy, a refusal to see and experience a situation from someone else's viewpoint or to even look at it; upset of not being handed an I-win-button, annoyed by discomfort, by the game tucking at things suppressed in the psyche.I suspect that at least some of the negative reviewers who claim they have been through depression themselves and this game is no good for portraying that have merely been 'successfully' conditioned into dealing with an uncaring world by becoming more uncaring themselves. Because if you can't stand the pain anymore, you have to become the pain. But everybody just becoming as egotistical as the society that affects them is not a solution, but the very expression of the problem.The general emotional experience of the player character I can relate to a lot, while many situational elements not, but that doesn't matter. This game is art in that it conveys an experience to the player, so I guess it is only natural that all those who are fueling the problem will not like it. This game is like an enactment, through showing the mirror and making people attack their projection or focus on evasion points.Its high negative review ratio is like a representative for the emotional distance and uncaring that depressed people might have to deal with every day.It was easy for me to come to a very positive outcome, just by choosing what I would have chosen in a real situation, not even the supposedly strongest, ideal decisions (if there even is one, because everything has up- and downsides). The player character is relatively lucky. Other people might not have any of the potentially positive influences available to tap into. For them it might be a losing game from the start. Unless we change that.If the negative critique points mentioned are your grievances, too, then take that as a sign that you are not helping with your current mindset. And maybe I shouldn't even say mindset, because as this game conveys quite well, the mind alone cannot solve problems of the heart. It is caring and the will to make an effort for a better world, to accept inconveniences based on empathy for others, that solves such problems. And that requires a certain amount of courage. Not so much the kind of courage that makes the warrior wield a sword against a foe, but the kind that makes him cut out a parasite from his own body.https://twitter.com/Dowlphin/status/704736089823645703All the mind can do is square the circle, but it can never remove the sharp edges that cause injury.https://twitter.com/Dowlphin/status/701880481181208578True caring hurts.That's why it's unpopular.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2015
												In reading the reviews for this game i believe that most of these people are misssing the point so im going to adress all of these as i go.First thing i have seen alot of was that all the good choices where crossed out... ofcourse they are. when you live with depression doing something as simple as getting out of bed can be difficult  so ofcourse you cant do certain things.. your depression wont allow you to do them.Secondly there where alot of complaints about the music and the dullness of design... this is also themeing... when you live with depression for long enough things do begin to dull but you dont notice it it hapens slowly over time in little ways, and then when you are finally free from the beast of depression everything else seems so much more vibrant. i feel like the devs where attempting to maintain that dull feellastly ive seen alot of reviews claiming that this isnt a game... lets start with the definition of a video game. a game played by electronically manipulating images produced by a computer program on a television screen or other display screen. DepressionQuest seems to fit the bill alright. and i know that its not funny or fun, but its not meant to be. its honest, its an expression its art in a way which is something that gamers have been trying to claim that video games are formore than half a decade. and personally this game hit home for me.. i was diagnosed with major depressive disorder a year ago, but my therapist beives that i developed depression for the first time when i was 13, thats 7 years of my life i spent fighting just to do mundane things and thinking i was crazy because they were so difficult for me to acomplish. 1 in 3 people in the world have depression most of them dont even know they have it. just think about all the people  that can be helped by simply playing this game and realizing that they arnt crazy there are other people out there who have the exact same problem.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2014
												This is as much a game as other non-AAA and non-mainstream games are. A close analog I can think of would probably be the Stanley Parable which, for all its 1st POV and GUI and mouse, pretty much is a "Choose-Your-Own-Adventure Book" but in 3D. DQ hearkens back to earlier-era text-based games. It's no surprise that the game's epigraph come from David Foster Wallace, who crafted in boredom and addiction and depression as much as Pynchon does paranoia, as the closest prose relation (as well as most probable genesis) is his short story "The Depressed Person". My one criticism is actually a rather common one when it comes to western RPGs as well as love songs (not to mention Bella Swan in Twilight): by making the protagonist's circumstances and personality so general, you'e actually making them less universal. Providing specficity is what creates resonance, as specificity provides more opportunity for empathy. Largely, though, due to the nature of the game and the fact that you are making the choices, you're able to tailor the 2nd person POV so it can be more like a mirror and you can be the one whose actually making these decisions. I felt immersed in this than I ever did Fallout 3, and in a fraction of the time too.Overall, an amazing game that everyone ought to play.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												This is an impartial review of this game.  I'm aware of the Zoe Quinn Scandal and the bad publicity of this game, however, I wanted to try it on my own with as unbiased a few as possible.  First and foremost, this is certainly not a game by any means and should be treated more as a depression simulation and should be provided to those suffering with depression to share with those around them.  Though the game fails to provide any catalyst to explain the depression or to allow the player to empathize with the character, all of the activities, layouts, choices, and mindsets clearly depict depression as intended.  On this front, the "game" achieves what it intended to do.  Since it is free of charge, this depression sim should be recommended to anyone who knows someone suffering with depression.  Even if you hate Zoe Quinn for the scandal or want to blast this for not being a true game, think of the message of depression and the stigma it can help alleviate to help people.Pros:-Accurately depicts depression symptoms, feelings, actions, restrictions etc...-Will accurately explain depression to someone who hasn't experienced it-Spreads awareness of what true depression is and helps alleviate stigma of mental illness-Costs nothingCons:-Just like Coming Home, this isn't a game-The player will only relate to the character if they are within the range of late teens through twenties, limiting audience-There is no explanation for the depression, making the character appear to be a whiny privileged person with first world problems-Anyone unaware that this is essentially a depression sim read-along may be in for disappointment

content:
Posted: January 11, 2016
												The game makes a very important point at the end: there is not a "true" end to depression, as it is something that just happens and you can't plan it. There is so much stigma and ignorance against mental illness and I find that the game portrayed it very well, as well as the feelings of desperation, self loathing, mind feeling numb and blank all the time, and making those little efforts that although they are absolutely important to someone with a disorder, it feels like we did nothing. I found the game particularly real and it felt like reading the diary of someone that actually feels the way I do. The scratched out choices, who were like "the best choices for yourself" were scratched out and that makes a powerful statement: you can't just shake off depression or any other disorder, because it is  a chemical imbalance in the brain, an illness, no different than any other and it consumes you slowly.I hope Zoe Quinn will still produce beautiful content like this in the future.

content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
												*sigh*  SO like some of you and a lot of who didn't.  I have(do?) suffered with depression.This game brought tears to my eyes as I relived thoughts in my head of times past.  At this point, I have recently broken up with my girlfriend and I fear that I did that because of how she was feeling when she was depressed, especially after reading this.  I may have fractured a relationship forever because of my own insecurities and fears.The phone number of the therapist in the game was an actual phone number to a Toronto based therapist (I assume it works based on IP, or the creator(s) are Canadian).  I am strongly considering calling them as a result of what has happened.While I agree with a previous commenter that the protagonist has a much better life than some, sometimes depression hits you the worst when you are in the middle of an upswing (have a sig. other, job, etc.) like it apparently did me.To anyone who feels down and depressed.  Do yourself a favour, no matter how bad things may feel, talk to someone, anyone that may have an inkling of giving a damn about you.  If that doesn't work, call a suicide hotline and tell them you want to get in touch with a local therapist.Anyone who is depressed can be brought back from that.  Anyone who wants things to change, has the power to change them.  You are your own worst enemy and your own best friend.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
												Depression Quest, the game that shattered the gaming community due to alleged journalistic bias going to this game regarding her being in a relationship with the journalists.  While I cannot confirm this nor care enough to, Depression Quest is an interesting experience.  For those who don't know what it's like to have the frustration of clinical depression, this game does do a good job trying to explain it.  You really do feel for the main character who just doesn't know what to do.  I especially like the design choice of X-ing out one of the dialogue options that you or me would choose but  not someone with clinical depression.  Now it is a text based adventure and I did finish the game in under an hour.  There are different routes you can take the story like try to get professional help or keep it all bottled inside.  I did get the best ending where my character is getting help and told his girlfriend about it.  It's not exactly a happy ending, but that's how it is for some people struggling with clinical depression.  I highly recommend playing through this game once.  I am glad that it's free on Steam as even asking for a dollar is kind of a little overpriced for a one-and-done game.   I don't even have this installed in my computer anymore.  But it's free so check it out.  It's not really a game, but more of an experiece.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												I see in other reviews that there is a lot of negativity surrounding this game. Although this game is incredibly simple with no gameplay elements nor entertainment value, I believe that there is something integral that people can take away from this. Depression Quest provides a very interesting perspective that allows one to truly understand the concequences and repercussions of depression through decently well-writen and introspective narrative and exposition.I strongly believe that this game is definitely not for the majority of people who are looking for entertainment and in general; a fun time.( which this game totally does not offer ). However, it does provide an insight about depression that is captivating if you are open-minded enough to get engrossed and invested in the characters in the story. It gives you this feeling of helplessness and despair that is truly unmatched by any game I've played.There is something i would also like the clarify, which is that this game is NOT for people suffering from depression, but rather people that are living normal/happy lives and make them truly understand and empathize for the people who are actually suffering from depression; exemplifying the helplessness and solitude they are facing, despite the social world around them.However, a word of caution is that people who are weak-hearted or suffering from depression to NOT play this game as it will  leave you in a state of mental turmoil for quite a while ( around 2 hours for me ) after finishing the game. My advice for anyone who wants to try this game is to put yourself in the shoes of the protaganist and to keep an open-mind about the game, understanding and empathizing the emotions that the protaganist feels, making the choices that best fit the mood that you are feeling right then and there, in the shoes of the protaganist.This game is definitely not for everyone, and I only reccommend this game to people who are intruiged about how people suffering from depression feel and percieve the world around them. Otherwise, to everyone else, its a boring game and please stay away from it because its probably not a pleasant experience scrolling through text that you're not invested in, dont waste your time.OTHER NOTES: - I suggest playing this game in one sitting, it is ~1 hour.- Turn the music on, its pretty good setting the atmosphere.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												Depression Quest:I can't really classify this as an actual game, rather than an experience. Sure, it's a bit short, but it's not like the devs wanted to make this a full fledged game. Heck, not a whole lot of people even notice this game anymore. So you wanna know wether or not to get this game? (Even though it's free) P.S I'm gonna be doing this Completionist style. STORYYou start off as somebody who's, obviously going through depression. Like the description says, you are given daily life scenarios and have to decide what to do, considering the fact that you are in depression so you are not given some of the choice you may want. Luckily, in my first playthrough, I got the "good" ending, or where you beat depression. I would definetely NOT want to see the bad ending.... PRESENTATIONHow you play the game is by textscreen. At the bottom of the page is your choices, with some of them being crossed out making you go like, "Oh come on why won't you WORK WITH ME". Ok, maybe not, but that's how I felt. FINAL VERDICTAfter playing the game, and looking at other reviews, I think that this game deserves a 4/10 to a 5/10. It just feels right inbetween there because it's not good enough to be noticed by "the big guys" but you should defenitely give this game a shot!

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												This is an interesting one, unlike anything I’ve played recently, and consequently rather difficult to evaluate. It would be misleading to classify it as a video game, or even a visual novel, and should be approached accordingly. The awkwardly titled (yet entirely appropriate?) Depression Quest is a cold, presumably personal take on depression. In the course of my first playthrough, completed in one sitting lasting about an hour, I felt it was more of an opinion piece, a snapshot of depression, wrapped in biographical accounts, situations and perspectives. For me, it didn’t work. The quality of writing is average at best, suffering from overwriting, repetition and a jarring form of second person narrative that too often insists on telling the reader how to feel and why. Perhaps this is intentional - one of the aims of Depression Quest, I’m told on the opening page, is to help people who do not suffer from depression to understand those who do. This could work, yet I also find that the plot was fairly generic - we assume the role of a character who is depressed for undisclosed reasons, and as a result, he or she has no energy for hobbies, work, family and friends. I’m not entirely sure what message Depression Quest carries about depression as a whole, other than that it happens. This may sound good on paper, a frank depiction of depression, the sort that doesn't necessarily have an underlying cause or meaning, but it’s akin to filming a man crying continuously for several minutes - there must be more, ultimately, to truly engage the audience, to give them a reason to care and empathise. The interactive element of Depression Quest is also questionable, multiple choices provided at the end of every other page of text. As with so many other choice-based titles, this creates an unsatisfactory overall narrative, and the idea that you can go back and change things, achieve the best possible ending, is in stark contrast to the realities of depression. Beyond that, it also creates logic problems - without spoiling anything, in one scenario I achieved a positive outcome, and a mere two pages later things had fallen through, without any real relevance carried in the writing. The music, too, is poorly implemented, the same piano piece, while fitting, looping over and over and in the end serving as little more than a frustrating distraction from the writing. Ambient sounds are introduced in various scenes - coffee shop sounds in a coffee shop, for instance - but this does little to enhance the experience. Nor do the images, small snapshots of images vaguely linked to the current scene, which seem to have various amounts of blur depending on your character’s depression level. This is another thing I don’t understand - depression, in my own experience, does not affect visual or auditory senses. I do not start seeing fuzzy images or hearing static no matter how low my mood is. Ultimately, then, I found my experience with Depression Quest underwhelming. Regardless, I recommend the title because it’s free, because a playthrough will not eat up a lot of time, and finally, because it is a personal experience that will invariably resonate with different people in different ways. If you're interested in gaining insight into one of humankind's ugliest emotions, give Depression Quest a go.

Posted: February 24, 2015
												There is a lot of flak for this game and it's creator. I decided to avoid reading reviews and just dive in.Depression Quest plays like an old choose-your-adventure book. You play as a depressed man and are given different choices each passing day. Some choices can be unpickable based on the mental state of the protagonist.All in all, there are a few different endings but the game itself is very repetitive. The protagonist is a pathetic whiner who is completely unlikable.I talked about this game with my girlfriend who claims to have suffered from depression. I told her that the game was uninspired and the protagonist an unlikable♥♥♥♥♥♥ She got really premenstrual about this and whined about "being intolerant" and not understanding what a crippling disease depression supposedly is.Needless to say, we're no longer together. Anyone who's half-sane knows depression is not a REAL disease anyway.I'll give it a generous 2/10.

Posted: March 25, 2015
												I appriciate the game for attempting to break the mold of convention as to what is concidered a game. That being said the dialogue is very uninspired, I was hoping that this would be more of a "literary" game. When it came to actual mechanics the dialogue choices gave me very few options, by marking out the dialogue options in red made my interactivity fall off the chart completely.I would recommend this game because I feel that in better hands it could have been something much more interesting. With command functions and true dialogue responses it could have connected the player closer to the content. I had a very strong disconnection when the script tried to put me in first person. I feel that the game would be more effective if the player was playing as someone other than themselves. From a mechanic stand point this stops the player from making the easiest, obvious or "right" decision.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2016
												As someone who has never experienced depression, I am unsure as to whether this game accurately represents the illness or if it is exaggerated for effect (although I imagine not everyone experiences depression in these ways, regardless of whether or not this game is accurate), but I found it very interesting. It does show how hard life can be when you have depression and frustrated me a time or two because I couldn't choose to do something simple or something that I would have normally done because of the character's lethargy. I was also very surprised at the amount of self-loathing this title presented, which was also very frustrating, and very depressing. So I guess the game accomplished what it set out to do, to show how depression affects people on a day-to-day basis, even if it wasn't a particularly fun game to play.Also lots of spelling errors, repeated verbs/adjectives and word confusion.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												This is an interesting one, unlike anything I’ve played recently, and consequently rather difficult to evaluate. It would be misleading to classify it as a video game, or even a visual novel, and should be approached accordingly. The awkwardly titled (yet entirely appropriate?) Depression Quest is a cold, presumably personal take on depression. In the course of my first playthrough, completed in one sitting lasting about an hour, I felt it was more of an opinion piece, a snapshot of depression, wrapped in biographical accounts, situations and perspectives. For me, it didn’t work. The quality of writing is average at best, suffering from overwriting, repetition and a jarring form of second person narrative that too often insists on telling the reader how to feel and why. Perhaps this is intentional - one of the aims of Depression Quest, I’m told on the opening page, is to help people who do not suffer from depression to understand those who do. This could work, yet I also find that the plot was fairly generic - we assume the role of a character who is depressed for undisclosed reasons, and as a result, he or she has no energy for hobbies, work, family and friends. I’m not entirely sure what message Depression Quest carries about depression as a whole, other than that it happens. This may sound good on paper, a frank depiction of depression, the sort that doesn't necessarily have an underlying cause or meaning, but it’s akin to filming a man crying continuously for several minutes - there must be more, ultimately, to truly engage the audience, to give them a reason to care and empathise. The interactive element of Depression Quest is also questionable, multiple choices provided at the end of every other page of text. As with so many other choice-based titles, this creates an unsatisfactory overall narrative, and the idea that you can go back and change things, achieve the best possible ending, is in stark contrast to the realities of depression. Beyond that, it also creates logic problems - without spoiling anything, in one scenario I achieved a positive outcome, and a mere two pages later things had fallen through, without any real relevance carried in the writing. The music, too, is poorly implemented, the same piano piece, while fitting, looping over and over and in the end serving as little more than a frustrating distraction from the writing. Ambient sounds are introduced in various scenes - coffee shop sounds in a coffee shop, for instance - but this does little to enhance the experience. Nor do the images, small snapshots of images vaguely linked to the current scene, which seem to have various amounts of blur depending on your character’s depression level. This is another thing I don’t understand - depression, in my own experience, does not affect visual or auditory senses. I do not start seeing fuzzy images or hearing static no matter how low my mood is. Ultimately, then, I found my experience with Depression Quest underwhelming. Regardless, I recommend the title because it’s free, because a playthrough will not eat up a lot of time, and finally, because it is a personal experience that will invariably resonate with different people in different ways. If you're interested in gaining insight into one of humankind's ugliest emotions, give Depression Quest a go.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2016
												The game is just not as interesting or deep as it thinks it's being. It starts off with you waking up in your room on a monday morning and the flavor text berrating you. Some of this text is clickable and brings up even more text than the intial introduction. The first flag is how condescending the narrator is to the people in their life, how everybody "is trying their best but just "doesn't understand the pain." Instead of explaining what "the pain" is or why it's affecting their life so adversly, the narrator just admits that they have a problem but that there really isn't anything anyone can do about it and that it's there to stay. The actual interactivity of the game really shows the blatent "feel sorry for me" attitude with options that are logical and pretty helpful with the situation or further the downward spiral of the character. Instead of having a choice in the matter, however, the "helpful" choices are scratched out in bright red with text at the bottom of the page reinforcing the fact that your life is terrible and nothing is helping you. I don't know if it was the developers intentions to sound condescending and pathetic at the same time but it's frankly not sad but annoying. Just because it feels like there is nowhere to go doesn't really mean it's true and if other people are willing to help you then it isn't going to hurt more just to talk about it. Also it feels like this is just focusing on a very specific type of depression instead of what could actually be a varying type of disorder that people actually have, trivializing the concept of depression. It's a game on a high horse and I'm not impressed.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												I tried this game expecting a result that would match some of the critics I read, and honestly, I'm baffled. This game is absolutely fine. I have gone through a few playthroughs, and I think it depicts depression (and only depression, not linked to any kind of PTSD or any other mental or emotional disease) with a simple and neat outline. Obviously, it doesn't cover everything it could cover, and as it states at the forenote, it's not recommended for people still struggling with depression.However, it puts simply the basic functioning of depression, it's limiting capacity and how it works as a neverending cycle if you don't step out of it, which is something most people without depression or closeness to someone with depression can't understand.So yes, I do recommend this game, because honestly, the basics are great, and it makes some clear statements that, judging from other reviews, not even people with depression know, and everybody should understand them.Long story short, the makers are skilled with the subject, know how it works, and produced a neat outline to display the basics of how depression feels and works, and also how to keep it on track.

												When I heard wind of this game and how poorly recieved it was, I knew I had to see it for myself. I was eager to compare the character's experiences to my own. After playing the game through twice, I have this to say first.ANYONE who says this game is innacurate in it's portrayal of depression is full of♥♥♥♥♥♥/b>.Everyone experiences depression DIFFERENTLY. For some people, it makes them sad and cry. For others, it causes lethargy and lack of motivation. EVERYONE is different and has different solutions.That being said, I myself have depression and anxiety disorders. number of helpful: 40 of 80 people (50%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 8, 2015
												Before talking about the actual game, I want to emphasize the first sentence of this game's description: "Depression Quest is an interactive fiction game where you play as someone living with depression". If you're expecting anything more than a text based game, think depression is just 'people being lazy' or simply don't like reading, this is not a game for you.I've seen some reviewers complaining the character you control is gloomy, lazy, paranoid, clingy... Well, welcome to the ugly ugly world of depression! I don't think the people complaining about the crossed choices quite get the point of the game. Depression is a downward spiral of negative thoughts and emotions, where even the things you once loved cheer you up. Everything is exhausting, even something as simple as making dinner or talking to someone. You want to ask for help, but instead shut down and distance yourself from others, genuinely believing you don't deserve their attention. Asking why you can't choose the better option is the same as asking why poor people don't buy money.I think the good and bad endings could have benefited of more differences between them, simply to emphasize the importance of getting help and support during these times. Otherwise it was a good, short, free game. 8/10

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5
												An interesting text-based game. While the phrasing can be a little awkward at times ("You are a mid-twenties human being"), it's a good read if you have around half an hour. I'd say give it a go.Some of the criticism of this game is valid: If you don't like reading, this game is not for you. The way depression is portrayed is a little simplistic, and characters seem a little too supportive at times, which is usually not the case in reality. The cross-off mechanic that prevents you from accessing certain options seems restrictive. At least in my experience, depression doesn't really work like that. It might be interesting to try to attempt something unreasonable and be worse off for it. Also, having a depression indicator is a little on-the-nose; players should be able to judge for themselves. The UI could also be a little more interesting in general.On the other hand:Despite what I said earlier, the game does an okay of job of portraying the battle with depression. The characters are very supportive and the game encourages looking for professional help and reaching out to those who care, which is good advice. It's not too long, it's free, and provides an interesting insight into depression, if nothing else. Also:Some of the other criticism is very unfair. It really isn't the "worst thing ever" as some seem to be making it out to be. It's not that fun, but neither is dealing with depression. Since it's not too long, I'd suggest playing it before jumping to conclusions.

number of helpful: 33 of 66 people (50%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												Depression Quest is an interactive presentation of what living with depression can feel like. As a game, it is very spartan - in fact, it is closer to a hyperlink story than to other interactive fiction games. One could think of it as a Choose Your Own Adventure game, but the game could also be described as a minimalist visual novel or, more technically, a finite-state machine. On the other hand, so can adventure games. As someone who lives with depression many of the scenarios hit close to home. Social missteps become impossible embarrassments. Enjoyable activities become guilty pleasures or rote comforts. Simple tasks become insurmountable projects. Minor insecurities are internalized as vast character flaws -- the very condition of being depressed is mistaken for being one. As a player, however, it is important to recognize that depression is not the root of any of these problems. Being introvert or insecure is intrinsical to a person. Depression exacerbates traits to the point of being harmful.I am fortunate to never have slid too deeply into depression myself. I was able to get get the player character's mental state progression to more or less mirror my own, but without my own experience I would have fared a lot poorer. The game reflects the negative spiral of depression by locking out productive choices as the player character's mental state declines.  This conveys to the player some of the frustration that someone with depression will feel at not being able to take perfectly obvious and sensible steps to improving a situation.The prose is written in the terse style of most works in the interactive fiction genre. Sentences are short and active. Descriptions are restricted to the bare essentials. The point of view is second-person to blur the line between player character and player. Each scene in the game constitutes a page of exposition, and a page for describing the short-term consequences of the player's choices. Short of a few grammatical mistakes, the writing is perfectly readable, albeit a bit bland, as is typical of the genre. Overall, the effect is one of detachment. The authors recommend that the music be left on to complement the writing, although I do not consider the music to be all that effective. More poignant is the conservative use of sound effects and secondary tracks, such as the distant mumble of a woman or the bass sounds of a party.Depression Quest is a well-written exposition on depression in the form of an interactive story. The hour or two it takes to play through the game is well worth the time to get a better understanding of what living with the condition is like for some people.

The game demotes you for doing something it forces you to do.There's another part where one of the choices was blocked out for no apparent reason.It just seemed like the creators were just to lazy to write an outcome to that choice."An interactive (non)fiction" the subtitle boasts.Ha.Hah.You see, the problem with this is that it would have to have actually happened to be considered "nonfiction".Sorry Zoe, but considering how this has multiple endings, there is no way that this has all happened to you.Don't play this. Use your hour to do something more productive, like laying on the couch for an hour and eating chips.

												This game has gotten a lot of controversy, but I think it is a great example of a simple narrative game. It also shows a lot of the thought processes that go through the mind of someone with depression. I have never been diagnosed with depression, but I have had times in my life when I felt the way the character feels in the game and thought similar things. Nice, simple, and free.

number of helpful: 8 of 16 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 2, 2015
												I loved this game. It made me feel more emotions than any other game I've ever played. I have struggled with depression and it is comforting to me that there is a game that shows how difficult it is to live with depression. Many people who don't understand what it is like to be depressed don't know how to help or understand someone who is lives with it. I actually had my boyfriend play it even though he was against it at the beginning because there was a lot of reading. But when he finished we talked about it and I think he got a lot out of it. It's hard to live with me sometimes when I get down but he's always there for me and I think Depression Quest can help him know more how I feel. I liked how there would always be a "normal" response to a situation but it would have a line crossed out and you weren't able to pick it. That's just like real life. You know what you should feel like or what you should be doing but you just can't do it. It's just not possible. That also is a great way to show people who don't suffer what it feels like. I always tried making the best decision possible when I played. Again, I know what it's like to be depressed and I always try to see the best in life even when it's really hard to do so. I think it should be manditory for everyone to play this game.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
												While I haven't finished this game yet, I noticed that there were a lot of negative reviews. I noticed that a lot of them didn't like depression being defined for them by someone else, but they were more than willing to provide their own definition. I find that to be weird, because in my experience depression takes on many forms.The game even tells you that this isn't meant to definitely define what it means to be depressed. There are just too many types of depression and people in order to have one set definition.I do have a bit of a theory that some of these negative reviews might be a knee-jerk reaction of shame. Such as us saying "No, I'm not that PATHETIC." or it could even be that you think you are far more pathetic than this. It depends on your depression I guess.There were some statements I agreed with a lot. I have seen a therapist recently and have been doing better. I'm not sure there's anything like a cure out there for depression, but I do think there's a possiblity of living life fully without it fully controlling you. I don't think it's easy to get there and it depends on each individual if we can make it to that point. I hope I continue down the road where I am relatively happy instead of how it has been, but I don't know for sure.I'll take playing this slow, but for now I think it's worth reading just from the standpoint it makes you think.Oh yeah, it's a "Choose Your Own Adventure" book and not a traditional "game". Get over the fact that you need to read in this - the screenshots are not deceptive about what's in this game.

Posted: November 16, 2016
												I don't think the majority of the negative reviewers actually "get" this game. It's not meant to be fun. It's meant to be frustrating. As someone who suffers from depression, this is probably the most accurate representation of the experience that I've seen. Is it meant to be a "good" game? No. Could it have been better? Yes. It's nothing fancy, and there's a few spelling errors, but I don't think there's any other legitimate criticism. It's just some dumb little game, and it does the job it set out to do. I find it unbelievable that this is what set off the Gamergate mess. Is it really unbelievable that someone else "got" what this game is about and wrote a decent review? If you want to see what depression is like, play this. This is not something that's meant to be enjoyed, and that's the whole point.

												I note that a lot of the marked helpful reviews of the game, at least at the top, are negative, as I read them before playing. I disagree with them. A lot of people are saying this game is awful at imitating depression, but as a depressive and anxious individual, it really clicked with me, and even brought me to tears. Obviously the experience of depression and anxiety is different for everyone, and so will their experience with the game be, but for some of us this game represents perfectly how hard just living life can be sometimes. This game is a really good addition to the library of anyone who suffers these things similarly to the way I do, because it doesn't just help you see your own troubles more clearly, but it represents the fact that there are people who understand. And that, I think, is very important.

number of helpful: 11 of 23 people (48%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 12, 2016
												This was an unique game, and an interesting opportunity to connect with how I see  Depression. I myself have been diagnosed and struggle with clinical (or major) depression. I downloaded and played through the game today, read all of the note from the producers in about 1 1/2. My experience, and the choices that I chose throughout the game really helped me connect with the same behaivors, and the impact of my choices in real life. While the game itself may not be for everyone- and may insult or desenitize others with depression or similar diagnosis- I would say it in my mind very similar to what I myself have experienced as a person diagnosed with Depression. I would simply like to thank the producers for their involvement in this project, and while I may not ever touch this game again, I would recomend it to some friends- their outcomes, their resolutions may not go well, but maybe they might just be able to grasp how difficult depression can be to handle from day to day. One choice can affect everything, making positive choices- even when you feel empty, guilty, hurt, embarrest- like you are a failure or ugly inside, and don't know how to tell anyone else- That is one of the hardest things to do. No ammount of telling someone to try harder or be a better person will change if they don't trust themselves to feel safe, or to feel loved, beautiful, or capable to live as they want to. The only reason I have this ability is because I made that choice to open up no matter how afraid I was everything I did would fail. This might be a game to some people, but for me, it's like reliving a part of my life that I didn't know how to connect to before. So Thank you.I know some people may not agree with my review, but please respect that this is my opinion, you don't have to agree with it, but please don't bash it.

My First issue with the game is the stup*d soundtrack, boring, and it becomes nuisance in no time, it's so terrible that i cannot even concentrate in the text, the very long and boring text about someone with a very♥♥♥♥♥♥y life, after the first five pages a was like "Ok, it will start anytime now", but, a text without gameplay it's not a game, it doesn't have the any of the four basic element that consist a experience as a game, you beign developers, i think you should know what element are those, in case you don't know, fear not for you incapaity, i will listen those here, they are Alea (The Random factor in a game, Aka Luck Factor), Agon (The Competitive Factor, Aka Skill), Mimicry (The Roleplaying Factor) And Ilinx (The Vertigo Factor) The only factor i saw was roleplaying, you say the game brings the experience of someone who suffers from Deppression, i will come back to this later, right on the bat i see the first choice on the blocked, cleaver, giving limitations to the player to make the "Game" Challenging, i chose something, even if it's not what i would chose because what i would chose is not an option or it's blocked, but after some turns i just get annoyed by this design choice, i'm just chosing random things, making the "Mimicry Factor" not really there, but i'm feeling generous today, but every bolder choice that would be better if you where in the main character position only results in your own demise, beign blocked or becoming a unhappy cat owner, an i guess this is not how depression works, would you care to send me the contact of the psychologist or the psychiatric doctor that gave you consultorship for your project? Because that person is a incompetent, and that is a important thing, in any matter, developers can't say "I Think" about a problem this dangerous such as depression, you NEED consultory, you NEED someone who know what they are talking about and when your friend offers help to you YOU CANNOT EVEN GET THE F*CKING THERAPY RIGHT AWAY, the game make a huge burden for you to call the doctor, even if you should encourage depressed people to do so, well, since the soundtrack is stupid, the gameplay is non-existent and the content is bullcrap, the graphics must be Outstanding, Crysis Level sh*t, but they at it's best, Lookable, they don't hurt your eyes, but they are not an eye candy, the fonts are boring and the background is so bright that make the text feel take a huge effort to read, which should not happen in a TEXT BASED GAME, why not use the Visual Novel style? number of helpful: 9 of 19 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14
												An alright story about a person with depression.As a person that lives with depression, but have gotten past my most extreme parts of it, it was more of a look-back at my own experience with depression, social anxiety and self isolation.I can relate to some things while I don't get some parts.That's as much detail as I can really go into.It's not great, it's an alright, short read that most people will probably dislike.Now, a touch on other reviews; a lot of people complain about how it doesn't manage to portray depression correctly.Depression is different for every person who has it, if you went into this novel thinking it would cover every single aspect of depression ever or manage to perfectly portray your own experience with depression then you deserve no attention and your review is invalid.The game says in the opening paragraph that it goes without saying because of the very basic nature of depression it is experienced differently by every single person who suffers from it.This game is just a tale of the experiences of the developers and people close to them.It doesn't say that this is the best or most accurate representation of depression.To close the review it is an alright read that manages to portray depression in some aspects but it also goes into things that has nothing to do with depression, like disliking your job, hating your job has, at least on the surface, nothing to do with depression.

number of helpful: 9 of 19 people (47%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 17, 2015
												I've had depression since I was 17. I just turned 40. I know it all too well. Been on meds ever since. This game gives a good scenario, but like some people say in their reviews it isn't very accurate. If he was THAT depressed, without any counseling or medication, he would of been thinking about suicide a hell of a lot more. Maybe even make a plan or carry it out.  I'm not sure how he ended up in a relationship unless he wasn't depressed before that. A lot of people don't understand. This game is a 'sort of' example what it is like day to day. I will give it that. Everybody is different though. Depressed people are able to hide it well, I know I did. But it got bad. Really bad. I begged my mom to take me to talk to somebody but she didn't take me seriously. But she finally did. Well after that she realized how bad it was. The main thing is, talk to a professional person. But sometimes you don't care about anything, or anybody including yourself. Then you start doing stupid things, getting angry for stupid reasons and become anti-social. If you know somebody that is going through this, please encourage them to talk to somebody and get the help they need before it is too late. And be there for them if you really care about them.This game was hard to play through for me. But I got through it. I just wanted to see what all the hype was about and see for myself instead of just reading the reviews.8/10 - Will not forget my meds on the counter again... (STP song Bi-Polar Bear. RIP Scott Weiland)

number of helpful: 7 of 15 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
												This game novella is not depressing. I found it thought provoking and kinda cute.What to expect: It's written in second person ("you are feeling stressed and your mind is numb"). "You" are 20-something of unstated gender with a girlfriend and a dead-end job. The writing is quality and easy to read. The pages are short, and it runs in a window, so it's convenient to read while multitasking. I came across a couple of typos and a couple of details I didn't quite understand (I think because the writing is very US-centric), but those are trivial concerns. I think anxiety & depression sufferers will identify with elements of the story, and it might help others to understand these phenomena a little better. With the path I chose at least, it was ultimately a hopeful story.It's unfortunate that the popular negative reviews are political in nature. Reviews should be 100% about the content, and the content is super rudimentary. The whole thing is essentially old school HTML + some music. But I'm fine with that.Edit: I just realised how much this story, as a stream of consciousness, reminds me of The Catcher in the Rye.

												This game isn't your typical game. You're put in the shoes of a guy in a very bad place. The game does a fantastic job of captivating you and making you feel like you truly are leading them down the path you're choosing.Each choice matters, every decision counts. I managed to clear his depression first try, but after replaying a few times I found this is only done by making the correct choices.The only fault in this game is the fact that when I used a controller, it'd crash a lot.Overall, I'd recommend this game to anyone who likes reading a lot, learning about depression, and feeling immersed in a game at the same time.

number of helpful: 7 of 15 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 10, 2016
												Maybe I experienced the game differently. I definitely thought the protag was whiny and the writing was a bit pretentious, but I didn't get the sense that the game was making them out to be lazy and selfless, more that the depression was crippling their motivation and made it hard to find interest in the things they normally do.For people saying that all the positive choices were crossed out, yes, the most helpful ones were, but there were still positive choices (usually the second option - this game has a tendency to list options in order of most-to-least helpful with a few switch-ups thrown in now-and-then, which I find a bit weird but w/e). I managed to get what I believe is the best ending (my protag was seeing a therapist, taking medication, and they weren't depressed anymore), so maybe it's just that I took the time to read the choices and think about what would be most helpful.For those saying it's too long/too much reading, come on. It took me maybe 20 - 30 minutes to play this game and I only skimmed like 5% of the text.I've never been officially diagnosed with depression and I don't think I have it, so I can't speak to the accuracy of the depiction in this. I'll simply say, take it with a grain of salt. You may relate to it, you may not. This game doesn't suit everyone. I liked it, but hey, that's just me. Experience the game for yourself if you want to have an opinion on it. Or don't. It doesn't matter.

number of helpful: 7 of 15 people (47%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 19, 2015
												Depression Quest provides what I feel is a very fair representation of some of the thought patterns and attitudes prevalent in those experiencing depression.  Calling it a game however, is a bit of a stretch in my opinion considering depression itself is not a game.  I am seeing lots of reviews that are written by people that seem to think that the "solution" choices being unavailable is ridiculous, but from my experience wtih type 1 bipolar disorder the lack of those options is nothing short of realistic as a representation of the workings of the mind of the severely depressed.  Hell, I would even argue that the options presented *aren't hopeless and dark enough!*  That, however, is just reflective of my personal experiences with very intense and deep depression where hygene and food intake are put completely on hold and every other thought that goes through my head is self deprecating or suicidal.  However, the authors explained the choices and decision options very well in the description when they stated that eveerybody experiences depression differently, and it is quite simply not possible to cover every single possible decision and experience angle.  Besides, if they DID manage to cram in... say 100 different decision options, it would result in the game not being what it is supposed to be - a glimpse into the mind of one "average" depression afflicted individual for the purpose of educating those unfamiliar or curious about what could be on the mind of a depressed person.Is this title for everyone?  Hell no.  There is no happy ending or real control illustrated in the text... this is EXACTLY how MANY, MANY people with depression feel and see the world and is completely intentional.  The only goal of the seriously depressed is to make it to the next minute of their life.  The princess is NOT in another castle... she bled out in her bathtub last week.  If you expect a sunshine and lollipops style ending with just the right combination of choices, you're in the wrong place.Does this title reflect poorly on the depressed, making them appear lazy?  Only to the grossly uninformed or those with a deeply misguided view on depression as a weakling's illness that's cured with force.  (Please F*** right off - you only perpetuate or worsen the problem)  The described emotions herein are very true to life and the lack of a real "ending" is truly reflective of the illness.Should people give this a try for s**** and giggles?  If you are truly looking for giggles or a sense of accomplishment after  completing this, you are looking in the wrong place.  Trust me.  Uncertainty orbits the depressed mind like a moon and often eclipses the soul from the light.  People curious about the depressed or those faced with living with a depressed person absolutely should give this a go.  The reality of the depressed person won't make you smile or laugh, so this game will not either.  Reality's a ♥♥♥♥♥ like that.Do I reccomend people try this out?  Definitely.  Just know what you are getting into, and that everybodies experience and attitudes are going to be different.  Don't be a jerk - realize what the goal of this project is, and not what you want it to be:  education, not entertainment.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												I know that this game doesn't accurately represent what depression is. The choices are so simple they might as well have named the choices good choice, bad choice. But why do I recommend this game then? It's because I read the authors note at the beginning and the epiolouge of the game. It's cleary said that this game isn't therapy or an accurate representation of depression, it's way for general audiences to understand what people with depression are going through, it even said that this might not be true for everyone's case. The story about being a 20 something year old with an achieving brother and a out of your leauge girl friend might seem cliched, but it's the narrative that make it work. There are time where things don't sense, like when your boss tells you "it's dead". What's dead, wtf is "it" boss? But the point I'm trying to get across here is that this isn't a terrible game, it's original and the developers really took a chance making a game about depression. That's couregous as hell, if a bit crazy. I played the game twice, getting the good ending and the bad ending, it was really easy for both. But what the character was going through was made it interesting and engaging. Not everyone with depression is going to go through this, but the main character did, and that's the point of this game. It's a visual novel, you don't see people complain how dating sims aren't realistic. I know depression and harems are completely different, but it's about putting your self in the character's shoes, and I was able to do that. Yes this game has room for improvement, better grammer/spelling, more complex choices and for ♥♥♥♥s sake a save button (what's up with that?), but it also does things good, like the narrative, charcters, and how it handles telling the story from our main characters perspective.TL;DR? It's free, play it, but don't expect it to treat depression, expect it to be a visual novel

												This game achieves everything that it sets out to do. The format is inspired and is quite nostalgic for those of us raised on 'choose your own adventure' books. The feeling of helplessness as those choices slowly become inaccessible while still being visible was quite striking to me.The conversations feel organic and natural, and the descriptions of locale and feeling are detailed and poetic while not falling into overbearing or ham-handed territory.This game may not be for people who require constant action and instant gratification, but for those willing to sit quietly for half an hour in order to be given a look into one person's experience with depression this game exceeds expectations.

												Don't mistake this for a game. It is not. It is a piece of propaganda designed to drive home that depression is a hopeless condition.What annoys me the most is that there are no real choices presented. Any meaningful way to improve your character is vividly struck out in red, to underline that it is hopeless. This is a huge lie-  there are genuine sufferers of depression who do make an effort to and do overcome their condition. They do select the red choices and make things better for themselves. This game does a great disservice to genuine sufferers of depression who may be led to believe the message that all is hopeless. I worry that it might just tip them into seeking a permanent solution. If you have any remotely depressed friends, DO NOT let them play this 'game'. I cannot stress this enough.And I cannot understand why the developers have chosen to preach such a bleak (and untrue!) message instead of one carrying some hope for depressives. This is bordering on, if not outright irresponsible.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2014
												This is not a "game" in the traditional sense of the word. Its more of an experience, a window into the life of someone living with depression. I'll tell you right off the bat: this game is not very fun. However its not about being fun. The game exists to provide understanding. I read some of the reviews for this game, and several of them came off as shallow minded and superficial. Phrases similar to like “Was listed under the RPG category but its not an RPG its just a text based game.” I’m not saying that people aren't entitled to their own opinion. I’m saying that a person shouldn’t take this experience as just another free to play game. One must look past the simple categorization and actually see Depression Quest for what it is. The developers never had the intention of making a fun game, nor did they ever want to make money off of it. I believe that this game was created because someone (namly a Zoe Quinn) simply wanted to tell a story and get a thesis across.I came into Depression Quest with low expectations as I do all free to play games. I found that the ambient soundtrack was appropriate for the subject matter. The writing wasn’t anything revolutionary, but it told a narrative that I saw to the end. The story had its moments where I related to the characters and felt real emotions like pity. I was told that the game has 5 endings depending on the choices you make. I only played through once to in order to not dilute my experience and impression of the game. Like I said before this game was not fun and it was never meant to be. Depression is a real world issue and it affects real people every day of their lives. Simply creating a triple a Sims-esque simulation game would possibly serve to detract from the subject matter.Bottom line: If you go into this game with a sense of superficiality or immaturity you are going to leave feeling like you wasted your time. However it you read into it and get invested the same way you would any other form of media, the experience will resonate. I’m not saying it will affect everyone like it has me and many others, but it will  one some level. If you do have depression. Seek help. It is out there.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 11, 2015
												I recommend this game if you've got some idle time, as it's short, free and it paints a beautiful, sometimes upsetting, sometimes uplifting view on one of the most common mental states in the world. It's presented as a visual novel, it's low budget, and it shows. Regardless, if you are patient enough to immerse yourself in the fictional character through the text, I think the experience warrants it. It employs one particularly clever trick - showing you options which you want to pick, but preventing you from picking them. This gives you (the person behind the keyboard) a sense of frustration, and through that, an understanding. Those banned options go through your characters head too but, like in real life depression, they can't do them any more than you can click the buttons.It has some story telling issues, the biggest of which was that time was poorly represented. I suspect the events play out over many months, yet this isn't made obvious, and it feels like weeks instead. Also, it's "obvious" which are the better options to pick - at least when you're in a healthy mindset - but I'm not sure how it could be done better. If you're suffering right now from depression, this might make you feel terrible, but you might still want to persevere - it's a story of hope, as much as it is a story of depression.

												The game leaves you with a heavy feeling in your heart, but that's exactly what the developers were aiming for. They told from the very beginning that it wouldn't be a pleasant expirience, and it wasn't. But I think they achieved their goal - show  the player how people with heavy depression feel.I see two minuses in the game:1. It won't start from Steam menu, and I had to launch the .exe file from the game folder. Not a big deal, but this technical flaw spoils the impression a bit.2. No saves. The game is really short, but the fact that you have to beat it in one run makes you hurry a bit and doesn't allow you to feel the story as deeply as you could.I think it would be useful for everybody to get acquainted with this game, because it can help you to understand how somebody near you feels, and how to better help him/her.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												I've played this before on the interwebs. Might as well toss out a token review.For a game that causes grown men to go into fits over the dreaded ess-jay-dubyas, this isn't a terrible intersectional game. The main character doesn't have any money concerns, has a steady job, a supportive girlfriend and at least one supportive family member, hits the jackpot on their first time visiting a therapist (it took me about four or five tries to find one that clicked), lives in a location that allows them to keep a cat, and doesn't seem to suffer any ill effects from race, religion, physical disability, age, or gender.As a long-time sufferer of depression's smaller cousin, dysthymia (if depression is a big black dog sitting on your chest for stretches of time, dysthymia is an overweight cat that lays on your head and never leaves), I recognized a lot of the situations presented in the game, and the options for action described pretty well actions I might have taken. Although I really wish getting help were as easy as clicking a link in a Twine game...All in all this game doesn't merit the hate it gets. So thusly I give it a recommendation. It's not a Half-Life-esque landmark game... but it deserves to be appreciated for what it is.I hope that somewhere, somehow, thisgame  makes a grown man-child dudebro cry. I hope it makes him recognize depression in himself or someone he loves. I hope he can become a better person because of it. I hope like hell.

In my playthrough, I really symphathised with the main character and his situation. I really do recommend playing this game, especially if you are going through hard times, like I currently am while writing this. The game in total lasted only about 2 hours and, for that entire time, I was intently reading every line of dialogue, skipping nothing at all. In a playthrough, I believe that you should choose every option as if you were in that exact situation. It is definitely worth the time and, if anything, it will help you out if you're currently dealing with any depression-related problems yourself.P.S.I think that the game should only be played through once, as there are multiple outcomes and your inital outcome will represent how you feel and how you dealt with things the most.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
												Depression Quest manages to convey a believable sense of what one might experience, living through daily life with depression.  While it won't capture everyone's experience with the illness, it can certainly serve to allow players who haven't experienced depression to imagine what others go through better.On a mechanical level, Depression Quest is also interesting in the realm of interactive fiction in the way it tracks your character's mental health, and presents choices which may be disallowed because of your character's illness.  An interesting study on the power of the *illusion* of choice (or at least, the frustration of missed opportunity, even if certain options are never allowed to be chosen).

content:

Product received for free
												Being someone who has suffered from clinical depression for years I found Depression Quest to be a very relatable experience as well as also being excellently written and quite well-paced. Many have disregarded the game completely for reasons such as it not matching their personal experience of depression or their knowledge of the illness, however depression is an almost entirely unique experience for every person who suffers from it and this game can only depict so much.  Overall I’d say this is a great portrayal of what depression CAN be, and in my opinion it’s a massive step in the right direction for a better understanding of the illness for both people who don’t suffer from it and also people who do suffer from it but aren’t aware of how others might experience it.

												the idea is actually not that bad. The only problem I have with this game is that while it has this insanely good soundtrack (best part of this game), the whole thing in of itself is nothing but an unfinished text reading and clicking bonanza. Seriously. It often feels like perusing a wiki article and flowing through hyper-links out of curiosity, while at others, the lack of appeal to this "book" makes me flat-out skip entries I'm completely and utterly uninterested in.While this game can be sharp in terms of it's text entries, it certainly lacks in terms of everything else that should make it a videogame - but ultimately can't make a videogame out of it, as the "video" elements of this game are missing- outside of the surprizingly striking status text at the end of each day's entry.In the end, this game worked one thing for me: reading the increasingly worrying status texts in the entries was immersing, but in the end, I was so bored out of my mind with everything else to this game that awarding this game a 4/10 is, unfortunately, a too generous review.2/10 is my final grade.Hope this project gets to be polished. As of right now, this isn't worth being called a videogame. I'd have more fun reading wikipedia articles.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
												This game is just... ugh. Despite it's good intentions, it manages to depict sufferers of depression as whiny, angst ridden people content to live in their misery, which i know for a fact is not true. As I played through, I tried my damndest to get my character help, but every attempt to open up to somebody or to pursue help led nowhere. Beyond that, the supposed choices the game offers are a lie. Every single choice you make leads you to exactly ONE alternate snatch of text, and then directly back to a screen which you'd have wound up on if you had made any other choice. On top of that, the game does NOT tell a cohesive story, with a beginning, middle, and end. out of nowhere, you get a screen explaining to you that it didn't have an ending, because depression never ends (oh I see, it's completely insurmountable, good to know). I could forgive all of this if the game was simply able to cause me to empathize with sufferers of depression, but in that, and many other regards, it utterly fails. The people heralding this as a grand artistic step for video games absolutely baffle me. The writing reads like the kind of stuff a high schooler might write, and the scope of the game is surprisingly limited, even considering the small development team. Don't give this game your time.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												The feeling of having no motivation, getting no enjoyment from anything, and believing that by getting help you're just inconviencing others, are all things that this game tries to portray as well as it can. So while it does fall short in terms of length and actual gameplay, it at least makes a effort to try and emulate the real ways that depression slowly eats away at you like a crippling disease.The fact is that in the end it actually displays the effects of depression better than most other games, movies, and TV shows. Because depression is a monster in your closet that you can't ever be rid of. No matter how much people say things like "Just go get help" or "Do something to not be depressed", that's just not possible because that beast called depression will always be in the back of your mind chewing on your thoughts and making it seem like every possible choice will just make you a burden on others. Often people suffering from depression will never seek help, and the best help they can receive is by their friends and family noticing the problem and getting them that help (sometimes whether they want it or not).To sum up:Gameplay: 3/10 (Pretty much non-existing)Story: 5/10 (Could be much longer and more compelling)Experience: 10/10 (For anyone who has actually experienced real depression and been diagnosed, this game may or may not be relatible to your own experiences)Fun: 0/10 (This game is about depression and doesn't have a happy ending)Worth it? (Price): 10/10 (It's a free game)Length: 1/10 (Short and simple)Overall: 2/10 as a game, but a 8/10 in terms of actual effort and care that was put into it. I wouldn't say that this is a all-time "Must play" kind of experience, but rather on par with playing through a brief educational game.In the end I will say that it's good attempt at approaching a serious subject, and that It is unfortunately a forgettable experience.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
												This.Thiiiiiiis.Let me start from where I should: It's about a man in his mid-twenties who goes through, well, depression. It's interactive, and presents situations this man goes through while providing 2-5 options to pick your way to continue.At the very beginning and a few more [pages?] through, it felt as it was shouting "Welcome to Ayudon". Way too me-ish, and I'm sure I'm not the only one who felt like this.But then as I progressed it felt like.. I don't know, should I say "less charming"? With this I mean, I think I 'lost focus' on actually giving accurate answers on what *I* would do in his place and instead trying to get the best ones for him to achieve a happier mood. Maybe because it showed your mood "status" on each page and I felt like it asked me to increase it, maybe because it had options to make you choose from (still, if it hadn't I suppose it would be even less interesting) instead of being a one-way wall of text (don't get me wrong, a very worth reading wall of text)... or maybe it's just me playing it entirely for the whole night. Although it's quite short, so it's possible.Enough, back to the point. In sintesi, if there was an "Unsure" option for recommending games, I would leave this one there. It has its ups (such as depicting something I was diagnosed with very accurately), and downs (losing its touch), but then again it might as well be just me...... Why don't you find out *yourself*? It's a very short road in both playtime and file size, like ~100mbs, so there's that to it as well.8/10. Might re-review it some day.. I think..

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
												This isn't much of a "game" so much as a story you can click through, and I don't understand why such a big deal was made over it, oh wait yea I do because people still think trigger jokes are funny and harassing women is a sunday passtime.The game is lacking a lot of...everything. For one thing, the game assumes at the start that you'll be able to relate to the main character despite him being about as fleshed out as an actor in an antidepressant commercial. I was honestly hoping that, with the thought of an actual game in my head, we'd be able to personalize the story a bit at least as far as our age/gender/race goes. I can't relate at all to some dude who, despite apparently having debilitating depression, has his own apartment/a girlfriend/loving family/can hold down a job.For another, as many other people have already said, the game is simply too easy. A text-adventure game cannot convey the difficulty many individuals with depression have simply asking for help, let alone seeing a therapist, consistently taking medication, being open with their S.O., etc. etc. etc. and a format in which you only need to click the button you know is the "right" choice is one that destroys the potential any game that attempts to be thought-provoking has, although the bit where the "best" choice was blocked out/not available was a nice touch.Regardless, it's a step in the right direction as far as acknowledging mental illnesses in vidya goes, even if it didn't quite hit the mark, or even have a mark to hit to begin with. The developer also seems to have dealt with a ridiculous amount of♥♥♥♥♥♥10/10

content:
Posted: November 3, 2015
												This game accomplishes what the goal is supposed to be: highlighting and explaining depression in a realistic way. Thus, it isn't enjoyable or fun in any sense, but it IS interesting. The music choices and visuals offer great atmosphere for the depressing content. Most of all, I like that there are choices listed that someone that isn't depressed would usually make. "Be honest," "Enjoy your night," "get the therapist without prompting," etc. However, for you, being depressed, it is impossible to make those choices. Including them, but making them inaccessible, was an important choice. I would only recommend playing this game if you understand that not all games are meant to be fun, but can be a social/emotional commentary.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												I really love the concept of the game about an insight of what goes through a depressive mind. As the devs said it is not going to be something that everyone suffering or suffered from derpression can relate to but rather for people who never have been depressed before to have an idea about what goes through the mind of a person going through depression.Now, the game is well written, explaining in detail things even when I was depressed I couldn't express, and the choice based system is nice. It is a good interactive novel.While I had such an unique experience, game could improve upon some aspects, I'd like to say that sometimes there were things which were crossed out, but if I was in the protagonist's shoes I would do just that, which sucks as I could relate better if game allowed me to do the crossed out things. I understand everyone's experience with depression is different, I could actually quite relate to many parts of the game. The best part is that this game is free so please give it a try.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												A quiet and honest look at the emotional resonance that games can have. Even if they have to let go of the concept of fun to do it.This game doesn't have win-lose scenarios, an obvious best choice, or even a guarnteed resolution. All it has is realistic decisions based on the story's current circumstances. It plays with exceptations the same way reality does.While I've only played through the game once, I managed to get a personal ending that I felt was appropriate for the story (out of the possibilities of 150 possible encounters). If you ask me, it was pretty close to the best ending, but I felt like I didn't always make the right choices. Just honest answers.And rule of thumb: the first choice isn't always the best choice.Plus it's free and takes about 20-30 minutes of reading (at my reading speed).If you can spare that time, then I guarantee that this game deserves to be played once; and you deserve to understand that depression is always a possibility, but never an eventuality. So remember what this game offered. As a fellow human, it is the best that you can do.Sincerely,R.B.
