												I really didn't know what to expect when i downloaded this "game".It made me a little uncomfortable as I played because it actually puts you on the spot of a depressed person.And as I was progressing through it,I felt that many of the situations that were described there actually happened to me.Now,after getting to the "ending",I feel a little better.Because i know things get bad,but there's a way to get yourself back up after.And I actually felt kinda happy when I started to see that my actions were actually helping the protagonist and that every choice i've done,no matter how small,changed him in some way.It was a suprisingly fun experience as much as a helpful one.I recommend it to everybody that has (or know someone who suffers from) this problem.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
												I understand that for everyone with depression, this game isn't a reflection of every person and their experiences with depression. However, people would realise that if they read the introduction that the producers never claimed that it was. It was an interesting and enlightening game for those who are not sufferers of depression and it was comforting and eye-opening for me. Zoe Quinn herself suffered from depression and she is trying to spread awareness through an unprecedented medium. It could do with a lot of revamping and become a more visually enticing interactive novel, but I see nothing intrinsically wrong with the game or the concept behind it. Ok, it's not a barrel of laughs, but depression isn't and it shoul be taken seriously. And yes I bought the damn cat, why the hell not?

content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												As much as I want to enjoy this game, for the sake of abandoning bias, Depression Quest is undeniably a boring game. While the game is obviously designed to make the player feel helpless, the method of achieving such a feeling is awkward at best and dysfunctional at worst; The Player does not take the role of the protagonist or understand the protagonist, but rather feels agitated by the lack of control of the protagonist (For this reason, I especially do not recommend Depression Quest to those suffering from Clinical Depression).You know you've failed in your work when an MS paint comic (Hyperbole and a Half) made by one person better conveys the concept of clinical depression than an Interactive Fiction made by three people.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2014
												This "game" was nothing more than my life on screen. I am even right now in bed at 3pm after taking the day off from work. I have no motivation and if you people that write reviews want to say I have no personality that's ok. I don't go out on the weekends. I have a dead end job, with a few co workers that I talk to. The only reason I am still around is because I legit don't have the balls or energy to kill myself. I have tried therpy and pills and neither seems to work, and I would rather sit quietly in my room facing the wall then have to talk to someone about myself. The last relationship I had ended almost exactly like that expect at a much faster pace (we only seen each other for a couple of weeks). The holidays for me are my hardest couple of months. They bring nothing but stress aniexty and hopelessness to me.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
												     The issue I would first like to adress, is the issue of people saying this visual novel does not give an accurate description of what depression is like. I have never seen a single book, visual novel, movie, show, article, website, etc. give a proper understanding of depression. No healthy mind can understand a suffering one. (Well, there are some exceptions to this yet I am speaking of the majority of healthy minds) We simply don't have the ability to understand the extent. It is simply cruel to expect that of a game made by a limited number of people. They did their best to explain the mental suffering to those who have no issue with it. Also, the majority of the public is quite sensitive to issues as suicide and thoughts of suicide. This did a fantastic job at not giving too much visualization for those who are sensitive yet just enough to still show them the severity.      The next problem, is that people point out it is not a "game".  This is a visual novel. At no point was it intended to be a game in which you could play and enjoy. It gives you choice as to what you should do yet it does not tell you to "play" it per se.      Finally, many people say that it offers little choice and simply tells you a story. Yeah...no shiz. It is a visual "novel". This means that it is supposed to give an experience instead of let you play a lot. The choices you make do affect the outcome but the goal is the same. To speak to you about depression. The choices you make are determined by earlier choices. This shows the "player" that if you stay in one mind-set, things will continue down that path.Anyways, that is all I have to say. I quite liked this game and don't feel that it is being judged correctly. People become really harsh to games with sensitive topics and I just wanted to give a nice review for this. I don't mean to offend anybody and if I have, I thoroughly apologize. I have little experience at a lot of things and hope that people don't take my words too seriously. This was simply my personal review.

content:
Posted: May 24, 2015
												Depression Quest did it's job. To show depression.It needs to be said (and should have been said by Quinn herself) that Depression Quest is merely a manifestation of a general idea of clinical depression, meaning that the whole nine yards of the condition will not be exhibited here. Should you want to have a more in-depth comprehension of the concept, Wikipedia will do the job well enough. Hell, even prior to starting the game, there was a disclaimer, for lack of a better term, stating that Quinn is not infallible, and what is provided here is all she could muster from others. Maybe she is lying but she is still rebutting all the people here shaming the game simply because of that. Just like any other disease, there is always a spectrum that ranges on various aspects of the condition. Now, the game.The character is...You. Literally, to enhance that self-insertion part of the game. You have a girlfriend, a minimum-wage nine to five, and parents who still happen to be together. The average guy, You are, but here's the kicker. You suffer from depression, and Depression Quest is a chronicle of said depression which places You in situations that the average twenty-something year old might face. As this is a record of Your progression, the game has the propensity of lending You the course of events, for You to determine the events that transpire while coping with the symptoms. (Note all of this ♥♥♥♥ing redundancy, I'll stop.).Quinn, or should I say, "The Quinnspiracy" tackles themes that are associated with clinical depression, such as anxiety and social exclusion. These themes are used and emphasized fairly well as they are exemplified in many occasions throughout the game when the player gets confronted by others or even more so when Mr. Protagonist succumbs to his condition, lessening to a pile of spite and self-loathing. Even if one does not suffer from this illness, I am certain that players can relate to the events here, since the average person does find him/herself in a number of situations here. The only visuals here consist of small photo pamphlets containing even smaller pictures of daily trifles in subdued color, which often repeat. Along with the continual track of music, they do nothing to thicken the ambiance of the story. Depression Quest might as well be considered a "Choose your Adventure" e-book rather than a game, taken into account the large portions of text the player is given. I think the main problem most people have with this game is the "decision time" element of the game, which I don't entirely disagree with. It's honestly sort of absurd how the game handles it, as some, if not most choices will be scratched out or not there at all if you didn't take up the cat offer. It is evident the choices provided are affected by your depression level, but even this is stupid as on the instance of a high depression level you will be barraged with scratches, leaving only one damn choice most times. To make matters worse, there will sometimes be that one "ideal" choice that is scratched out always, practically ridiculing the hopelessness one can potentially feel with depression. The level-choice relationship could have made a fine mechanic to implement in the game, but the developer failed to get a firm grasp on it to make it work well.The game sure isn't perfect, but what was done here isn't as reprehensible as some other projects I've got my hands on. If you seek a brief, satisfying story that tries not to amaze but to "inform" (to a certain extent), then pick this up and give it a go. Don't expect much, it's still from Quinn herself.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 9, 2014
												Being a 17 year old with Bi-Polar (Manic Depressive Disorder) who has developed a very strong control over his condition,I find that this game very much describes my actions and thoughts/feelings when I'm stuck in a manic depresive phase. The gameplay is FILLED 110% to the brim with heartbreaking walls of text with little to no interactions which is a total downer and makes me question the actual amount of effort put into making this into a "Game" and I do not feel like this was good game material or a good idea for one. However, seeing as this is a "Game" and is currently playable, this "Game" was more than successful in delivering what it promises to: Heartbreaking Scenarios that you have little to no control over. I do not reccomend this game to anyone who already has symptoms of depression, Bi-Polar, Cyclothymia, Multiple Personality Disorder, etc. If you don't and you actually give a♥♥♥♥♥♥about how it feels to be like the above mentioned, this is not a dead on simulation, but a good start to understanding how we feel and think. Also, if you're like me and you find anything offensive to be extremely hilarious (like dead baby jokes and nazi stuff), play this for laughs. Like I said, I have good control over my emotional situation and can recognize my current emotional status at all times nad can act accordingly to function socially and perform menial tasks properly without my condition getting in the way. Because of this, I was actually able to laugh at some of the scenarios and situations in this "Game" because they tended to be only Semi-Realistic, yet I find myself to have been in every single one atleast once.Overall:Gameplay aspect = 1/10 Total♥♥♥♥♥♥..this aint a game...it's a half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥depression simulator.Story Telling aspect = 9/10 Very good! Good story still!Overall Rating = 4/10 This seriously did not need to be made. However, I aint gonna complain about the fact that it was.Note: While this aint exactly fun, I gave the game a thumbs up because of the fact that despite it's rating (the one I gave it), it's a "Game" that I would honestly suggest everyone without symptoms of depression, Bi-Polar, Cyclothymia, Multiple Personality Disorder, etc. to play atleast once and to actually read it and take thier time to actually choose their responses (if allowed). This is more a "Learning Experience" than a game.

content:
Posted: October 18, 2015
												This is not a fun game.Now that we have that out of the way, let's get to what it is.  This is an attempt to shine a light on how difficult depression is.  I live with someone who suffers from depression and many of the situations in this game reminded me of ones close to real life. The game follows the player through the discovery of what is happening to them as well as who their support system is. During some parts of the story there will be options marked off. These options are simply what most people would say to do, but someone suffering from depression might not be able to do.If you are looking for a game that will deal with some pretty mundane but powerful situations, here it is.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
												First, this isn't a "game" and does well to label itself as "interactive fiction."I can definitely see what the intention was here, and the writing isn't TERRIBLE. But the main character's experience with depression is a little over the top and not always relatable. There are definitely moments where the writing hits on some poignant things, but it's overall a little too serious and doesn't live up to the potential for a witty commentary on depression that it could be. I'll admit, I played this ironically, reading aloud to my boyfriend as we worked through the story. The protagonist, while meant to be androgynous, would not realistically read as male in most cases. My boyfriend had trouble relating in most instances. The only believable impression is that you're playing a girl in a relationship with another woman. We both cringed at the protagonist's available choices as well.Overall, it was okay, but the ending was pretty lackluster, and even with occasionally insightful passages, the story itself was filled with secondhand embarrassment. It feels very much like reading an individual's very personal experience with depression and their own (poor?) way of coping. Better than I expected, though, to be honest. Quinn might have some success in blogging at the very least, but this isn't a successful "game."3/10 -not a game (why is this on steam?)-low-quality visuals, no aesthetic appeal-decent writing style, poor story structure/ending-only semi-relatable example of depression-ambiguous protagonist, but very personal narrative

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
												This game may not be like any other you have ever played before, it is something ompletely new.Many negative reviewers have said that because they are 'depressed' they cannot pick the options that they said would make them less depressed, ans so succeed at 'completing' the game. Depression is exactly that, it's a spiral of downward thoughts and negative emotions, it is meant to seem like you can never break away and make yourself 'better'. This game captures that very well, you have to be intuitive and engineer your own way out, not the easy option, but the realistic one that suits your mental state.I have never had depression and hope i never do, but this game might have given me an insight on how that mind set may come about and how damaging and comsming to life and social interactions it may be.I don't know how accurate this game is at portaying how it is to live with depression, however it was an enjoyable play and is quite short, a bit less than 1 hour.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2015
												Very much a Choose-Your-Own-Adventure style game. This is suppsoed to give an insight into depression, something which it does very well. Having been there, and seen others who're in the same state, it's very true to the nature of the disease.I'm not going to enter into a debate about what constitutes a game or not, and whether this was 'fun' or not. I consider it a game, but by no means was it fun, nor was it meant to be.It's 30-60 minutes of eye-opening, and it's free. In terms of spreading awareness in a unique and interactive way, it does its job. Don't play if depressed, but definitely play if you know someone who is and you don't quite know what they're experiencing.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
												     The issue I would first like to adress, is the issue of people saying this visual novel does not give an accurate description of what depression is like. I have never seen a single book, visual novel, movie, show, article, website, etc. give a proper understanding of depression. No healthy mind can understand a suffering one. (Well, there are some exceptions to this yet I am speaking of the majority of healthy minds) We simply don't have the ability to understand the extent. It is simply cruel to expect that of a game made by a limited number of people. They did their best to explain the mental suffering to those who have no issue with it. Also, the majority of the public is quite sensitive to issues as suicide and thoughts of suicide. This did a fantastic job at not giving too much visualization for those who are sensitive yet just enough to still show them the severity.      The next problem, is that people point out it is not a "game".  This is a visual novel. At no point was it intended to be a game in which you could play and enjoy. It gives you choice as to what you should do yet it does not tell you to "play" it per se.      Finally, many people say that it offers little choice and simply tells you a story. Yeah...no shiz. It is a visual "novel". This means that it is supposed to give an experience instead of let you play a lot. The choices you make do affect the outcome but the goal is the same. To speak to you about depression. The choices you make are determined by earlier choices. This shows the "player" that if you stay in one mind-set, things will continue down that path.Anyways, that is all I have to say. I quite liked this game and don't feel that it is being judged correctly. People become really harsh to games with sensitive topics and I just wanted to give a nice review for this. I don't mean to offend anybody and if I have, I thoroughly apologize. I have little experience at a lot of things and hope that people don't take my words too seriously. This was simply my personal review.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2015
												There is so much going wrong for this game that it would be far quicker to list the good things than the bad.  However, I find it's often best to do things the hard way.In the opening screen, you are presented with the statement, "This game uses audio as a part of the play experience.  We encourage you to play with the sound on."  This is not a good idea.  The music is very haunting and fairly immersive, but only for the first few bars.  It quickly devolves into a grating noise that is either looping or just played with annoyingly similar chords, throughout the game.  It does not enhance the experience.  If anything, it hurts it.The story itself is a major problem.  As the game states, people experience depression differently, and the game can only shed light on so much.  However, the game feels lazily put together.   There aren’t many options, just a few blanket ones.  As you plod through, more types of options are locked or unlocked based on your decisions.  But even with the amount of text displayed on each page, the story was very lacking.The characters felt like two-dimensional effigies.  You could not get attached to, or even empathize with, any of them, because there simply wasn't enough to them.  It was as if each character was their own dating website profile, with only a few words plugged into each text field.As the protagonist continues to get worse, (or better, as it's hard to tell since it often feels vague) more options are blocked off, leaving the player stranded on a route based on just a few decisions they made early on.  Though this is somewhat accurate to reality–people living with depression find themselves unable to do even simple things like get out of bed or shower, at times–it seems to railroad the player into one of three possible routes:  The good end, the bad end, and the neutral end.The truth is, these ends come with some loaded messages.  Productive actions will be rewarded, yet by choosing not to make productive choices you will be heavily punished.  This message is incredibly dangerous to spread to those with depression who are playing the game in an effort to feel understood.  It spreads a message of helplessness and worthlessness.  After all, you are made to feel you’ve lost the game, and downright worthless for having done so, if your choices weren’t the “right” choices.At the end of the game, in the credits, you are pretentiously thanked for "being willing to play games that are meant to be something other than simply 'fun.'"Even though I have referred to "Depression Quest" as a game throughout this review, it really is not.  This is a "choose your own adventure" book, or an exercise.  There are no real gameplay elements in this thing, save from being able to make choices that have lasting effects.  And yet, it is making itself out to be something better than "fun" games, despite having almost none of the qualities that make a game, period.In fact, it's barely even a game book.  In "choose your own adventure books," the story is engaging, and what you do matters in the pursuit of your goal.  "Depression Quest" is not engaging, there are no stakes, and it's hard to tell what effect you're having.Long story short, "Depression Quest" is, at the most, a meretricious, amateur attempt at creating a "choose your own adventure" game book, loaded with text and grammatical errors, being projected as something above and beyond other video games.  This is ironic, seeing it accomplished none of its goals.It fails as a video game.  It fails as a game book.  It fails as a teaching or therapeutic tool.  It fails at depicting what living with depression is like (especially if you consider the testimonials I've received from friends, family, and online sources).  It even fails at being an expression of the author's personal pain, as it does nothing to instill any sort of empathy in the player.  It's all so tedious, unimaginative and even narcissistic, that it comes off as a whining teenager's journal, destroying any attempt of connecting with the player, even at a superficial level.Worse still, the game's history renders it even more unenjoyable.  What really did or didn't happen is irrelevant.  Obviously, it doesn't make any sense that the creator would have fraternized with online game journalists for monetary reasons, seeing that the game was always free.  However, after playing the game and seeing what it's all about, it makes perfect sense that they would for pure publicity.  That is quite possibly the only way that this game would have gotten any form of notoriety.  Otherwise, it would have faded into obscurity in less than a week.  And it worked.  The scandal is the biggest reason that anyone knows about it.  It has given its creator more publicity, voice, and money than their talents could have ever brought.That doesn't mean that the subject of depression is impossible to put into game form.  "Actual Sunlight" is one that better achieves this.  Although, some may think that it's more of a visual novel than a game, it still has more and better gameplay elements than "Depression Quest."  Better writing with a deeper, more meaningful story, and makes no lofty assertions about what it is.  The stakes in the game are clear, and you can empathize with the characters.  Its creators put thought and care into their game, despite it being simple in the game play aspect.In closing, "Depression Quest" was one of the most poorly made, pointless things I have ever spent time on.  The creator owes $25 to every person who has ever downloaded it.

												A chilling, thought provoking, and accurate representation of depression. This game is not enjoyable, however, that is not the purpose that it is supposed to serve. This is a narrative game with the purpose of making you think, and it succeeds in this regard. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2015
												Stepping into the shoes of someone who has a different experience of life and interact with their world is the thing that games are much more capable of doing than any other medium. Using a limited and restrictive set of mechanichs and graphics can still be effective if you have a good story to tell or an inventive idea. Just like using a limited pallet painting the artist can produce something fantastic but it takes skill. This game nails how to do that in the games medium. The central idea of depression limiting your ability to be proactive or energetic is really well done. It's a simple mechanic crossing out the options but its a really artful way of putting the player in the shoes of someone with clinical depression. The options are there and anyone can tell you, that doesn't mean you can take them. This game would be really helpful to someone trying to understand a friend or family member going through this so long as they aprouched it honestly and with an open mind.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												Seriously, this game does not belong on Steam. That sounds heart, but it's true; this kind of format is more suited to a text adventure, style games in their own right, but shouldn't exist cluttering games on Steam.Also, as far as a text adventure, this is pretty aggravating. This does NOT convey depression accurately as far as decision making and the general vibe. I got more and more frustrated as the answers only dialed down to "depressing" or "More depressing". Nothing about the story is engaging. It would be better suited to use this character in a third person to give them some empathy. However, to sound more “Immersive” I suppose, they stick you in the first person as the player. Problem with that is, I would NOT make those choices in those situations. So instantly, I have lost focus with this character, these scenarios, and this game.Positive things?...I dunno, it launched and exited quickly. Looks like my PC can run it, so there’s that. Color palette isn’t absolutely disgusting. So...there’s that.Totally unrelated to the review, but the fact that this game caused such a big upheaval is unheard of for me. It's certainly no triple A release, but this game is boring and dull by indie game standards. For something more in depth on depression, for games, look up TellTale's walking dead series, or The Beginners Guide on steam.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												Although the game seems to accomplish what’s it sets out to do to some extent it is all together a very boring game that I don't believe will have a meaningful impact on the people that play this game. It does have a depressing feel to it and your decisions have somewhat of a meaningful impact but in the end there aren't really any consequences for your actions. Sure you can end up losing your girlfriend but even then you have a positive outlook on it. You take away that Alex (girlfriend) will find someone she will be happier with. The decisions made had slight impacts but no real consequences. I went through a second time and attempted to self-sabotage and i was expecting a darker outcome, for instance death of the character, but there was not such outcome. This may be due to the fact that they didn't want this game to be that dark, but depression is that dark. They allow partial reality to the game, not true reality. If they wanted to follow accurately they should have much darker consequences, but also the ability to have lighter outcomes.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												This game feels inaccurate in its portrayal of depression. None of the friends save for Amanda seem to be helpful individuals. I would hope that if I had the behavior of our protagonist, someone would try and talk to me or do something. Depression is a legitimate struggle to get out of, but this game makes it feel like a game. By trying to simulate someone’s very personal experience, you make someone with a legitimate medical issue seem whiney. You can’t really relate to the protagonist if you haven’t had depression, and from people who have had depression, it would seem inaccurate. My brother has Bipolar disorder, and has intense periods of depression. He acts completely different from the protagonist in these periods. No one supports the protagonist unlike the girlfriends and family of the real world. While some people don’t get the support they need, I feel someone would at least notice early on. If you wanted to make an impact, make the game from the point of view of someone only slightly depressed, and have game options that can make it better or worse. Starting from the bottom makes it hard for the “typical” person to get into the mindset of the depressed individual. 	Aside from the faults in its portrayal of depression, the game feels boring. The red crossed out text is just frustrating in the early game where they are not even a conceivable option. They would be better off when they are something a player could access. The static-text is aesthetically unpleasing as it stands out from the rest of the games aesthetic. The photos on the top often feel like its going for an artsy feel, but overall they feel pointless. This game feels like it’s trying to be artsy, being important. It wants to be profound and interesting, but it comes across is trying too hard to be sad and not capturing what it set out to do. The game only got the attention it had due to scandal, and it shows. The gameplay is boring and the commentary is weak. I would not recommend the game to anyone who wants to understand depression. You are better off with an old textbook or internet entries. The only saving grace is that this game was free, so at least I didn’t lose anything other than a few minutes of time.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2015
												This game's purpose was to raise awareness on what depression felt like to those who didn't suffer from it; which it did, but all too well. I personally did not think I was depressed, but after playing this game I had slight hesitations in my head: "Am I actually depressed?"It delivered it's purpose all too much, with the very detailed information and sound. It felt too real, and really made me think in the character's perspective. At the same time, I was disappointed every time when I couldn't click on the crossed out option, which is obviously the option for those who aren't depressed. It seemed as though although I wanted to take the more cheery option, it was out of my reach and ended up having to take another option which I felt wasn't my first option. While this game is completely successful in it's purpose, I will not recommend this game even to those who are not depressed just for the fact that it could affect your life negatively, and is not worth any positive points that could be taken from this game.

												In "Depression Quest", the game's objective is to have the player experience a situation where depression is present and to help the player realize how depression is a serious illness. The game does exactly that, as it puts you in a 20 year old man's shoes who has the ongoing feeling that he is exhausted all the time and feels down on himself. With the help of the noticable music in the background and the somewhat interesting storyline, it definitely makes you feel that presence of depression. After playing the first few minutes of the game, I was actually fairly impressed with how the developers were able to portray the image of depression through a video game such as this one. "Depression Quest" definitely achieves it's goal and takes you on one heck of a ride.

If only that were the case here...Some might say that this is merely the fault of the people involved, and shouldn't reflect too badly on the end result, but you have to remember, it was their choice to make all of this public, one idiot made the initial push to get the 'news' out there, and then the other idiot brings this to attention on her public social media accounts, so that we're all caught up in the drama and arguing our own points on the matter when in truth, the only idiots who have any say in the matter are Zoe Quinn, the alleged five dudes she was banging while still involved in a relationship, and the first idiot I mentioned who was her boyfriend.They are all stupid idiots who we shouldn't be enabling, but we are regardless of what we say about them at this point because the damage has already been done, they've gotten out of this exactly what they all needed and we're all suckers for giving it to them..So in conclusion, do not play this game if you just want to get a better understanding of the current drama, those people are not worth your time. content:
Posted: September 24, 2015
												The writing style is bland, the presentation is completely unengaging, the music is grating, and despite all its attempts to present itself as a game about depression, one gets the sense that while the writers may have read about depression once and maybe even had it at some point, they have no idea how to communicate this fact outside of simple description of symptoms, and have an even weaker understanding of the concept of a "game". A far better approach, if you really want to understand what depression is like, is to read Allie Brosh's now-famous account of her own struggles with it, or if you prefer to do so in the form of a video game, try playing Winter Voices. For all the bugs and interface problems Winter Voices struggles with, it does a far better and more engaging job of portraying depression and grief, by taking advantage of the fact that it is a video game in order to represent things more abstractly and truly draw in the player, trying to make them actually engage with the subject matter.Depression Quest is like reading the most boring and linear Choose Your Own Adventure book ever printed, one where all paths lead in roughly the same direction to roughly the same ending and the serious subject matter is treated so blandly that there's just no reason to give a ****. They say real art makes you think, and this game does make you think, but it makes you think "wow, I'm bored".It's bug-free, playable, and costs $0, therefore it's already got several legs up on Aliens: Colonial Marines, but otherwise just not worth anyone's time, even as a curiosity.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2015
												I think the most important thing you have to remember is that this game doesn't have "right" or "wrong" answers. This isn't something that you have to try and win, because that's entirely not the point. Some people might hesitate to call this a game, but I think "interactive experience" is a bit less catchy. Nonetheless, it can offer you a bit of insight into depression that simply talking or reading about it won't achieve. Things like being unable to bring yourself to act upon options that seem so obvious or effortless to "regular" people, and how frustrating that is. Being fatigued by repeated interactions with well meaning but oblivious people that offer no solution or resolution. Finding occasional comfort in unexpected places.For those complaining that this game isn't an accurate representation of depression, I'm not sure if you've actually played it or are able to read, or understand humanity at all, because if you did, you'd have seen on the very first page that it doesn't pretend to represent ALL cases of depression, nor is that even possible since, besides the innumerable different types of mental illnesses out there, everyone with even basic depression experiences it differently, and live with it under unique circumstances. What I got out of it was a familiar retrospection of how my life and experiences had been several years ago, and occasionally (but fortunately rarely) still relapse into every now and then. But it wasn't exactly the same obviously, as I'm not actually dense enough to expect a 30 minute free game to somehow perfectly mirror my whole life experience.Depression Quest is very honest about merely being an attempt to provide people who know and care about someone who has depression a bit of potential insight into their otherwise private and closed off lives and consider what sort of reactions from loved ones help and what actually makes it worse, despite the best intentions.If this does not apply to you but you're just curious, it's free! But for those to whom the events described in the game are familiar, but genuinely struggle to explain what they are going through to loved ones, this could potentially be something valuable.For me, it illustrated the concept of "I understand what you're going through/went through" so much better than a vague verbal reassurance that, when you're in that situation, often feels ingenuine or meaningless anyways. Just remembering the familiarity of that creeping hopelessness reminds me why the vapid suggestion that people should "just get over it" is so uselessly dismissive, and that dismissiveness comes from the lack of empathy, due to a lack of perspective. If this game can offer people a bit of perspective, that's value.I'll admit I wasn't overly fond of the music, it was a bit more distracting than probably intended. Here and there were also a few obvious writing mistakes, but other than that, I'd certainly recommend this to people with an attention span.

												I think this game gives a good example of what it may be like to live with depression. It illustrates how limiting it can be by eliminating the obvious good options, since you know what you should be doing but are too depressed to actually do them.  It shows how positive actions lead to positive outcomes, how easy it is to slip further into depression, and even how unpredictable it can be to try to take positive actions but end up being more depressed as a result.I found this to be a very emotional game, both sad and dark and uplifting and positive.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
												I'm disappointed in this 'game'. If I wanted to know what a person feels when they're living with depression, I would ask as I have several times before. The concept is somewhat interesting, but the story is just bland; an overall waste of my time. [I don't need flashing lights, loud noises, mainstream music or gunfights to get my attention, much less entertain me, just wanted to throw that out there.] I know the crossed out options for making things better is an attempt to show people without depression how depressed people (may) feel, but it gets tiring when after a while the main characer does just about nothing to actually help themself. The character is over-analytical, and I got the feeling ever so often that they didn't want hope, that they didn't care for a chance to get better. Even if that's what depression can do to a person, a simple attempt to feel better about themself or their position in life should at least be an option, even if the end result is no change for the character. Whether or not the people who made this game wanted an immersive feeling to be had by those playing it, text and a few photos does nothing to grab my interest. Illustrations and a change in the characters' appearances (from third person or the main character's point of view) would have made this much more interesting of an experience. Instead I am stuck watching a person feel sorry for themself. This is not what a game is for. There has to be a goal, a reward or have rising action, a climax and a resolution - a reason to go on, and I see none after clicking 'next' 15 times. The options to make things 'progress' or make things better in this story sound like the kind of things someone would THINK a depressed person would do. If it means anything to Isaac, the repetative piano music kinda made me want to kill myself. I'm not sure if that's what was being aimed for, but man, bad music is one of my dozens of triggers - including triggers - and got me more into the game, but still not very much.I give this an overall 2/10 - the 2 is me being generous, and I'm not sure if I should be.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
												It's an interesting experiment but I'm not sure it achieves what it sets out for. In most cases it nicely describes the thoughts and moods of a depressed person but I feel like it's too simple. For someone that struggles with the illness it may seem oversimplified and "too easy" to get out of the severely depressed state in the game... you know what option you need to click (even when the ones naturally available for healthy people are crossed out, which is a nice touch) to possibly better your situation but for someone depressed it's not this clear. Also, although the creators do note this at the beginning, this particular character is in a very good environment (even if their job is not satisfying) because basically everyone supports them eventually and they can affort treatment and medication. So I'm not sure the game succeeds in what it tries to do. The idea is not bad and some of the descriptions are on point but the gameplay and the options lack in representing the difficulties and intricacies of the subject... which would be the reason to make a "game" such as this in the first place. I do recommend it if you are interested in the topic but don't expect too much from it.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												I found this game while searching for games with overwhelmingly negative reviews. I wasnt really sure what to expect, but it was free and I had nothing to loose. My initial thoughts were "wow who makes a game about depression" and "lol when my friends see me playing this♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; I ended up really liking this game tho. Not that depression is fun but the fact that your choices affected you in different ways. I saw a review that read something like "this is kinda a slap in the face, I have depression" and at first I kinda agreed but there was nothing that really bashed on depression or made light or fun of it. Not that the people who made this game are 100% right but the morale of the story is to fight depression instead of letting it keep you from living. Not many people would go and google "what is depression and why should I be considerate of other people". I think putting this in the form of a game like this can really help open the eyes of someone who otherwise wouldnt care. with that said this game is probably not for people with depression. I do not have depression and I understand that the developers of this game probably meant well however I can also understand how it might make someone with depression a little offended. to name a few things, the title of the game, the fact that it is portraied as a game, and scratched out choices etc. For me it wasnt really a game it was a novel with a branching plot about depression, and that is what it should be advertised as. NOT as a game and probably with a different title With that said I do not reccomend it because even though I liked it and feel as though they got there point across, the "game" is advertised as something it is not and for all intents and purposes I think whether you have depression or not this "game" should be avoided and pushed under the rug as on of those things that even though the devs meant well it was still a mistake.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
												Right away, I liked the way the game gives you information. I like that it gave you the option of getting more exposition/background details or just moving on with the story. After the gray boxes under the options started changing, I felt like I was helping my character and that the options I chose could really influence the story. I like that they show options you can't pick because of stress or exhaustion, which implies that, if you make good decisions, some of those choices may open up, and also shows how depression can make it harder to communicate with people.I was skeptical when I first opened up this game, since, with the title "Depression Quest," it doesn't sound all that engaging. However, a few minutes into playing, I found that I was really invested in my character and wanted to help them.  I don't have depression, but I can empathise with my character with so many more things than I though I would. I have felt the "end of the week, I don't want to do anything" feeling, I know what it's like when you feel like you can communicate better through writing than speech, and the procrastination is very similar to how I deal with almost all of my work. It felt to me like my character's successes were my successes, and the character's pitfalls were my own. I felt a real sense of accomplishment and happiness when my character felt better and felt sad when they were having a bad day. What matters in a game is the experience. It might not be for everyone, especially if you're someone who can't get into text adventures, but this game made me feel for my character. Even though they're just a cluster of words in a simple text-based game, I genuinely wanted them to succeed. I felt accomplished, like I'd done something really good, by the end of it. If that isn't the mark of a good game, I don't know what is.

Posted: April 1, 2015
												I don't get all the hate for this game. There are some misspellings and grammar errors but they are fairly minor. It's not particularly fantastic storywriting, but it's not supposed to be. It's supposed to be as accurate of a representation of depression as possible. Depression isn't romantic. I also don't feel like it portrays depression as being "whiny" as some people say, however it may seem that way because the person's feelings are unwarranted. This is actually a huge part of the problem of our societies' attitude toward depression - that it has to have a reason, that the person's feelings are invalid if they don't have a reason. This only makes people suffering with it feel worse. I feel like despite the fact that this plainly says it is not a "game", people still expect it to be. It's not, it's more like a visual novel. The reason choices are crossed out is to portray the idea that people with depression feel like some choices are IMPOSSIBLE. Whether they are or not, the person feels trapped by their own mind. If you go back and make different choices, you would find that choosing to open up, see a therapist, take antidepressants, etc. opens up more options. I DO wish it didn't end so abruptly - In particular, if you choose the options to not get better. This sounds really messed up, but I think the story could make more of an impact if it led to the character's suicide or self harm or something. As it is written, while the indicator at the bottom shows that you are getting worse, the story doesn't really describe it. It should delve deeper into the thoughts and feelings of the character, rather than just describing it as exhaustion, anxiety, etc. It doesn't describe the self-hatred, etc. of someone with severe depression. I think that's part of the reason people think the character seems "whiny". Is this game a perfect representation of depression? No. But it IS eye opening and perhaps could help some people relate to a person in their life that may be struggling with it. Depression is something that needs to stop being treated with a stigma, and it needs to be talked about more openly. Hopefully stuff like this can help with that.Finally, to anyone struggling with depression - You can make it through this. You're not worthless. Even the smallest gestures you do can make an impact to someone else. Don't try to go through it alone, there are people that care and will help.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												It's a good game. Sure, it's text based but the music is well done, as are the background graphics and the occasional dreary image to add to the feel of the game. It honestly reflects what depression is like in a well thought out way, thoughts just pouring through your mind. What would add to this is a couple of different options. Alex being male would be pretty cool. Maybe removing her altogether would be a good course of action, maybe with some of the other characters to show how important supportive figures are in dealing with this kind of problem. The only thing I have an honest problem with is the ending. It felt abrupt, withoout rhyme or reason. It really should have some kind of objective to it, like achieving a certain state of mind, but instead it just cuts out and tells you that the game has ended. To me, this chronology based ending makes little sense for a game as there is no real "objective" to aim for as a game.Overall, it's a free game, and it takes 20 minutes max to complete. Just play it already.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												As a person who has dealt with depression, I must admit that this is far closer to reality than I expected, given how little effort went into this game.  That being said, it still looks like it was written by somebody with only a passing knowledge of actual, clinical depression, especially the part where everybody can tell you're depressed.  If it were that easy, there wouldn't be so many untreated casees of depression.  The fact that I could reproduce the entire game in html in a single weekend makes this whole thing insultingly simple.  Even if you don't buy the narrative that this game only got good reviews due to *ahem* inappropriate influence, this thing is like an art film.  It's horrendously boring and poorly made, with no real point, but everybody will proudly prostrate itself before this game, calling it 'bold' or 'artistic.'  It's neither.  It's lazy, and the same kind of people who write good reviews of this game are the ones people make fun of in sitcoms who call a work of art 'brilliant' only to find out it was made by cats running across the canvas with paint on their feet.In short, skip it.  It's lazy, boring, and overpriced.

I wouldn't recommend this to anyone who would want to understand the feelings of anyone with Depression.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
												Right away, I liked the way the game gives you information. I like that it gave you the option of getting more exposition/background details or just moving on with the story. After the gray boxes under the options started changing, I felt like I was helping my character and that the options I chose could really influence the story. I like that they show options you can't pick because of stress or exhaustion, which implies that, if you make good decisions, some of those choices may open up, and also shows how depression can make it harder to communicate with people.I was skeptical when I first opened up this game, since, with the title "Depression Quest," it doesn't sound all that engaging. However, a few minutes into playing, I found that I was really invested in my character and wanted to help them.  I don't have depression, but I can empathise with my character with so many more things than I though I would. I have felt the "end of the week, I don't want to do anything" feeling, I know what it's like when you feel like you can communicate better through writing than speech, and the procrastination is very similar to how I deal with almost all of my work. It felt to me like my character's successes were my successes, and the character's pitfalls were my own. I felt a real sense of accomplishment and happiness when my character felt better and felt sad when they were having a bad day. What matters in a game is the experience. It might not be for everyone, especially if you're someone who can't get into text adventures, but this game made me feel for my character. Even though they're just a cluster of words in a simple text-based game, I genuinely wanted them to succeed. I felt accomplished, like I'd done something really good, by the end of it. If that isn't the mark of a good game, I don't know what is.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
												I don't get all the hate for this game. There are some misspellings and grammar errors but they are fairly minor. It's not particularly fantastic storywriting, but it's not supposed to be. It's supposed to be as accurate of a representation of depression as possible. Depression isn't romantic. I also don't feel like it portrays depression as being "whiny" as some people say, however it may seem that way because the person's feelings are unwarranted. This is actually a huge part of the problem of our societies' attitude toward depression - that it has to have a reason, that the person's feelings are invalid if they don't have a reason. This only makes people suffering with it feel worse. I feel like despite the fact that this plainly says it is not a "game", people still expect it to be. It's not, it's more like a visual novel. The reason choices are crossed out is to portray the idea that people with depression feel like some choices are IMPOSSIBLE. Whether they are or not, the person feels trapped by their own mind. If you go back and make different choices, you would find that choosing to open up, see a therapist, take antidepressants, etc. opens up more options. I DO wish it didn't end so abruptly - In particular, if you choose the options to not get better. This sounds really messed up, but I think the story could make more of an impact if it led to the character's suicide or self harm or something. As it is written, while the indicator at the bottom shows that you are getting worse, the story doesn't really describe it. It should delve deeper into the thoughts and feelings of the character, rather than just describing it as exhaustion, anxiety, etc. It doesn't describe the self-hatred, etc. of someone with severe depression. I think that's part of the reason people think the character seems "whiny". Is this game a perfect representation of depression? No. But it IS eye opening and perhaps could help some people relate to a person in their life that may be struggling with it. Depression is something that needs to stop being treated with a stigma, and it needs to be talked about more openly. Hopefully stuff like this can help with that.Finally, to anyone struggling with depression - You can make it through this. You're not worthless. Even the smallest gestures you do can make an impact to someone else. Don't try to go through it alone, there are people that care and will help.

content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												I played through this game twice, and I can honestly say that I recommend it. However, there are a few things you should know before you get into it.It is exactly what it says on the tin: an interactive (non)fiction game. "Interactive fiction" fits better than "visual novel" because it's almost entirely text-based. Sure, there are some accompanying pictures, but the text is the main focus. The "(non)fiction" label fits well because while the scenarios and characters are entirely made up, the underlying premises are very real. The descriptions of how the main character feels and what they're thinking are scarily accurate for someone suffering from depression. You can tell that the people who wrote this have firsthand experience with it.Playing this made me anxious, not gonna lie. The breezy writing style lets you immerse yourself in the main character's persona, and I had some heart-poundingly anxious moments while playing this. The scene where you talk to Attic about what's going on damn near made me cry, because he said exactly what I needed to hear in that moment.My only complaint about this game is how easy it is to railroad yourself onto the worst possible path, and end up with the "bad ending." The choices you make at the beginning of the game have much more of an effect on the outcome than your later choices. The degree to which your options are limited in the last half of the game is a tad unrealistic; having been in the depths of this debilitating condition myself, I can say that even at my worst, I could still at least attempt to bring myself to do things that were blocked in the game. I found this unneccesarily restrictive. I understand that it's meant to illustrate the hopelessness that one often feels when deeply depressed, but it still felt unrealistic.Bottom line: this game is not "fun." It's not meant to be "fun." It's meant to illustrate the struggles that depressed people go through every day of their lives, and I think it gets the point across really well. I enjoyed playing it; the first time through, I answered the way I felt like I would probably answer if it were actually me in these situations, and got completely ♥♥♥♥ed in the end. The second time, I was actually invested in the characters as third parties rather than actors in my own life, and tried my hardest to make things work within the context of the story, and ended up with a satisfying enough ending.Give it a try; it's free, you have nothing to lose other than maybe half an hour of your life, and let's be honest, you'd probably squander it by watching something stupid on Youtube anyway, so why not give this a try? Try to ignore for a moment who it was that made this game, and focus on the game itself; you might be a little shaken up, but you won't be disappointed.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												I have suffered with depression myself over a number of years. This game helped me see depression in a new light, specifically how I can deal with it. In my first playthrough, I tried to do all the "right" things. I will eventually do a "negative" run to see how the ending changes.One thing that I liked about this game is that it seems biographical even about my own life. I have made many of the poor decisions that are presented in this game, namely ignoring people that care about me and situations that could help me. I have also noticed that the "NPCs" in the game react like many of my real life friends, something I was oblivious to before. Being able to play a game based on depression allowed me to be more "clinical" and make the right choices to see the outcome. I think it has changed many of my negative thinking patterns and I might try to do right thing from now on.The only critique is that I wish I could go back from the ending and be able to make other decisions to see how they played out. Perhaps a narrative tree could be supplied that allows me to go to a specific entry and play it differently. I think it might be beneficial to know about the different types of endings, too, and my progress for obtaining each one. Part of me like to be able learn from my choices and see where different choices take me.This game is definitely an A for me. I can't wait to see more stuff from Zoe Quinn and her associates.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 19, 2015
												I understand all the down votes this game gets. This is not so much a game as experiencing someone's journal first hand. There isn't any real progression that is experienced, the images are incredibly tiny, and the musc isn't anything to write home about. In the end, this is not a good game. However, that doesn't mean that it is something to be avoided, ignored, or rejected. Mental illness is hard for an outsider to understand. It's even hard for people with a mental illness to understand in someone else, due to a large variety of factors, such as severity of symptoms, what those symptoms are, support network, etc. However, I think this game does a really good job of telling you exactly what it can be like. It doesn't let you experience it the same way you would first hand, but it gives you a foundation of what it can be like. I myself suffer from bipolar disorder. This means I go between depressive states, and manic states. I am of the type that my depressive states are the more problematic. I was able to relate directly to the experiences of the character you are to be portraying as I have been there. This game uses the mechanics as a metaphor well to tell you how sometimes an option is not an option just because you cannot get there. This is a game everyone can take away something from. I issue anyone reading this a challenge. Playing through this, I want you to stop at each option and ask yourself, "What is the opposite of what I personally would do?" Then I want you to choose that answer.

												This game is very realistic, in that it addresses the issues of depression and the experiences of people living with it. I found that is was accurate in depicting what it is like having depression, for me at least, and definitely reccommend it to anybody suffering from depression, knows someone who is, or simply wants to know more about it and what it is like living with it. The message of the game is a very powerful and positive one, and it's absolutely lifted my spirits and given me a bit more hope for my future.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												As a person who has dealt with depression, I must admit that this is far closer to reality than I expected, given how little effort went into this game.  That being said, it still looks like it was written by somebody with only a passing knowledge of actual, clinical depression, especially the part where everybody can tell you're depressed.  If it were that easy, there wouldn't be so many untreated casees of depression.  The fact that I could reproduce the entire game in html in a single weekend makes this whole thing insultingly simple.  Even if you don't buy the narrative that this game only got good reviews due to *ahem* inappropriate influence, this thing is like an art film.  It's horrendously boring and poorly made, with no real point, but everybody will proudly prostrate itself before this game, calling it 'bold' or 'artistic.'  It's neither.  It's lazy, and the same kind of people who write good reviews of this game are the ones people make fun of in sitcoms who call a work of art 'brilliant' only to find out it was made by cats running across the canvas with paint on their feet.In short, skip it.  It's lazy, boring, and overpriced.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												For a game that calls itself depression quest, I found the actual message of the game to be "Dealing with antisocial issues". The character (you and I) deals with the inability to speak with people and gets tired of social interactions in a manner more associated with introversy. I felt a genuine amount of effort in this visual novel (not so much a game at times, in that it limits your options) but it falls short at times. The limited options and the general feel of the game doesn't really capture depression as it does teenage angst. I wouldn't recommend this to anyone who would want to understand the feelings of anyone with Depression.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2016
												A game that you play as a man who is depressive. It's just texts and you need to make a choice after you read it. There are several options you can choose and your choices affects to your development. There are 3 sentences after every text except choiceless texts. These sentences describes how is your mood or how you are now. But there is something diffrent. Firts of all i realized that the choices which is at the most bottom ones make you feel more and more deppressive whenever you choose them. And the toppest choices (i mean every first choice) are closed at the start of the game but if you keep select the toppest choice your stress level decrease and first selections opens. For me, this system make the game easier. If developers mixed these selections it would be more complex and good. The other thing that i found weird is our character's girlfriend. The game says that our character has social anxiety, so how he made a girlfriend. Maybe we can say the girlfriend found our character, not our character found her. Then it's okay with me. There are at least two endings which depends on your choices. But as what i said the choices are ordered from best to worst. Anyways it is a good game to play to play. By the way there is no saving feature.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												I went through the whole story once and I must admit it felt quite close to actually being depressed. Having been depressed some time ago myself, I think it is a genuinely good effort by the developers, and a very important one for that matter. One of the problems with depression is the external feedback as it is generally one of rejection, specially for anyone going to therapy or under medication. Depression quest aims at trying to share the emotions and inner workings of this condition, making it more understandable to people that have not experience it. More than a game, this is an a guided text story in which situations unfold differently depending on the answers given in each situation.

Product received for free
												So me and 2 others played this game together, here are all our opinions:Friend 1: It was good.Friend 2: Listening to it was a nice expreience (I read aloud and we made the decision as a group)Me: I thought the game was very well played out, and even though it was kind of easy to reach a good ending, it kept me entertained for an hour. I would rate this game 9/10. Its only issue is that it kind of has low replayability, once you reach a good ending you can't really go again. Another nitpick is that it was depressing to play/read, but it really opened my eyes to what people with  depression face. If you have the spare time, make sure to download and play this game.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2014
												This is not a game, it's simply a 'choose your own adventure' novel... but the well timed drama involving Zoe Quinn just leaves nothing but a sour taste in the mouth, and I'm compelled to write something about that. It's obvious that the community didn't want this initially, otherwise it would've made the cut on Greenlight to begin with... Basically this release is the result of a long string of industry related sex-scandals, and what happens when a developer sells every single ounce of their moral integrity in order to make their dream a reality, and in the process involves themselves with people able to help her out with that dream, but also lacking any moral integrity themselves.The whole situation is just a huge mess, what we should all do as a responsible gaming community is just ignore all this nonsense, and just let horrible people be their horrible selves without having to suffer any bs. If only that were the case here...Some might say that this is merely the fault of the people involved, and shouldn't reflect too badly on the end result, but you have to remember, it was their choice to make all of this public, one idiot made the initial push to get the 'news' out there, and then the other idiot brings this to attention on her public social media accounts, so that we're all caught up in the drama and arguing our own points on the matter when in truth, the only idiots who have any say in the matter are Zoe Quinn, the alleged five dudes she was banging while still involved in a relationship, and the first idiot I mentioned who was her boyfriend.They are all stupid idiots who we shouldn't be enabling, but we are regardless of what we say about them at this point because the damage has already been done, they've gotten out of this exactly what they all needed and we're all suckers for giving it to them..So in conclusion, do not play this game if you just want to get a better understanding of the current drama, those people are not worth your time. If however you want to get a better understanding of how to use depression as a mechanic in something that almost resembles a video game, or want an idea of how to present a character with depression, then that should be the only time you consider downloading this.Do not let them use you.-B.Fitz

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												I found this game while searching for games with overwhelmingly negative reviews. I wasnt really sure what to expect, but it was free and I had nothing to loose. My initial thoughts were "wow who makes a game about depression" and "lol when my friends see me playing this♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; I ended up really liking this game tho. Not that depression is fun but the fact that your choices affected you in different ways. I saw a review that read something like "this is kinda a slap in the face, I have depression" and at first I kinda agreed but there was nothing that really bashed on depression or made light or fun of it. Not that the people who made this game are 100% right but the morale of the story is to fight depression instead of letting it keep you from living. Not many people would go and google "what is depression and why should I be considerate of other people". I think putting this in the form of a game like this can really help open the eyes of someone who otherwise wouldnt care. with that said this game is probably not for people with depression. I do not have depression and I understand that the developers of this game probably meant well however I can also understand how it might make someone with depression a little offended. to name a few things, the title of the game, the fact that it is portraied as a game, and scratched out choices etc. For me it wasnt really a game it was a novel with a branching plot about depression, and that is what it should be advertised as. NOT as a game and probably with a different title With that said I do not reccomend it because even though I liked it and feel as though they got there point across, the "game" is advertised as something it is not and for all intents and purposes I think whether you have depression or not this "game" should be avoided and pushed under the rug as on of those things that even though the devs meant well it was still a mistake.

												You know, most games that arent entertanment to me, I dont really care for, but this game even thougth it is very boring, and someone inaccrute, I believe that this game was created to get the word out about depression. This is a very tuff game to play. Warning you that. Dont play unless you think you can handle it. Very ruff read. Its like doing a maze, and just running around in circles. This games objective was to get the word out about depression, thougth may not have been done in the proper way, the way this game leaves you feeling, allows you to get a glimpse at how someone that suffers from this feels, 20% of people suffer from some form of depression, the 80% need to help them, and make them feel acceppted and happy. Btw, this is not a how to get out of depression, if so, id be a bit insulted about that, its not easy for people to come out of depression, and its never a cut and dry situtation. If you suffer from depression, you should reach out to a professional, or if you're a teen, reach out to a parent and/or teacher, that can help you contact a professional. This game, is designed, for a goal, and I believe it is impossible to describe depression, and that this is the best attempt/outreach about depression.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
												As much as I can recognise some of the situations and reactions in this title, I can't help but feel that this is more of a way for the author to cope than to let others understad. Reading through it once won't take you long so you might as well since some choices actually were striking. If the subject matter and the emotions are interesting you shouldn't bother with this, though. There are plenty of great books out there, read one of those. And no, you don't need a multiple choice type fiction game to drive home the point that depression cancels out your ability to make choices. Its only real quality is handling a subject that isn't handled often, really. Had it been a more common subject no one would have cared about this level writing / decision making.

I'd give it a 7/10, a taste of depression but a rather superficial one but also taking into account something like this couldn't be too realistic/lengthy without being too much for most. content:
Posted: August 28, 2014
												It certainly isn't an amazing piece of engineering genius; it's basically a set of hyperlinks. I played for 0.3 hours and won, which is my biggest qualm about it. The choices in the text were obvious:-"Tell GF you love her" or "Tell GF you hate her"-"Talk to brother" or "sit and do nothing"-"See therapist about depression" or "don't see therapist about depression"-"Take cat to cure depression" or "I hate cats"Thing is, the game starts off saying that you're depressed, so of course you're going to want to fix it. You can't explicitly say "YOU ARE CURRENTLY DEPRESSED" and expect someone to take the depressing route. Say something like "You're tired and it doesn't sound like you'd have fun drinking with your coworkers" or "Your girlfriend doesn't sound like she's being honest", stuff like that.Bonus point for the subplot where IM friend gets cheated on. It's like it's based on real life or something. Zing.2/5, wouldn't play again; would recommend others try once while still free. I really hope no one paid money for this.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												There are a lot of things wrong with depression quest. How the game tells it's story is though text based narrative and player "choices". Unfortunately as the developer clearly have a set story they want to tell none of the choices feel like they matter. An argument could be made that this is exactly how individuals suffering from clinical depression feel. The problem is that the player does not feel this emotion so much as it is forced upon them. The game feels clumsy and heavy handed as a result.Why the recommendation then? This game does do soemthing right in that, even though the excecution is far from perfect, it tries to tacle a topic not dealt with in many games: depression. The aspect of feeling closed in is indicative of the condition and comes through in spades in narration portions. It's free, which is also a plus. Finally the recommendation comes in hopes of more developers wading into difficult topics within the human condition to bring players more interactive experiences worth having.

Posted: August 22, 2014
												i give it a lukewarm recommendation, since the only thing i spent on it was time it was certainly worth what i paid. i guess the main reason my opinion isn't very high is that it's not much of a game, interesting conceptiual piece to be sure, and honestly seems well researched.the problem is in the exposition. it's all exposition. i think a message just as powerful could have been delivered with a lot less fluff, given that i got a good 'ending' (i know the game doesn't really end) by only reading the first and last paragraphs of every page. it could use a little more show and a little less tell i guessi'd give it 6/10 on the standard game scale, an 8/10 on the indie scale, and a 9/10 on the art scale. worth playing, but receiving massive penalties for the low production value on the 'game' aspects, but the portrayal of depressive mentality was good enough to compensate on a concept level.the caveat to the portrayal is that the main character is kinda boring, the same way mario is, to be relatable to anyone they are a 20 something disappointed with life, with a disappointing job, disappointing love life, and a 'project' which gets no name. sure, i can relate to that, but it doesn't make me actually invest myself in the game because i'm not doing the work for you, i want you to make me want to get invested in the character, not just bait my own narcissism into making me preserve my own avatar's life

content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												I like that the game's authors tried to include as many people as possible by making terms gender neutral. Technically, this game could be pulled off entirely on a website with an appropriate hyperlink scheme. Based on other comments and reviews that I've read, the content is personal enough that people can relate, and it seems the authors conformed to modern thinking with regard to psychological treatment in an attempt to not mislead anyone who may be suffering from depression (you don't reject taking medication and go on a caribbean cruise meeting the guy/gal of your dreams, for example, or anything fancifully romantic). It's a game. It's worth playing just to experience what the authors see as the progression of life choices and how they might affect someone internally.

												I tried to like this game, but I feel like it misses the point of making an interacting [non]fiction. I understand that the atmosphere is supposed to be oppressive and, well, depressing  - and the game has that down to a T. However, there's no excuse for a game or interactive experience to be so UNENGAGING. This game made me want to shut it off after three pages of text, it felt like a chore, I felt like I was playing it for the game and not for myself. Nothing made me curious about what was going to happen next, and nothing made me want to continue. Worse still, it misses the essential trouble of depression: there isn't an escape. Escape from this boring e-book is always two clicks away! I've played games, read books, listened to music, and watched films that have made me absolutely miserable, but I've always been compelled to continue 'til the end. This game had me back on my desktop in half an hour.
