content:
Posted: August 28, 2014
												It certainly isn't an amazing piece of engineering genius; it's basically a set of hyperlinks. I played for 0.3 hours and won, which is my biggest qualm about it. The choices in the text were obvious:-"Tell GF you love her" or "Tell GF you hate her"-"Talk to brother" or "sit and do nothing"-"See therapist about depression" or "don't see therapist about depression"-"Take cat to cure depression" or "I hate cats"Thing is, the game starts off saying that you're depressed, so of course you're going to want to fix it. You can't explicitly say "YOU ARE CURRENTLY DEPRESSED" and expect someone to take the depressing route. Say something like "You're tired and it doesn't sound like you'd have fun drinking with your coworkers" or "Your girlfriend doesn't sound like she's being honest", stuff like that.Bonus point for the subplot where IM friend gets cheated on. It's like it's based on real life or something. Zing.2/5, wouldn't play again; would recommend others try once while still free. I really hope no one paid money for this.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												Depression Quest isn't that bad, really. I think it stands up on its own really well. I've held judgment of it because I never bothered to install it, but taking the leap to click play is one I'm glad I took. While the story itself is highly cliche and likes to play into a very simple monologue, it does give you a feeling of uncertainty as to what will happen with the decisions you make and what decision you will have to make next. As someone who suffers from clinical depression, I did find that it was somewhat accurate in the descriptions of how it feels to be depressed, to go to a therapist, and be on various medications to "cure" yourself. Regardless of the controversy behind the creator of the game, Depression Quest does a decent job of telling a story about a real life issue. Whether or not one can classify this as a "game" is a completely different topic, but it is a rather interesting way to engage an audience through a different medium than ones that are more commonly used (like speeches, books, etc.). In my mind, there's no difference between Depression Quest and visual novels, because neither is focused on the typical aspects of a video game like graphics, gameplay, or performance. Rather, it wants you to invest your time much like you would with reading a novel. It is only a matter of what medium Quinn uses to convey the story.Overall, you shouldn't expect much out of this title. It took me exactly 52 minutes to complete the story. However, you shouldn't be expecting a whitewash, cut-and-paste tale about how depression is bad and how it can affect you. If you do choose to install Depression Quest, I would recommend you to not go in expecting a triple A-class story, but you also should not be expecting a narrative that wants you to hold pity for the protagonist. I would rate the overall experience of Depression Quest a decent 6 out of 10. The story is flat in some parts, and many other parts seem to be shoehorned in for no apparent reason; however, the writing is eloquent enough for you to hold interest long enough to complete the story. For those reasons, I recommend the product.

												There are a lot of things wrong with depression quest. How the game tells it's story is though text based narrative and player "choices". Unfortunately as the developer clearly have a set story they want to tell none of the choices feel like they matter. An argument could be made that this is exactly how individuals suffering from clinical depression feel. The problem is that the player does not feel this emotion so much as it is forced upon them. The game feels clumsy and heavy handed as a result.Why the recommendation then? This game does do soemthing right in that, even though the excecution is far from perfect, it tries to tacle a topic not dealt with in many games: depression. The aspect of feeling closed in is indicative of the condition and comes through in spades in narration portions. It's free, which is also a plus. Finally the recommendation comes in hopes of more developers wading into difficult topics within the human condition to bring players more interactive experiences worth having.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
												A very accurate portrayal of Depression.  While it is debatable whether this can be considered a game, it does it's job well.  You read through a story describing the life of someone suffering from depression, life seems ok at first, they have a decent job, friends and a life partner. But the whole point of this 'game' is that ANYONE can suffer from depression.   You're are given multiple choices to progress, with the option someone without depression could do crossed out, such as:  You're feeling heavy from the stress of how far behind you are on your work, the thought of doing it makes your breathing short and heart heavy. Normally, you would just bunker down and do the work but, for someone suffering from Depression it just isnt an option so you have to make do with what little options are left.   This 'game' isnt for everyone and it is not for fun.  It is here to give others that do not suffer from depression, an insight into what it is really like and to give true understand of how hard it can truly be.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
												I'm not really certain what to say about this game. . .It certainly isn't enjoyable.  That's not to say that it's bad.  Far from it.  The game just has a certain appeal that I think we're only used to finding in other types of art; ideas and feelings that are uncomfortable to confront.  This was one of those games that wasn't easy for me to get through, especially considering the past two years have been a maelstrom of major depressive bouts.  Fair warning that there are a lot of self indulgent comparisons here that might get tiresome to read, but I'm going to be blatant in my honesty.This is the most accurate depiction of depression that I've ever witnessed in any type of art form.  It's often glorified in commercials and television as a fast burning sadness that will immediately end in suicide.  My friends, the road to hell doesn't smell like sulfur, and it's not painted in varying intensities of reds.  This road drones on endlessly, painted in grays and browns with a bleached white sky overhead promising a storm that never comes.  That's what depression is really like, and this game brilliantly depicts the overwhelming nothingness that silently attempts to destroy everything that you've ever loved.(This should really be referred to as a depression simulator.)Although I took a little issue with the often droning nature of the writing (Stemming from a style choice. . .perhaps?), I appreciate the effort that was taken in creation.  You can tell that the fruits of the end product were made from a labor of love.  Everything about this title screams at the top of its lungs why we need to support Indie developers more and more in the coming years.  These experimental pieces of gaming provide a strange kind of joy and a level of empathy that I don't often find in games where I stalk random industrial corridoors, blowing every single living creature away that opposes my color coordinated team.  Combined with the fact that this title is available for the incredibly low, low price of FREE, you've got yourself a winner.Play/Experience it.  Now.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 1, 2015
												Most of the time, we think of video games as "fun". They often have stories, sometimes involved and emotional stories, but in general video games are generally escapism or competition of one form or another. Depression Quest, on the other hand, admits up front that it is *not* "fun". It's an attempt to communicate how depression feels and impacts someone's life, and I believe that it succeeds admirably in that.The game itself is short -- a little over an hour, depending on your reading speed -- but in that time it puts you in the shoes of someone who is dealing with depression. The story is told in text, with branching dialog trees at various points, similar to "Choose your own adventure" books or other interactive fiction. The clever thing they do at various points is to list various options, but then remove them. In most games that feature branching dialog, the good/bad/snarky options are generally very clear; BioWare is (in)famous for this. In Depression Quest, too, there are clear "right" choices and answers, and the game will show them to you, but they may be crossed out and unavailable based on your mental state. This simple mechanic is brilliant, as it accurately models how depression can feel; you know what the "right" thing to do is, but you just can't seem to do it.If you want to know more about how depression feels, or if you're trying to understand or help someone who may be dealing with depression, this game is well worth your time.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
												Playing the Depression quest isn't going to be a riveting experience, but that's not the point of the game.  It's meant to teach you how people who suffer from depression think and might react to the world.  It's a text based adventure and the choices given to you might seem like the best choice, but as it turns out you won't really know unless you try out every choice and you can see the best choice but it's crossed out and unable to be chosen because depression makes choices that seem so easy unbelievably difficult.  Don't let your decision to play this game be based upon someone saying it isn't a game or the horrible news about the developer.  It's a game meant to educate you and it does a great job.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 21, 2014
												I'm going to recommend this game, although barely.  I'll break it down into pros and cons:Pros:This game does a fairly good job of putting the player into the shoes and mind of someone with clinical depression.  A lot of the descriptions in this game hit home for me.  Although I disliked the characters at first, they started to grow on me over time.  Cons:The game makes it WAY too easy to make the right choices.  The biggest problem with depression is that it robs the sufferer of the motivation or ability to make good decisions.  On my first playthrough, I ended up fixing pretty much all of the main character's problems.  Yes, there are attempts to try and describe the precarious mental state and constant danger of backsliding, but it's just too easy to click on the equivalent of "suck it up and do the hard thing" every single time.Also, the structure of this game just isn't very engaging.  It's basically a choose-your-own-adventure story, with the added mechanic that the character's current level of depression may lock out certain choices.If you want a game that truly captures the hopelessness of deep depression, I can't recommend "Actual Sunlight" highly enough.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2015
												Most of the time, we think of video games as "fun". They often have stories, sometimes involved and emotional stories, but in general video games are generally escapism or competition of one form or another. Depression Quest, on the other hand, admits up front that it is *not* "fun". It's an attempt to communicate how depression feels and impacts someone's life, and I believe that it succeeds admirably in that.The game itself is short -- a little over an hour, depending on your reading speed -- but in that time it puts you in the shoes of someone who is dealing with depression. The story is told in text, with branching dialog trees at various points, similar to "Choose your own adventure" books or other interactive fiction. The clever thing they do at various points is to list various options, but then remove them. In most games that feature branching dialog, the good/bad/snarky options are generally very clear; BioWare is (in)famous for this. In Depression Quest, too, there are clear "right" choices and answers, and the game will show them to you, but they may be crossed out and unavailable based on your mental state. This simple mechanic is brilliant, as it accurately models how depression can feel; you know what the "right" thing to do is, but you just can't seem to do it.If you want to know more about how depression feels, or if you're trying to understand or help someone who may be dealing with depression, this game is well worth your time.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2015
												This is essentially a choose your path story. Ok, so not really a game... but a piece of interactive fiction. There is a lot of text to read, at least the first play through. You are presented with a variety of options, but choosing some may cause later actions to be crossed off. This is interesting, but it sucks a lot of interactivity out. I also don't like the medicate moral that I think this story is pushing. I also think that it provides an incredibly narrow portrait of depression. I respect that, because it doesn't need to. It's the portrait of a single static character rather than a dynamic one that morphs around the player.  I think that using a more dynamic character scheme would have increased replayability, however, I'm not going to count that against the game. The problem lies in the way it quickly degrades into cynically clicking the remaining available options. After the first 2-4 reads, you realize that very little changes with each play through except the ending. The ending only changes depending on choices. There is nothing to encourage a player to see all the endings or to try new combinations. Maybe there isn't supposed to be. I don't know.There are some spelling and grammar issues, but having been an avid interactive fiction player I've noticed that that isn't uncommon. I note this because a lot of reviewers bring it up. Sure, they could update it with better spelling and grammar. Or they could move on to another project. Most choose that latter and it's not a bad choice. Most interactive fiction isn't professional, but made free to play by hobbyists for hobbyists. Does the game achieve the goal of creating the atmosphere or portraying a singular portrait of depression? I'd say yes. Others might and do disagree. I wouldn't say it is the best at portraying depression. Calunio's Depression is probably the best representation I've seen. A major difference is perhaps that this game gives us a character that is incredibly human. We see her as human and as another individual entity, but we achieve only the closeness of an onlooker. Calunio's Depression works by giving us a shell of character and starts with conception. In black and white, the player must slowly and painfully grind to walk a short jaunt to the boss. You win, but he curses you so that with every new screen you arrive, you lose experience. Every new scene causes an exponentially greater experience loss. Meanwhile, you are questioned on the nature of happiness, and no matter how hard you attempt to level, you are never the strongest. Before you lies a tower that seems impossible to climb, a final challenge. Can you reach the end before your curse overwhelms you? Depression Quest may portray a story of a depressed lady, but Calunio's Depression gives out a depressing atmosphere drags you into it (for good or ill.) The powerlessness felt between these to games are incredibly different in both nature and magnitude. At the end, I'd merely say Depression Quest is heavily flawed. I wouldn't recommend it to most people I know. It is free though, so maybe try it sometime. Choose for yourself.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
												I'm disappointed in this 'game'. If I wanted to know what a person feels when they're living with depression, I would ask as I have several times before. The concept is somewhat interesting, but the story is just bland; an overall waste of my time. [I don't need flashing lights, loud noises, mainstream music or gunfights to get my attention, much less entertain me, just wanted to throw that out there.] I know the crossed out options for making things better is an attempt to show people without depression how depressed people (may) feel, but it gets tiring when after a while the main characer does just about nothing to actually help themself. The character is over-analytical, and I got the feeling ever so often that they didn't want hope, that they didn't care for a chance to get better. Even if that's what depression can do to a person, a simple attempt to feel better about themself or their position in life should at least be an option, even if the end result is no change for the character. Whether or not the people who made this game wanted an immersive feeling to be had by those playing it, text and a few photos does nothing to grab my interest. Illustrations and a change in the characters' appearances (from third person or the main character's point of view) would have made this much more interesting of an experience. Instead I am stuck watching a person feel sorry for themself. This is not what a game is for. There has to be a goal, a reward or have rising action, a climax and a resolution - a reason to go on, and I see none after clicking 'next' 15 times. The options to make things 'progress' or make things better in this story sound like the kind of things someone would THINK a depressed person would do. If it means anything to Isaac, the repetative piano music kinda made me want to kill myself. I'm not sure if that's what was being aimed for, but man, bad music is one of my dozens of triggers - including triggers - and got me more into the game, but still not very much.I give this an overall 2/10 - the 2 is me being generous, and I'm not sure if I should be.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
												It's an interesting experiment but I'm not sure it achieves what it sets out for. In most cases it nicely describes the thoughts and moods of a depressed person but I feel like it's too simple. For someone that struggles with the illness it may seem oversimplified and "too easy" to get out of the severely depressed state in the game... you know what option you need to click (even when the ones naturally available for healthy people are crossed out, which is a nice touch) to possibly better your situation but for someone depressed it's not this clear. Also, although the creators do note this at the beginning, this particular character is in a very good environment (even if their job is not satisfying) because basically everyone supports them eventually and they can affort treatment and medication. So I'm not sure the game succeeds in what it tries to do. The idea is not bad and some of the descriptions are on point but the gameplay and the options lack in representing the difficulties and intricacies of the subject... which would be the reason to make a "game" such as this in the first place. I do recommend it if you are interested in the topic but don't expect too much from it.

												Honestly, I have been dealing with chronic depression for a good amount of my life. The game in and of itself attempted to relate to some and much of the generic issues brought up within a "depressed" person's life and they were quite relatable, but at some points it seems quite unrealistic and blunt. It wasn't a bad experience per say, but it feels as if the game shoe horns you into choosing the generic and or bad choice. Also the generic melancholy music and static felt like it was trying too hard to set the mood in my opinion. I ended up succeeding in game possibly getting a good ending, but i still didn't feel all too satisfied. Not a bad game, nor am I going into the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ background of it and its developer, but eh it wasn't as heavy as some people would expect it to be. 												Depression Quest is extremely realistic. I played through answering questions as if I was actually dealing with those situations. And, as someone who has dealt with depression all her life, I found that my answers reflected how I've actually felt before. As a result, I became profoundly depressed, and that limited what I could choose for answers. That aspect is especially realistic. When you are truly depressed, your mind can go blank and you lose the will to do things. Beautiful, realistic game. If you don't have depression, but want to know what those who do have it are going through, play this game. It's a fantastic example and can really give you an insight you didn't know you needed.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2016
												From what I've seen so far, Depression Quest seems to represent depression quite accurately--it feels inescapable, hopeless, and almost impossible to communicate to other people without feeling like a burden. It has ups and downs, and no matter how hard you try, there's no way out. As far as the writing goes, it goes. It's simple and effective language that says what needs to be said. No poetry or anything like that--none needed.Choices are (sometimes humorously) limiting based on how a depressed person thinks and feels, which is a good method of teaching players about that kind of lifestyle.Overall, good depiction of depression, nice writing, nice mechanics. Don't care about the background development or subsequent controversy--this is actually seems like a decent game.

That's what a relationship offers you, so unless you have REALLY persistent friends or family, then youll be stuck.It would be an AMAZING expansion to have a hardcore difficutly [what is this Halo? YOU CASUAL!] where you dont have a girlfrined [or even better you just lost her], your parents are oblivious to your depression, no therapist, and your friends arent persistent to give you help. Digging yourself out of this would be a real challenge.Also, im not sure if this is implimented, but a few choices could also have a few perma perks or hinderences like how getting a cat adds the option of playing with it. Such as if you try to down the cup of whisky to "loosen up" for your girlfriend, you might develop alcoholism. Or if you Chose not to do work and not get motivation to continue working, you might be without a job and furthermore, without a place to live O.O idk, something i just thought about.9.5/10 [cuz if felt a bit short but definalty a good read for a hour]

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2016
												Over all, this game creates a pretty accurate depiction of the kind of depression that I myself have faced; a state where literally nothing seems to help you get better, no matter what you do. The game does a pretty good job of showing what simply being medicated can do for a person experiencing depression. It doesn't cure depression by any means, but it helps a lot. The element of having some options crossed as unaccessable is a good reperesentation of wanting to do things but being unable to do them.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2016
												Honestly, I have been dealing with chronic depression for a good amount of my life. The game in and of itself attempted to relate to some and much of the generic issues brought up within a "depressed" person's life and they were quite relatable, but at some points it seems quite unrealistic and blunt. It wasn't a bad experience per say, but it feels as if the game shoe horns you into choosing the generic and or bad choice. It did well locking away the freedoms of choice one would have when experiencing depression and I appreciate that, but at times I was just bored and unimmersed with how it portrays it. Also the generic melancholy music and static felt like it was trying too hard to set the mood in my opinion. I ended up succeeding in game possibly getting a good ending, but i still didn't feel all too satisfied. Not a bad game, nor am I going into the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ background of it and its developer, but eh it wasn't as heavy as some people would expect it to be. It's worth like 1 playthru at best, do with it what you will.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2016
												Depression Quest is extremely realistic. I played through answering questions as if I was actually dealing with those situations. And, as someone who has dealt with depression all her life, I found that my answers reflected how I've actually felt before. As a result, I became profoundly depressed, and that limited what I could choose for answers. That aspect is especially realistic. When you are truly depressed, your mind can go blank and you lose the will to do things. Beautiful, realistic game. If you don't have depression, but want to know what those who do have it are going through, play this game. It's a fantastic example and can really give you an insight you didn't know you needed.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2016
												Depression Quest is a very well thought out and realistic game. Many, if not all, of the parts of this story are completely relatable. The way the protagonist thinks and acts are ways that i would in this situation as well. In every group of options, I was never forced to answer one way or the other. One answer just seemed to stand out because it is exactly the way i would react in a situation like that. The protagonist's emotions are well spoken and it is easy to see what he is going through and how it is effecting his life. I am very empathetic for this main character. Overall this game is really good, if you like being spoken to on a personal level.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

It does give away for those who don't have depression to receive a sense of what it is like for those who do. I can say what I have played it has made what it wants to portray clear enough, through its descriptions of situations, relaying what the protagonist is feeling to the player and making the decisions fit with the narrative. In that way, the game is recommended to those who want to know what it's like to have depression, but it offers very little aside from that.

												The game really does touch on the subject of depression very well. It gives you that feeling down in your stomach when the world is falling apart. It makes you think about your own life. After playing this game my heart feels heavy and that is probably a side effect of playing a game like this. The story felt real as if you could see it all play out. It made you think about your own emotions as well as the character's. If you feel like you made a bad decision you can feel the reprocutions of it. This game really does hit you hard and I don't recommend playing it if you have depression.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2016
												From what I've seen so far, Depression Quest seems to represent depression quite accurately--it feels inescapable, hopeless, and almost impossible to communicate to other people without feeling like a burden. It has ups and downs, and no matter how hard you try, there's no way out. As far as the writing goes, it goes. It's simple and effective language that says what needs to be said. No poetry or anything like that--none needed.Choices are (sometimes humorously) limiting based on how a depressed person thinks and feels, which is a good method of teaching players about that kind of lifestyle.Overall, good depiction of depression, nice writing, nice mechanics. Don't care about the background development or subsequent controversy--this is actually seems like a decent game.

number of helpful: 14 of 30 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 1, 2014
												I played this game during my psychiatry placement at med school to see how it corresponded with our teaching on depression, as well as to compare it to interviews I had seen and conducted with diagnosed depressive patients.This game is spot on in accurately depicting depression, as well as the stigma of mental illness. I have recommended it to my colleagues who are also on psychiatry.The warning at the start is not to be ignored. I have suffered mild depressive episodes in the past and by the end of this game you will feel lower than when you started (even if you get the "good" ending like me!) However, if you know someone suffering from depression or just want to know more about it, it takes under an hour to get through so broaden your horizons!

content:

												As many of you know, this game is being bashed by most users, simply because of the controversy surrounding Zoe Quinn. If you are willing to try this, I want you to not think about the war that's happening on the internet. I'll be honest: Depression Quest is not really a game, it's not something that you'll have fun with, it's just something else. Something that you have to see with your own eyes. I recommend it. number of helpful: 9 of 20 people (45%) found this review helpful14 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 21, 2015
												So it was 5:30 am for me on a tuesday morning when i stumbled across a artistic beauty of a game called Depression Quest. Through the expansion of my journey i found that the game was to teach and give players a feel of what its like to have Depressioon. Upon downloading and launching the game I was ever so graciously greeted with a "(not responding)" message that some games naturally have upon launch. Once i had reached the title screen i was intruduced to the most enlightening piano music i have possibly ever heard in my life. Instinctively I started playing skipping the controls and other useless information. The first page alone had way to much dialogue so naturally i was all "wow nope" and went straight to the options. Without any idea of what my options were actually affecting I picked the most negative one i could. Since everyone knows depression is a fake disease the only possitive choice I made was adopting a cat so I could officially become a cat man. Then I proceded to dump my girl friend Alex so i could oficially be a lonely cat man. I then decided that my love for cats was greater than that of myself. So in this process i realized the only reason I hate myself is because im a male. Finally I ended the game by becoming a flaming male feminist who wanted to eliminate all other males, and once done. Commit suicide. I ended the game with a personal high score of 420 Depression Points which i then cashed in at the arcade shop for a stuffed slice of pizza. Great game over all. Would play again

												Don't let the reviews dissuade you. this is a really well thought out story. number of helpful: 8 of 18 people (44%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												DQ is billed as interactive fiction but it's more a branching decision tree given the game's subject matter. The writing is unornamental and matter-of-fact. Though I don't personally suffer the condition, I related the experiences in this game to those I know that have, and I found it's dozen or so vignettes to be very powerful and very saddening at times. Perhaps the one real weakness of the medium is it's hard to make decision you know will later impact the story negatively, even if I felt these would have been more likely in the circumstances.I can't say I enjoyed playing Depression Quest but I nevertheless recommend it.

content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
												Depression Quest is a great game if you're depressed. Or even if you're not. In many ways, this game can help you understand how depressed people see the world, and conversely, how people in a depressed person's world see them, and the issues surrounding them. It really can. I was skeptical until I played through it a few times with different mindsets just how good it is at pinpointing the struggles a depressed individual might encounter, but it really is quite good at exactly that. The different choices that open up to you as you heal or decline further are very eye-opening. Whether the struggle is dealing with anxiety in friendships or simply trying to haul your butt out of bed in the morning, this game is a serious must-play for everyone.

number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												As someone who's still in the beginning stages of trying to treat their depression, this voiced a lot of my worries and concerns over the last few years.  As I read through, I did identify with a lot of the "excuses" the protagonist felt he was giving and the negative feedback loops.Most of the user reviews for this game have been to Not Recommend it.  Some of the players have, themselves, been struggling with depression and feel this wasn't an accurate representation.  For me, it was.  Maybe just because I'm still at the beginning of trying to figure out what it actually affects in my life and what it doesn't -- what I'm "whining about" versus what's actually a result of the depression -- trying to figure out what and how meds and counselling could/should fit in -- trying to figure out (and fight myself on) what my friends/family "actually" think/do about it (though, I will say, I am lucky to have a lot of support).It's disappointing to me that so many people felt that this narative was so ... "offensive" (for lack of a better term) or misrepresentative.  I, personally, want to recommend this to the people in MY circles, just to say "Look.  This has been me."  However, I do understand how this may not be everyone's story and how others' struggles show themselves.

number of helpful: 5 of 12 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 6, 2014
												I can't claim that "Depression Quest" is the best thing around. A lot of the writing is filled with grammatical errors and the option to undo a choice kind of negates what the intended message of the game is. But living with depression isn't something that is easy to convey and it's hard to say what would be the best way to communicate depression to people who have never experienced it.Having lived with depression, I see a lot of my own personality reflected in the main character. Most of the choices are things I've thought of myself and the way in which the game crosses off the "good" choices is very effective in making one realize that positivity is usually present but dismissed to someone with depression.Some of the endings are real downers, but there always seems to be the prospect of hope if you look deep enough. Nothing with depression is easy, especially taking the first step towards treatment. The game properly conveys that outside influences are often required and even reluctantly seeking help may lead to a better future.To any of the people worrying about the lack of traditional "gameplay," realize that "Depression Quest" is not meant to be an action-platformer or first-person shooter. This is simply ideas being related in a different format to people who would have otherwise ignored them. I can't say that I read a lot of novels, but I do love reading within digital confines.At the end of the day, trying to encapsulate a depressing life is hard to do for people without depression.  People suffering with depression aren't the types with some weird illness or psychosis. They are average people who just happen to get bogged down by things to a stronger degree. "Depression Quest" gets that idea across and it does it for free. Why would you pass the opportunity to expand your mind a little simply because there is no gameplay?

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 17, 2014
												WHY ARE YOU READING THE REVIEWS? Seriously, for the most part, they're worse than YouTube comments, they're written by the same kind of people, and with the same amount of careful thought and consideration. So that should tell you something.Anyway, here's my real review: It's an interactive story. And while it is not exhaustive on the topic of depression (by the developers' own admission), it does educate on the subject. I really do think that people who really don't understand what depression is like, but want to change that, will benefit from this.As one who does understand, I felt for the character (myself?) as I played. I worried. I chose honest answers and got pretty accurate results. I played through it several times. It made me realize some of the dumb mistakes I actively make and how I justify them to myself. I started a freaking notebook in Evernote just to write down what I was learning from this.Again, it's not exhaustive. I would honestly have liked to have seen more. But it's free, and it's an attempt to venture into uncharted waters with the medium. It's a discussion starter. It's good.

												As someone who has only recently started to look into getting help for my own depression, I have to say that this has been a very special experience for me. I know that what I'm going through isn't quite at the level of what's described in the game, but I absolutely know what it's like to feel so completely lost, worthless, and alone that you feel like you can't go on with normal day to day life. I'm glad Depression Quest exists. I'm glad that Zoey, Patrick and Isaac put this together. I can read about depression all day long and it won't mean a thing, but this isn't just reading. This is an experience. This means something, something I understood, something I've experienced. I feel like everyone should take a look at Depression Quest at least once.

												As much as I hate Zoe, I put those feelings aside and actually played the "game".It's more like a choose your own adventure book than a game, you can't lose.Having said that, here are my thoughts.It portrays someone struggling with depression and (possibly, as taken from context) Social Anxiety. I'd say the Main Character has a vague description on purpose, and whose issues are not very specific, so you are able to easily project yourself onto him/her.You could argue that it generalizes depression, but it delves into what is probably the "most common scenario", which is appropriate.As someone with Severe Social Anxiety, I do not have a problem with the game itself. I do not think it helped "get over" my issues, which frankly would be ridiculous that a single game could do it, but I do find that it can help people understand depression just a little bit better and how hard it can be to break the downward spiral.It's not for everyone, nor is it meant to be.I give it a "Thumbs up" and give it the title of "Not Sucky", even if i personally disagree with the views and actions on the creator.Also, to all the people who wrote the joke reviews, ♥♥♥♥ Off.

												5GB&FWith that out of the way, Depression Quest is still an enjoyable experience. The game is about half an hour long on a single playthrough, and you can extend this to about an hour if you feel like exploring everything (not something I'd recommend).The game provides a decent narrative, and the lack of images forces you to image the scenario happening instead. The crossed-out options when progressing in the game is an intelligent design choice, as  it blocks out the often most common solution to problems.I recommend it, don't expect anything on the level of Paper's Please, but rather something along the side of Gone Home.

												If you are looking for a fun game, stay away. This game, if you want to call it that, is pretty soulcrushing. number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 1, 2014
												The Good: I wanna start off by listing the good things about this 'game' since everyone seems to be hating on it. For starters, the developer says that this is supposed to be a representation of what life is like living with depression. This does EXACTLY that. The is definitely an accurate description of depression. Zoe hit the nail on the head with this. I think the reason this game is getting so much hate is because 1) she's a woman who has the nerve to make a game with content matter that most would not even dream of touching and 2) she's actually getting attention for this game. It DOES have its problems (which I will list below) but it isn't deserving of the vehement hatred that its getting. The Bad:If you have depression this is gonna put you in a bad mood, especially if its undiagnosed. Reading through this, it forced me to introspectively inspect myself and that isn't something that most people want to do. There are a TON of typos, grammar mistakes, and spelling mistakes. Despite how good the game is, I can't get over those mistakes as it seems like she just simply didn't proofread anything. She claims to have spent a while on this but it makes you wonder what the time was spent on. This is more of an interactive story than a traditional video game. It also isn't a very deep experience. While it accurately describes depression, its only a scratch at the surface of what its like. If you want to know more, you should look up more information about depression. Other stuff: I really advise playing through this with an open mind. This isn't something that is meant to be fun; its meant to get the audience thinking and to bring attention to depression. If you read the other reviews, it apparently fails on getting people to think because all I'm seeing is mindless hatred. I played it to see how accurate it was and what exactly a small team could do to bring this much attention to themselves and depression. It took about an hour to complete one playthrough because of all the reading. You could probably finish it in 3 mins if all you did was read the choices, but then what would be the point of playing the game?I want to stress this again: please keep an open mind when you play through this. It won't make the experience more enjoyable, but it will allow the game to achieve its point and you'll get the most out of your time by doing so.I also want to take a moment to point out that depression is different for everyone. Thats why it is so important to keep an open mind towards this. Even if you have depression, you may disagree that this details what depression is like. I believe this is a representation of Zoe's depression; it feels very much like it was written from a perspective steeped in personal experience.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2014
												Content Warning: Mental Health, Misogyny, SuicideIn the wake of Robin Williams' Death, everybody who speaks English should download and play 'Depression Quest'.It's a free, tiny 'game' on Steam's Downloadable Game service, although it's really a choose-your-own-adventure type of deal. That means you mostly read text, listen to audio, and make decisions on how to move the plot forward. Simple, but it's like looking in a mirror sometimes.It is a harrowing interactive experience that will teach anyone who's depressed that they are not alone (and that they have an illness and deserve treatment). It will teach everyone who's not what depression can be like.I am depressed. Most of the time I think of my general lack of purpose, productivity or motivation as something that makes me an awful person who wouldn't deserve good things, who shouldn't have good friends. On good days I can remember that those are symptoms of depression, and that they are lies.I know this is stilted and ridiculous to say so on social media. I am actually telling you this because there's something else you should know.DQ was also created (mostly) by Zoe Quinn, who is now the target of an online hate campaign that includes slander, misogynistic threats to her safety and hacking of her online accounts. I like to think that by playing Depression Quest, we are showing our support.Again, it's free and only 100 MB download. If you have relatives or friends that are depressed, or you think you might be depressed, please take advantage of this opportunity.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												Depression Quest is an entirely text-based Choose-Your-Own-Adventure game in which you play as You. Well, okay, perhaps not the you You, but someone relatable. You might not have a job that you hate (this You does). You might not have a girlfriend you love, but who gives you intense anxiety (this You does). You might not be accustomed to imagining life without the comfort and convenience of your prehensile tail (this You does not have such a body part, or at least it's not mentioned anywhere in the text). You might not suffer from severe depression. Or you might, I don't know. Either way, this game was intended for every you to play, in the hopes that those suffering from this condition might be able to take some measure of support from it and that those who aren't suffering from it might better understand just how thoroughly depression can undermine someone's entire life.The presentation is simple enough; you are shown a series of days in the life of You, and each day you are given a set of actions to choose from. These range from the healthy (Ignore your bad mood and go out on the town with friends) to the blatantly self-destructive (Stay home and eat Fritos and wish you had more cats), and each choice has repercussions that determine how the story progresses. If you could simply always choose the healthy option, why, you'd probably wind up feeling great and be very successful... but that's not how depression works. Depression saps motivation, drains energy, limits a person, and depending on how depressed you are, your options will be more and more limited, offering you only the Fritos-related story paths. You'll see the healthy, socially-active options, you'll know they're there, but they'll be crossed out - there's no way you could bring yourself to do that. Instead, you get to choose from the remaining options, the leftovers, the coward's-way-outs and the awkward compromises and the lame, humiliating excuses. When it's available, pushing yourself will help you crawl out of your pit, but sometimes it's just not an option.This is a game with some very clear messages about the realities of depression, some of which you may disagree with. Not everyone believes that pharmaceutical options, psych meds, can really help a person. In my experience, it depends on the person, but they can work miracles. Not everyone believes that therapy is a worthwhile expenditure of time. I know that some therapists aren't fit for the job and do more harm than good, but that doesn't mean there aren't caring, intelligent people out there who earnestly want to help. And not everyone believes that their friends care for them, that they can be trusted; sometimes it feels as though the whole world is judging and laughing at you behind your back. But that's not the case, and without that support network of friends and loved ones, the world is a very dark place. I think the messages included here are all beautiful, earnest ones, and I think it's incredibly generous of them to offer the game free-of-charge on Steam; I got more enjoyment out of DQ than I have out of anything in a long while.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 30, 2015
												I've just recently been exposed to text adventure games (this being one of them) and after playing through the whole thing it was pretty well done! I had a good playthrough with mine so this is all coming from my personal experience. (Also anyone who plays this game I highly recommend you do something that cheers you up because it DOES get you down)This game has hit close to home for me, I sympathize with the main protagonist on some levels. I have suffered from depression before and continue to face obstacles because of it. Before writing this review, I've noticed how people say "this doesn't accurately represent what depression is like." Everyone is different. People go through depression differently be it extreme or mild. Besides this game is only giving us a basic idea of what it's like for someone to experience depression in their daily life. It may not have been how YOU experience it but that doesn't make the game completely inaccurate.  Now about the game itself, since you have to make choices in this game I actually appreciate having a "back" option to change your decision. Although there's no button on screen, you simply click the backspace button on your keyboard to go to the previous pages. I enjoyed reading the different outcomes and it helped to decide which route I'd rather take. Depending on the decisions you make, later in the game some of your choices will be scratched out. Often they are choices that may seem simple and the logical thing to do, but it's not that easy for your character who's having neverending battles with his/herself. More choices will be available to you, the player, when you make the right decisions and help your character fight against the depression. I must note that the audio caught my attention. The somber piano music is very mellow and slow. It is played on a loop but it honestly didn't seem repetitive to me. Each page or section in the game has more sound going on depending on the setting. There's a scene where your character is at a party and you can hear jibber jabber and party music all while the piano still plays. I think that's rather clever to keep the piano music. In my opinion it symbolizes the character's depression. The piano music follows the character wherever they go, even in a happy setting, it's always there. After completing this game, I actually do recommend it to others. Anyone who can be triggered easily, play with caution. If you're curious to see what it's like have a go at it. Keep in mind the experience with the protagonists' depression may not be 100% accurate, but it does offer an idea to those who want to understand what it may feel like to be suffering from depression. Don't forget this game can and will make you feel down, so go play some Katamari Damacy or watch cat videos afterwards. =)

												Let me start off by saying, I like this game. I like text-based adventure games, this is my cup of tea. I played through the game a few times making the decisions for this unnamed character, it still tells a good story with an albeit fantasy romance. I do believe that this game effectively communicates what it's like to live with depression. My big complaint with this game and the reason I wouldn't recommend it, is that I don't believe it belongs on a site like Steam. It simply doesn't make any sense that a TEXT game that may be boring to most people who are looking for games with entertainment (at least that's what I look for on Steam) a game like this belongs on a site like Kongregate. But, if you're looking for a game that portrays a person living with depression, this is the game for you which is why it gets a yes.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												I'm starting with the bad: There are a lot of things I felt like could have been done better, the biggest being getting through to the player why the "good" choices are crossed out, because from reading the reviews I feel like a lot of people missed the point. Guys: They're crossed out because of course you're thinking of those options and of course so would someone with depression, but that doesn't mean that you can actually execute those tasks when you're in the throes of it.Also, yes, nothing particularly bad happens to the character, but that's the whole point: depression doesn't have an external cause, just external stimuli that make it worse. In that sense, this is in many ways a solid depiction of depression. It manifests in different way to different people but this is part of why it's so demoralizing and frustrating--you feel like you've had your toenails pulled out one by one when none of what you're dealing with should be that difficult, objectively.While some people have said this should just be a novel or a story, the interactive part of this is critical--the choices you can't make are as important as the ones you can, and the feeling of relative futility equally so.And the stated objective here is to try to communicate this experience to people who haven't been through it, to help people who want to understand just a bit more what this is like to live with. As someone who's fought depression his entire adult life, any effort to that end is an admirable in my mind, especially given how many times I (and many others) have struggled with having the depression conversation with loved ones. It's not Kafka, it's not David Foster Wallace, but so ♥♥♥♥ing what. It's a helpful addition to a conversation many of us have struggled with, imo, and I'm grateful someone took on the task.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												There seems to be alot of hate for this game that is utterly and completely blind and unstructured. Regardless of the circumstances around this game's development, one should never in a review look at anything else than the game. If any of the devs read this id like to thank them for the experience theyve provided me with. This is a work of talent and art, something very unique that hasnt been created before. The depictions of emotions and characters in this game are reflections of real life and i can certainly say with full honesty that 90% is accurate to the last detail. I call ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t on anyone who claims to be struggling with depression saying this game is dumb. Either they are lying, disrespectful morons who take the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of a serious condition, or they are in denial about themselves and i wish them to seriously take a deeper and more truthful look. The presentation of the game is simple and minimalistic, a stark contrast to the maze depression is. It works rather well and doesnt detract from the gameplay experience. The music is spot of with that melancholy and aimless vibe. This is an honest game that deserves attention. It may be more interactive fiction than a fullyfledged game but who cares, it is what it claimes to be. A critisism is the length. I do understand the possible constraints the devs had to work with but if a follow up was created on a much grander scale that can really suck one into the bleak and grey world, it could gain far more worldwide recognition. Finally id like to ask the devs to focus more on the literary aspect. It is beautifully written no doubt but more descriptive elements would solidify the atmosphere. I ask everyone to forget about the controversy behind this game and stop accusing it as "feminist". The game is specifically made to appeal to both men and women, there is nothing propagating a feminist message. Even if it is, why not support rights for women? Nothing wrong with that. Just stop whining and start being objective and open minded. If i had the means id donate to this project, yet sadly all i can do i spread the word and hope reasonable and solid people listen and support the game/work.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 25, 2015
												To get this out of the way, People who are actively depressed and are not seeing a therapist or taking medication should NOT play this game.That being said, I suffer from depression and was diagnosed with Adjustment Disorder and possibly Bipolar Disorder.Playing this game was hard, emotionally. I didn't think that I would have a problem with the issues that the game represented, but it sure got me. It made me re-count a lot of the steps that I had to take to aid my depression and anxiety. I believe that this is an accurate representation of a form of depression, not all forms, but a common form of it. This was an emotional game and definitely got to me, I teared up during some of text, started grinding my teeth, and felt multiple anxious 'heart drops' during the course of the game. It may be short, but it covers a lot of subjets and has what I would think is quite a bit of replay value. I felt like going through the story was completely worth my time and would be for those of you who want to understand what depression is like.I saw a lot of reviews out there about this game, depicting that it's a disgrace or doesn't actually depict depression the right way, they all haven't really played the game or have actually suffered from depression. People have stated that they were diagnosed with 'severe depression' or whatever, 'severe depression' isn't a diagnosis, if you suffered from it, you'd know for sure what you were diagnosed with. Depression is a feeling that people have, everyone has it, it's when it becomes a disorder that is the problem, people get diagnosed with disorders not feelings.Anyways, I reccommend that you guys try it out if you aren't actively suffering from depression.

Sometimes depending on who you tell they all have different reactions... Eventually you start to feel useful again and the grey clouds start to go away... and possibly if you are lucky you can find that one person that will help you through anything.... you can make friends easily again and you can start to talk again... and eventually you will stop being so down all the time and saying sorry for every little thing... Eventually you can be happy again but not if you play this game... If you play this game you will learn alot about different theories of depression but if you play it while already having depression it can give you flashbacks to when you were like that or it can even make you hit a depression spike... Sometimes Depression is a scary thing and such a deep dark hole to try and climb out of... I warn you to not play it if you have depression.... But if you do... Dont fall backwards... Keep climbing out... You can talk to me if you need to....

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												As someone who has had a life-long struggle with depression, I was curious about this game (partially due to the controversy surrounding it, which has been written about to death so I won't do it here).  When I stumbled upon it, I decided to try it out.I'm a fan of visual novels which, for the uninitiated, the bulk of the "game" is reading text.  Visual novels tend to have images of the characters and backgrounds, which is part of its style and appeal.  Suffice it to say that it wasn't a great leap for me to switch over to the "gameplay" in Depression Quest.This game seems to set out to give the reader a taste of what it's like dealing with depression, although realistically it can't cover every possible life scenario such as class, gender, orientation, race, etc.  It describes the struggles of whether or not to include those close to you in your treatment, to see a therapist, to get on or continue with medication.  Learning about things like the 'feedback loops' that were mentioned can be life savers to folks dealing with depression.  To quote the old GIJoe cartoon, "Knowing is half the battle" and insofar as presenting the information in an interesting, descriptive manner, I think this game does that quite well.  It's a well-crafted game, although I'm not sure how well its replay value would be.My one gripe is very much with the music.  The piano riff put me in a negative mood before I read word one of the game.  I don't expect hyper anime-style music, but maybe something a little more neutral in tone would have been more suitable.I will recommend this game as it did resonate with my own personal struggles with depression and presented the information in a straightforward, entertaining manner.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												There seems to be alot of hate for this game that is utterly and completely blind and unstructured. Regardless of the circumstances around this game's development, one should never in a review look at anything else than the game. If any of the devs read this id like to thank them for the experience theyve provided me with. This is a work of talent and art, something very unique that hasnt been created before. The depictions of emotions and characters in this game are reflections of real life and i can certainly say with full honesty that 90% is accurate to the last detail. I call ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t on anyone who claims to be struggling with depression saying this game is dumb. Either they are lying, disrespectful morons who take the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of a serious condition, or they are in denial about themselves and i wish them to seriously take a deeper and more truthful look. The presentation of the game is simple and minimalistic, a stark contrast to the maze depression is. It works rather well and doesnt detract from the gameplay experience. The music is spot of with that melancholy and aimless vibe. This is an honest game that deserves attention. It may be more interactive fiction than a fullyfledged game but who cares, it is what it claimes to be. A critisism is the length. I do understand the possible constraints the devs had to work with but if a follow up was created on a much grander scale that can really suck one into the bleak and grey world, it could gain far more worldwide recognition. Finally id like to ask the devs to focus more on the literary aspect. It is beautifully written no doubt but more descriptive elements would solidify the atmosphere. I ask everyone to forget about the controversy behind this game and stop accusing it as "feminist". The game is specifically made to appeal to both men and women, there is nothing propagating a feminist message. Even if it is, why not support rights for women? Nothing wrong with that. Just stop whining and start being objective and open minded. If i had the means id donate to this project, yet sadly all i can do i spread the word and hope reasonable and solid people listen and support the game/work.

												It seems I am in the minority for enjoying this game. Sure, the game held your hand, and kind of forced you to make a few answers by cutting off others. But for me, that's how my depression worked, I wanted some things, but I could never bring myself to quite say it. My depressiong and PTSD is minor compared to many other people, but none the less, it's something I've had to suffer with, and this story did show many of the emotions I felt, and still do feel to this day. If you're looking for a game to have fun, this is not the one for you. But if you're hoping for a story, where you can at least learn a little about something like depression, I would recomend this game.

content:
Posted: April 28, 2016
												I know that this isn't intended to be a "game" in the sense that you have fun and find creative strategies to meet your goal. It is a story. A story that addresses a very serious, and often very misunderstood, issue. So I'm not going to judge this based off of the usual aspects I might on any other game in any other genre.This *experience*, from start to finish, was honestly a bit terrifying and often hit too close to home with me. I have depression and a lot of the scenarios the protagonist experienced felt as though they were ripped from my own life and molded into text. It was relatable. It was honest. It took an issue that so many find difficulty discussing and brought it into light. I actually cried at some points, won't lie. In my experience, things ended on quite the optimistic note. Things seemed to be getting better for the protagonist and, reading through this, it gives me hope that things will get better for me too.I doubt the creators of this game will ever read this, but if you do, I want to thank you from the bottom of my heart. Depression Quest is an absolute treasure.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												Having trained as an MSW, worked as a peer counselor in mental health and experienced years of depression myself I can say I applaud this game. As a game it is very simplistic, being more of a "choose your own adventure" story than what most would recognise as a game. If you're looking for dazzling graphics and high octane action then look elsewhere. However, Quinn and colleagues tell a good basic story of a person struggling to deal wth clinical depression. This game can provide some support for sufferers - indicating that there is hope as well as some of the ways of bringing that hope to reality. It can also provide a basic understanding of depression to would-be allies who don't know what it's like to be depressed. As such, it provides a potential bridge between people with depression and their support system and between the mental health field and the world outside it. Very well done.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												Well, Depression Quest. A free-to-play game about dealing with depression. Personally, I've never had to deal with myself or anyone in my family having depression. I'm sure this game gave the people who have a better understanding of the condition.Lots of lives are lost due to suicide every year, and most people think that commiting suicide is a selfish thing to do. People with depression actually can't get up and do anything, and this game illustrates and explains it perfectly.The protagonist delves deeper and deeper into his battle with depression, and through the story, you dip in and out of feeling amazing and feeling ♥♥♥♥♥♥. There's different things you can do, and in my playthough, I was set on "ending" my player's depression. I didn't purposely choose the bad choices, I didn't choose some good and some bad, I chose what I thought was best for my player. I'm not sure what happens if you choose to stop taking meds instead of taking them. I'm not sure what happens if you stop seeing your girlfriend. But this interactive story shows how difficult the decisions are for people who suffer from this.It's free, and it's eye opening. It gives you insight on how most people act, and what to do if you're ever affected by depression in any way.Overall: 8/10edit: soundtrack adds to the mood. its actually great!

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												Having trained as an MSW, worked as a peer counselor in mental health and experienced years of depression myself I can say I applaud this game. As a game it is very simplistic, being more of a "choose your own adventure" story than what most would recognise as a game. If you're looking for dazzling graphics and high octane action then look elsewhere. However, Quinn and colleagues tell a good basic story of a person struggling to deal wth clinical depression. This game can provide some support for sufferers - indicating that there is hope as well as some of the ways of bringing that hope to reality. It can also provide a basic understanding of depression to would-be allies who don't know what it's like to be depressed. As such, it provides a potential bridge between people with depression and their support system and between the mental health field and the world outside it. Very well done.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 16, 2016
												It's not a fun game, but it's not intended to be. This is a brave attempt to broaden the purpose of games, and to broaden the genre. It's a storytelling game that gives insight into what living with depression can be like. So this can be used to help people who have a depressed friend or loved one understand a little of what they're going through, and maybe give them some talking points to broach difficult subjects.I suffer from anxiety/depression myself.  I'm 45 years old, but had I played this game earlier in life, I can see how it could have positively influenced me.My only criticism is that it's a text adventure format.  I think it works for this subject matter, though.  Also, it's important to consider that there was a lot less funding for experimental games when this one was being produced.  Consider it a pioneering game in the indie field.All in all, I applaud the effort, and hope that people find it helpful. I also hope that we continue experimenting with therapeutic possibilities of games.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												Well, Depression Quest. A free-to-play game about dealing with depression. Personally, I've never had to deal with myself or anyone in my family having depression. I'm sure this game gave the people who have a better understanding of the condition.Lots of lives are lost due to suicide every year, and most people think that commiting suicide is a selfish thing to do. People with depression actually can't get up and do anything, and this game illustrates and explains it perfectly.The protagonist delves deeper and deeper into his battle with depression, and through the story, you dip in and out of feeling amazing and feeling ♥♥♥♥♥♥. There's different things you can do, and in my playthough, I was set on "ending" my player's depression. I didn't purposely choose the bad choices, I didn't choose some good and some bad, I chose what I thought was best for my player. I'm not sure what happens if you choose to stop taking meds instead of taking them. I'm not sure what happens if you stop seeing your girlfriend. But this interactive story shows how difficult the decisions are for people who suffer from this.It's free, and it's eye opening. It gives you insight on how most people act, and what to do if you're ever affected by depression in any way.Overall: 8/10edit: soundtrack adds to the mood. its actually great!

content:
Posted: November 12, 2015
												First of all, Depression Quest is not a game in any meaningful sense of the word at all. It’s an interactive set of multiple choice questions that lead absolutely nowhere.What the developers rather optimistically refer to as a “playthrough”, I managed to complete in about ten agonising minutes through severely gritted teeth. And no, it wasn’t long enough to get the point across; it would have needed about another thousand or two hours of teeth pulling for that to happen and still there would have been no point.The developers have classed this as a game and they call themselves game developers; on both counts they are hopelessly mistaken. A video game has atmosphere, a plot, very often a hero, and generally looks nice and is exciting to play. This is none of those things and one of the many things it lacks is guns, so that we could all blow our brains out by page five. This is not a game in any sense of the word and it would be more fitting to describe it as cruelty to the depressed and self inflicted punishment. Games are fun, this is not, so don’t insult us.It’s so easy to criticise the work of others and let’s face it, critics are just that; they produce very little or nothing at all. In this case, all the criticism Depression Quest has received is entirely justified for the simple reason that it’s a badly executed and irresponsible piece of  self congratulatory narcissism that should never have seen the light of day.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2015
												Well, that was something.So first, I won't even bother addressing the developer aspect. There are enough reviews that focus solely on the developers, and you can always read online to learn more about them.Second, to say that this isn't a game because the only elements are role play and choice, well would it help if there was a targeting reticule and a timer so that you could make the choice quicker? Maybe include some QTEs? If so, then it'd be no different than a Telltale Game (a developer I really like, by the way). In other words, I don't buy into the game/non-game debate. Interactive fiction is interactive fiction, regardless of the level of interaction required.Okay, so what is this? It's essentially an electronic choose-your-path adventure where the lead is already suffering from undiagnosed depression, but the decisions you make determine whether things spiral uncontrollably, worsen slightly, improve slightly, or even turn around.If you do not suffer from depression, this game may provide insight as to what people are saddled with on a daily basis. Then again, if you are one of the types who feel people should just stop feeling sad, then Depression Quest likely won't change your mind.If you do suffer from depression, you may find -- despite the fact that symptoms manifest differently in everyone -- elements of yourself depicted. In some cases, you may feel that every single page is ripped straight from your own life story.I played this game like I would with any other RPG with player choice: I played the opposite of how I believe myself to be. In other words, I sought help and I opened up to the people around me, much like how I'd flock to the dark side/bathe in evil points or whatever the particular currency happens to be in the title.In doing so, I... I felt uncomfortable. Like I was lying to myself, not to mention those around me. I felt guilty for leading them along, and pretending like things were okay. I went along with the therapist's advice, and even went out with people, and engaged my family in discussion.Afterward, I sat for a bit and wondered why I am unable to do these things in real life.Immediately, I restarted and chose the polar opposite of whatever I selected in my initial playthrough. In other words, how I really felt. It was disastrous. I sat for a bit longer. Why did I have a stronger emotional attachment to characters and choices in this piece of software compared to those around me? Around those who have stood by me, and attempted to support me?This was all a lot to absorb. I will need to dwell on this further.So, as you can see, not everyone will have the same reaction to Depression Quest. The unfortunate thing is while emotional and psychological variances are bound to occur, the narrative differences regardless of choices are slight. As you can imagine, the polar opposites yield dramatically different results at certain junctures, but it is otherwise the same regardless. I would have preferred to see more variety, and a few more callbacks to earlier choices, rather than copied and pasted pages that happen at preset times. Not only to encourage replays, an act that also could help people on both sides see how the littlest decision can have a profound impact, but also to make the experience more unique for the end user.Huh. I think I spent more time writing about this free game, a 30-minute text adventure, than for anything else in my library. Food for thought.

content:
Posted: September 19, 2014
												Is an expository piece still a game?  It depends on your definition of “game”, but is it still worth your time? Certainly.  I have always considered a game to be anything distracting that forces me to think and to feel for someone or something other than myself while maintaining a degree of interactivity.  Depression Quest is, above all else, an expository piece with some aspects of a more traditional game but to me it is a moving experience and certainly deserving of the title “game”. The gameplay such as it was is limited to using either the mouse or keyboard to scroll through text and to make decisions as the protagonist.  You aren’t going to be blasting bad guys or jumping over spikes.  The stated goal of the game is to depict depression as the developers have experienced it and to let other sufferers know they are not alone and as far as I’m concerned they hit the mark both times.  The writing is quite good, at times being quite poignant though at others it doesn’t have as nice a ring as it frequently does.  More often than not, it expresses surprisingly well the less concrete emotions one feels both during depression and day to day life.  What few editing errors I noticed were easily overlooked, mostly because the writer had distracted me with my feelings towards my character and myself.  The game has a very ambiguous tone throughout with regards to the personal life of the protagonist, who you “play” as.  Your job is vaguely defined, as are many other elements of the protagonists life which allows the player to more easily put themselves in the protagonists’ shoes.  I felt that I could draw parallels between my own life and the protagonists, which made the game have more of an emotional impact.  Depression  Quest is a concept more than a game.  Some traditional aspects of games such as combat, more interactivity and a well-defined conclusion have gone by the wayside to further the goals of this conceptual exposition to great effect, in my opinion.  This is not a game for people with a narrow definition of “game”, but if you’re looking for something that will make you think and feel, Depression Quest is for you.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
												Let me preface this review with one statement:As far as I know, I've never been depressed. I, like everyone, have had bad days, but nothing severe enough to consider depression.That said, the mission statement of the game seemed to be that depression is more than just being a downer or being mopey or a whiner.However, I found that the gameplay doesn't support this mission statement.Whenever I came to a decision to make, I chose what felt reasonable to me, a non depressed person. Don't feel like going out with your girlfriend to a party? eh, just do it anyway because it will make her happy. Even then, I chose to stalk in the corner and not to talk to anyone, but it didn't seem to matter.Should I call a therapist? Yes. Should I continue seeing the therapist? yes. Should I tell people that I'm depressed? Yes. Should I stay on my medication, even when I am feeling a little better? yes. Should I move in with my obviously loving and awesome girlfriend? Yes.And at the end of the game, I was living with my girlfriend, seeing a therapist, on medication, with an adorable kitty and my family was very accepting of my condition. I still didn't really like my job, but I realized it was a small part of my life and just something to get through. I was being more sociable with friends and, for the most part, fighting through my depression very well.There was never anything that would imply a depressed person is incapable of making these decisions. The game is, essentially, implying that depressed people are just being little ♥♥♥♥♥es and intentionally making the wrong decisions.That said, I enjoyed the narrative and the choices, though intentionally limited, felt like I could control my fate, rather than being told that I'm depressed, so I can't possibly recover.It's a free game and it only takes and hour, and I found it rather enjoyable.Despite its failure to meet its mission statement, I did feel like it enhanced my understanding of the thought processes depressed people go to in order to will themselves back to a good state. So I think I would recommend this game, as I have played many many worse games than this.
