content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												Very usefull tool for someone with depression or someone who knows someone with depression.  While it's not necissarily entertaining in the typical sense, it does a very good job of allowing you to see through the eyes of someone with clinical depression.  Or, in my case, making it even more clear that I have clinical depression.This isn't so much of a game but an educational tool.  It's not fun.  It's not something you'd play to relax.  But what it sets out to do it does very well.  There's not much in the way of graphics, being a texted based adventure game, but the sound design is wonderfully crafted.  It's oppressive, which is exactly the right mindset to be in for the game.So, good game, but if you're looking for something to have fun with, you'd be better off with pratically anything else.  However, if you're interested in learning about depression, this is a wonderfully crafted glimps into that awful awful place.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22
												This is an iconic game and, perhaps, not for the right reasons.Beyond the post gammergate fuss it's worth assessing this game as a stand alone experience, as a game in it's own right not as an exercise in either alt-right baiting or alt-right propagandising.As such this game stands up as a worthwhile experience.The game mechanics are simple: you have a list of options available to you each time a decision is made. you begin with most of these unavailable as you fall into depression and then as you are offered options such as speaking to loved ones and seeking professional help more options become available. if you choose not to the options narrow again, if you choose to open up to others and seek help more options become available.This is a simple but effective game mechanic and is effective in mimicking the path depression may take.No, the game is not 'fun' but why should games be fun and why are the mainstream games which offer you opportunities to do nothing but kill 'fun?'This is a game about emotional states and it is a work of art. if this is not what you are after from a game then don't play it and don't review it but don't trash the game the same way i would not trash a FPS.

												I would only recommend it if you want to get someone's point of view of depression, if you need an eye opener into depression. I would not really recommend this game, after having just played about 10 - 15 minutes of the game.Depression Quest is a game that will give you a deep insight into what a person is going through a deep depression experiences with daily life and activities. It is a choose your own adventure game that keeps track of your decisions in three ways: how depressed you are (like normal depression or deeply depressed) which affects what choices you can make, if you're seeing a therapist or not (and how much you feel motivated to going to more sessions), and if you're taking medication for your depression. This was a dark story in terms of how your character deals with depression because most of the choices that were crossed out were choices that had a definite yes or no answer. The choices that were crossed out becomes more frequent, the more depressed you are. You mostly had choices where you would second guess yourself and everything about people's opinion of you. I never reached the end of the game but it is a game that I would like to finish to see how it ends. The game does achieve its goal of making you depressed and trying to give you the same experience as your character. So it's not a terrible game but if you play it, be prepared to come out of this game with a negative feeling.

I understand everyone has a different experience with depression, and I found that this game lined up with my own rather well. The crossed out options are directly influenced by your choices in the game, and those crossed-out options are a perfect game mechanic to illustrate the crippling nature of depression and shows how certain actions and choices can worsen the onset. I recommend this game with the caveat that you remember that this is not a game intended to have fun. If you want a shot at seeing what depression is like, go for it.

												Honestly, I enjoyed it thoroughly. Sitebender explained the experience very well, and I'm glad he wasn't part of the typical ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t I'm seeing on these reviews. Legitimately, I'm actually annoyed just by seeing the freaking Burger Joint reviews on this page. Granted, I haven't read up on the full story on Zoe, or Vivian James, only bits and pieces. I just found the story only around an hour or so ago.Surprisingly, I got the good ending the first playthrough. Ended with him reminescing on his past few months, and telling his mom during Thanksgiving Dinner with family, "I'm good, Mom.", and him sure that he could feel his mom's smile appearing.I've never been depressed myself, and while I may not always be able to empathize with friends who go through depression, I can certainly say that I will always sympathize, and do my best to give them my fully-fledged support. I can't even count how many times I've had to pull my friends through so many horrible ruts. Just having someone to talk to can help.And especially to that last piece, you're definitely right. Hugs for everyone. ^_^*Spoilers for the game go under here*It was somewhat difficult to choose correctly, but I did choose to be openly honest with Alex, chose to help Attic, played with my kitty, and I did choose to take Therapy, and the medication. Gradually, my depression state improved overtime. I had one fluctation where I was extremely depressed, but I can't remember if that was avoidable at the time or not. While it wasn't met to be fun, I certainly found the interactive story enjoyable to play.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
												This is an honest and personal interactive narrative.  The crossing out of choices that you know you should make is an effective and elegant mechanic.  It's a very individual story so you are not going to get the opportunity to craft an experience that matches your own—this is not the Minecraft of depression (as some reviews seem to indicate that it should be, with their ridiculously high expectations of what this game should allow them to do), and as such it leaves room for more than one game about depression.  Hopefully it inspires other people to tell their own stories.

												It's... okay? Like, everyone experiences depression differently so I can't say this is terribly inaccurate, but the way it railroads you doesn't make it feel like an 'accurate' representation either. More importantly, I feel like the music and overall presentation of the game kind of detracts from the punch. Like, depression, at least to me, is just kind of static. I don't need the sad music to try to tug at my heartstrings. Depression is horrible but it's also mundane. I guess the issue comes down to that because everyone experiences depression differently, you can't really nail it down with one interperetation, and I feel that the biggest flaw of the game is that it seems to introduce itself like it is THE interperetation. Overal, tenuous recommendation if you know people with depression, but not recommended if you already suffer, because you likely won't take anything helpful away from it.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2015
												Honestly, I'm not really sure why people don't like this game; in fact I thought it was quite good. And if you take the time to read the first page, it really is exactly what it says it is, interactive-fiction; if you don't like reading, you're probably not going to like this game.I liked that your character couldn't just do the easy thing in a lot of the choices because it illustrates how people with the illness may not be able to make the easy choices in the same way someone without it would. I believe it's a fairly accurate demonstration of how depression can look; though, I do think it would have been cool if the game had more than one story to show how depression might look for people from other walks of life. I also think it could be used as a tool to teach people who don't know about depression what it can be like.Overall I'd say it's pretty good, it's free and not too long so it's worth a play.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
												Let me preface this review with one statement:As far as I know, I've never been depressed. I, like everyone, have had bad days, but nothing severe enough to consider depression.That said, the mission statement of the game seemed to be that depression is more than just being a downer or being mopey or a whiner.However, I found that the gameplay doesn't support this mission statement.Whenever I came to a decision to make, I chose what felt reasonable to me, a non depressed person. Don't feel like going out with your girlfriend to a party? eh, just do it anyway because it will make her happy. Even then, I chose to stalk in the corner and not to talk to anyone, but it didn't seem to matter.Should I call a therapist? Yes. Should I continue seeing the therapist? yes. Should I tell people that I'm depressed? Yes. Should I stay on my medication, even when I am feeling a little better? yes. Should I move in with my obviously loving and awesome girlfriend? Yes.And at the end of the game, I was living with my girlfriend, seeing a therapist, on medication, with an adorable kitty and my family was very accepting of my condition. I still didn't really like my job, but I realized it was a small part of my life and just something to get through. I was being more sociable with friends and, for the most part, fighting through my depression very well.There was never anything that would imply a depressed person is incapable of making these decisions. The game is, essentially, implying that depressed people are just being little ♥♥♥♥♥es and intentionally making the wrong decisions.That said, I enjoyed the narrative and the choices, though intentionally limited, felt like I could control my fate, rather than being told that I'm depressed, so I can't possibly recover.It's a free game and it only takes and hour, and I found it rather enjoyable.Despite its failure to meet its mission statement, I did feel like it enhanced my understanding of the thought processes depressed people go to in order to will themselves back to a good state. So I think I would recommend this game, as I have played many many worse games than this.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
												I was skeptical about this game at first; given the title, I thought it was going to be a game that turns depression into a joke, but that most certainly was not the case. As I was reading the first page that talks about the game and the goal they (the creators) hope to reach, I had a change of heart and thought that the game might actually have some realism to it and that it could possibly be an enjoyable experience (which is was).As someone who has battled depression within this past year (2014), I felt a connection to the character that you play out. There is a trigger warning on this game, so be warned. Some parts brought back up some memories of how I had felt and what I had gone through, which caused me to tear up and even cry at a few parts because those memories are still quite fresh and most definitly painful. If you are looking for a fun game, look somewhere else. This game wasn't designed or intended to be fun. It's more about the experience that you get from playing this game that is truly what makes it worth a playthrough.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
												I was skeptical about this game at first; given the title, I thought it was going to be a game that turns depression into a joke, but that most certainly was not the case. As I was reading the first page that talks about the game and the goal they (the creators) hope to reach, I had a change of heart and thought that the game might actually have some realism to it and that it could possibly be an enjoyable experience (which is was).As someone who has battled depression within this past year (2014), I felt a connection to the character that you play out. There is a trigger warning on this game, so be warned. Some parts brought back up some memories of how I had felt and what I had gone through, which caused me to tear up and even cry at a few parts because those memories are still quite fresh and most definitly painful. If you are looking for a fun game, look somewhere else. This game wasn't designed or intended to be fun. It's more about the experience that you get from playing this game that is truly what makes it worth a playthrough.

content:
Posted: February 14
												This game is fantastic! I really enjoyed it. It's a simple text based adventure game where you play as a depressed person. At the begining of the game this person does not realise that he has depresion. The game ofers variuos ways to help yourself in life. While playing the first time I tried to choose the options that would fit my own tactics in similar situations the best. And got the brightest ending. Then I wondered that maybe that's because I don't have depression and then tried to play again deliberatly choosing the worst possible options.... and got the worst ending :SThis game is short, easy to play, and teaches a lot about yourself and other. Would recommend to anybody looking how to spend and not to waste a spare hour. PS music is fantastic!

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22
												This is an iconic game and, perhaps, not for the right reasons.Beyond the post gammergate fuss it's worth assessing this game as a stand alone experience, as a game in it's own right not as an exercise in either alt-right baiting or alt-right propagandising.As such this game stands up as a worthwhile experience.The game mechanics are simple: you have a list of options available to you each time a decision is made. you begin with most of these unavailable as you fall into depression and then as you are offered options such as speaking to loved ones and seeking professional help more options become available. if you choose not to the options narrow again, if you choose to open up to others and seek help more options become available.This is a simple but effective game mechanic and is effective in mimicking the path depression may take.No, the game is not 'fun' but why should games be fun and why are the mainstream games which offer you opportunities to do nothing but kill 'fun?'This is a game about emotional states and it is a work of art. if this is not what you are after from a game then don't play it and don't review it but don't trash the game the same way i would not trash a FPS.

content:
Posted: September 9, 2014
												I'd consider this more of a life experience then a "game"This hits a lot of points at home for a guy like me.Normally when you think of depression, you just think of a person being sad about something that has happened."They'll get over it" you say.But it's never that easy.Depression can't just fade away.And a lot of times, it over takes you.You start to lose sight of who you really are, and your thoughts become so cloudy to the point where a rational thought is the equilivant of Gaben making a third instalment of a game.And sometimes, even when it's "gone", you think of it.You think back to those times, and it trys to make its way back into your life.I was depressed my whole life untill recently.When I was three years old, I was mauled by a dog.I lost my ears, and my face was full of scars to the point where I looked like I had enough stitchs in my face to patch up an entire leg wound.As a result, I never felt apart of anything.I was always a diffrent person then everyone.I didn't know what I liked, I didn't know what I wanted, but at the same time I didn't wanna be alone.So I did everything I could to try to fit in.I became a shadow of everyone else.I was like this for a very long period of my life.Eventually, I hit freshmen year.I was this angsty teen who had no interest in school.I just wanted to fit in, and I didn't care how I managed to do it.But then, I met a man.He was a senior when I met him, and we had an odd first meeting.He showed me a new side to life.It was in that class we had where I learned about some of the many things I've come to love in my life, such as Gmod, Tf2, and even MLP back then.It felt like a gate was opened for the first time in my life back then.And what was at the other side of the gate you might ask?A light so bright that even to this day, it still shines to the point where it is almost blinding.I have three best friends that I can always talk to, I've been going to conventions, auctually hanging out with people on weekends and not being locked inside my house like a ♥♥♥♥ing animal.And I have a girlfriend, a girl who I love more then anything.I think the main point of this story is that you shouldn't hesitate to reach out to others.Chances are, that person holds the key to the missing parts of your life.And unless you try to find them, You'll end up another shadow like I was.I can't stress enough how much you should experince this.

												I attempted playing this game months ago and couldn't get myself to read through the first few pages. I ended up throwing in the towel. After a friend of mine suggested this game to me, I made my way back. This is a game that you have to give a fighting chance to. It has a rough start, but once you get into it, you realize how important it is. It allows you to view depression from the perspective of someone suffering. It's an eye opener. If you enjoy reading and can stand to read a short novel- you'll really enjoy this. It's a bit depressing, hence the title, but it's a good story that keeps you engaged.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2016
												This game reminded me what it was like when I was severely depressed. It also reminded me that I, like the protagonist, have come a long way. I don't think the protagonist was portrayed as lazy, and I don't think it was cheap that some of the "better" options were not allowed to be picked. I think some of the people writing reviews forget that every person is different, and depression will affect people differently. Not every person will have the inner will power and determination to fight through their depression, especially since for the first third of the game, the protagonist didn't even acknowledge that they had depression. Also, it makes no sense to me that people are giving this game a poor review simply because it's a free game. Seriously?

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												This... is not much of a game. I will point that out straight away. I find it inappropriate to call it one.But being all about words and discreet visuals, it's all about putting you in the state of mind of someone who is depressed.So it's all about words and reading. But the writing isn't too great and there's minor typos (such as "Camero", missing punctuation, etc.). And the language is rather plain. Yet, most depressed people would hardly be poetic, so it fits. (Mind you, some also become much more poetic, penning miserable pieces that only spread the melancholy.Audio-visually, Depression Quest presents itself simply, static filters and little environmental sound effects set to a constant piano loop (albeit one too short). The points are delivered.There is no gameplay. It is simply a mildly branching story. And it's short. You can finish a readthrough in less than half an hour. (Then again, I'm a relatively fast reader.)So how realistic is it? You'll likely find other reviews suggesting it is not. But, it is.People do not understand "depression". For most people, the "blues" just come and go. They don't constantly eat away at you. Depression Quest depicts someone suffering from this "unnatural" state of mind, a medical condition that has only become officially recognized in the last half a century.The character's situation is given little backstory. Though, one might find the situation "promising" and good, that it's actually such good circumstances that there's no reason to be unhappy. Yet, the seemingly most successful and happy stars have killed themselves, and depression is an ailment that can strike anybody without reason. Just like a genetic defect.Perhaps it's not a fully accurate representation. It probably isn't. Perhaps you, a non-sufferer, feel it's absolutely ridiculous; that the character you play has a totally obnoxious way of thinking. Perhaps you are a sufferer, undergoing treatment or otherwise and you find that the story does not match your experience.Depression is a highly individualized ailment. If it were to be described as a criminal, it would be one who modifies their strategy to the individual target, striking them oh so differently.Just go ahead and read the Discussions on the Community Hub, or even anywhere else. The realism of the story has been debated there and so forth.But how do I recommend this? In short, I can't really recommend it. It's something that won't be enjoyable. But, if you intend to experience Depression Quest, enjoyment should not be your objective. You should want to "play" Depression Quest to experience one viewpoint (of many possible) of a medical ailment.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
												TL:DR - If TL:DR applies to you, then a game that's 99% reading isn't for you.Is this a game? Loosely.      There is little interaction and your choices don't specifically carry on to influence later options. They do, however, accumulate as a state of mind which impacts the number of options available. You are, in essence, taking on the role of someone who doesn't know they have depression as they fight the downward spiral. That's a deeper characterization than many games I've played.Should you play it? That depends. 1) Do you have depression? 2) Are you interested in learning more about what people with depression deal with?     If 1), 2), or both apply to you, then: Yes. It's an informative look into what is still a widely misunderstood illness. And it's more interesting than just reading dry scientific data.     If neither apply to you, then: No. You won't gain any entertainment value or added perspective from this.Overall: I like it and intend on replaying it now and then to see how different scenarios play out. Thanks to the developers for doing it well, releasing it for free, and getting it on Steam for a wider audience.
